children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Dorothy lived in the midst of the great Kansas prairies, with Uncle Henry, who was a farmer, and Aunt Em, who was the farmer's wife.  Their house was small, for the lumber to build it had to be carried by wagon many miles.  There were four walls, a floor and a roof, which made one room; and this room contained a rusty looking cookstove, a cupboard for the dishes, a table, three or four chairs, and the beds.  Uncle Henry and Aunt Em had a big bed in one corner, and Dorothy a little bed in another corner.  There was no garret at all, and no cellar--except a small hole dug in the ground, called a cyclone cellar, where the family could go in case one of those great whirlwinds arose, mighty enough to crush any building in its path.  It was reached by a trap door in the middle of the floor, from which a ladder led down into the small, dark hole.
children.prevalue: Dorothy lived in the midst of the great Kansas prairies with Uncle Henry who was a farmer and Aunt Em who was the farmer s wife Their house was small for the lumber to build it had to be carried by wagon many miles There were four walls a floor and a roof which made one room and this room contained a rusty looking cookstove a cupboard for the dishes a table three or four chairs and the beds Uncle Henry and Aunt Em had a big bed in one corner and Dorothy a little bed in another corner There was no garret at all and no cellar except a small hole dug in the ground called a cyclone cellar where the family could go in case one of those great whirlwinds arose mighty enough to crush any building in its path It was reached by a trap door in the middle of the floor from which a ladder led down into the small dark hole

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: When Dorothy stood in the doorway and looked around, she could see nothing but the great gray prairie on every side.  Not a tree nor a house broke the broad sweep of flat country that reached to the edge of the sky in all directions.  The sun had baked the plowed land into a gray mass, with little cracks running through it.  Even the grass was not green, for the sun had burned the tops of the long blades until they were the same gray color to be seen everywhere.  Once the house had been painted, but the sun blistered the paint and the rains washed it away, and now the house was as dull and gray as everything else.
children.prevalue: When Dorothy stood in the doorway and looked around she could see nothing but the great gray prairie on every side Not a tree nor a house broke the broad sweep of flat country that reached to the edge of the sky in all directions The sun had baked the plowed land into a gray mass with little cracks running through it Even the grass was not green for the sun had burned the tops of the long blades until they were the same gray color to be seen everywhere Once the house had been painted but the sun blistered the paint and the rains washed it away and now the house was as dull and gray as everything else

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: When Aunt Em came there to live she was a young, pretty wife.  The sun and wind had changed her, too.  They had taken the sparkle from her eyes and left them a sober gray; they had taken the red from her cheeks and lips, and they were gray also.  She was thin and gaunt, and never smiled now.  When Dorothy, who was an orphan, first came to her, Aunt Em had been so startled by the child's laughter that she would scream and press her hand upon her heart whenever Dorothy's merry voice reached her ears; and she still looked at the little girl with wonder that she could find anything to laugh at.
children.prevalue: When Aunt Em came there to live she was a young pretty wife The sun and wind had changed her too They had taken the sparkle from her eyes and left them a sober gray they had taken the red from her cheeks and lips and they were gray also She was thin and gaunt and never smiled now When Dorothy who was an orphan first came to her Aunt Em had been so startled by the child s laughter that she would scream and press her hand upon her heart whenever Dorothy s merry voice reached her ears and she still looked at the little girl with wonder that she could find anything to laugh at

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Uncle Henry never laughed.  He worked hard from morning till night and did not know what joy was.  He was gray also, from his long beard to his rough boots, and he looked stern and solemn, and rarely spoke.
children.prevalue: Uncle Henry never laughed He worked hard from morning till night and did not know what joy was He was gray also from his long beard to his rough boots and he looked stern and solemn and rarely spoke

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: It was Toto that made Dorothy laugh, and saved her from growing as gray as her other surroundings.  Toto was not gray; he was a little black dog, with long silky hair and small black eyes that twinkled merrily on either side of his funny, wee nose.  Toto played all day long, and Dorothy played with him, and loved him dearly.
children.prevalue: It was Toto that made Dorothy laugh and saved her from growing as gray as her other surroundings Toto was not gray he was a little black dog with long silky hair and small black eyes that twinkled merrily on either side of his funny wee nose Toto played all day long and Dorothy played with him and loved him dearly

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Today, however, they were not playing.  Uncle Henry sat upon the doorstep and looked anxiously at the sky, which was even grayer than usual.  Dorothy stood in the door with Toto in her arms, and looked at the sky too.  Aunt Em was washing the dishes.
children.prevalue: Today however they were not playing Uncle Henry sat upon the doorstep and looked anxiously at the sky which was even grayer than usual Dorothy stood in the door with Toto in her arms and looked at the sky too Aunt Em was washing the dishes

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: From the far north they heard a low wail of the wind, and Uncle Henry and Dorothy could see where the long grass bowed in waves before the coming storm.  There now came a sharp whistling in the air from the south, and as they turned their eyes that way they saw ripples in the grass coming from that direction also.
children.prevalue: From the far north they heard a low wail of the wind and Uncle Henry and Dorothy could see where the long grass bowed in waves before the coming storm There now came a sharp whistling in the air from the south and as they turned their eyes that way they saw ripples in the grass coming from that direction also

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Suddenly Uncle Henry stood up.
children.prevalue: Suddenly Uncle Henry stood up

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: There's a cyclone coming, Em, he called to his wife.  I'll go look after the stock.  Then he ran toward the sheds where the cows and horses were kept.
children.prevalue: There s a cyclone coming Em he called to his wife I ll go look after the stock Then he ran toward the sheds where the cows and horses were kept

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Aunt Em dropped her work and came to the door.  One glance told her of the danger close at hand.
children.prevalue: Aunt Em dropped her work and came to the door One glance told her of the danger close at hand

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Quick, Dorothy! she screamed.  Run for the cellar!
children.prevalue: Quick Dorothy she screamed Run for the cellar

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Toto jumped out of Dorothy's arms and hid under the bed, and the girl started to get him.  Aunt Em, badly frightened, threw open the trap door in the floor and climbed down the ladder into the small, dark hole.  Dorothy caught Toto at last and started to follow her aunt. When she was halfway across the room there came a great shriek from the wind, and the house shook so hard that she lost her footing and sat down suddenly upon the floor.
children.prevalue: Toto jumped out of Dorothy s arms and hid under the bed and the girl started to get him Aunt Em badly frightened threw open the trap door in the floor and climbed down the ladder into the small dark hole Dorothy caught Toto at last and started to follow her aunt When she was halfway across the room there came a great shriek from the wind and the house shook so hard that she lost her footing and sat down suddenly upon the floor

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Then a strange thing happened.
children.prevalue: Then a strange thing happened

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: The house whirled around two or three times and rose slowly through the air.  Dorothy felt as if she were going up in a balloon.
children.prevalue: The house whirled around two or three times and rose slowly through the air Dorothy felt as if she were going up in a balloon

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: The north and south winds met where the house stood, and made it the exact center of the cyclone.  In the middle of a cyclone the air is generally still, but the great pressure of the wind on every side of the house raised it up higher and higher, until it was at the very top of the cyclone; and there it remained and was carried miles and miles away as easily as you could carry a feather.
children.prevalue: The north and south winds met where the house stood and made it the exact center of the cyclone In the middle of a cyclone the air is generally still but the great pressure of the wind on every side of the house raised it up higher and higher until it was at the very top of the cyclone and there it remained and was carried miles and miles away as easily as you could carry a feather

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: It was very dark, and the wind howled horribly around her, but Dorothy found she was riding quite easily.  After the first few whirls around, and one other time when the house tipped badly, she felt as if she were being rocked gently, like a baby in a cradle.
children.prevalue: It was very dark and the wind howled horribly around her but Dorothy found she was riding quite easily After the first few whirls around and one other time when the house tipped badly she felt as if she were being rocked gently like a baby in a cradle

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Toto did not like it.  He ran about the room, now here, now there, barking loudly; but Dorothy sat quite still on the floor and waited to see what would happen.
children.prevalue: Toto did not like it He ran about the room now here now there barking loudly but Dorothy sat quite still on the floor and waited to see what would happen

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Once Toto got too near the open trap door, and fell in; and at first the little girl thought she had lost him.  But soon she saw one of his ears sticking up through the hole, for the strong pressure of the air was keeping him up so that he could not fall.  She crept to the hole, caught Toto by the ear, and dragged him into the room again, afterward closing the trap door so that no more accidents could happen.
children.prevalue: Once Toto got too near the open trap door and fell in and at first the little girl thought she had lost him But soon she saw one of his ears sticking up through the hole for the strong pressure of the air was keeping him up so that he could not fall She crept to the hole caught Toto by the ear and dragged him into the room again afterward closing the trap door so that no more accidents could happen

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Hour after hour passed away, and slowly Dorothy got over her fright; but she felt quite lonely, and the wind shrieked so loudly all about her that she nearly became deaf.  At first she had wondered if she would be dashed to pieces when the house fell again; but as the hours passed and nothing terrible happened, she stopped worrying and resolved to wait calmly and see what the future would bring.  At last she crawled over the swaying floor to her bed, and lay down upon it; and Toto followed and lay down beside her.
children.prevalue: Hour after hour passed away and slowly Dorothy got over her fright but she felt quite lonely and the wind shrieked so loudly all about her that she nearly became deaf At first she had wondered if she would be dashed to pieces when the house fell again but as the hours passed and nothing terrible happened she stopped worrying and resolved to wait calmly and see what the future would bring At last she crawled over the swaying floor to her bed and lay down upon it and Toto followed and lay down beside her

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: In spite of the swaying of the house and the wailing of the wind, Dorothy soon closed her eyes and fell fast asleep.
children.prevalue: In spite of the swaying of the house and the wailing of the wind Dorothy soon closed her eyes and fell fast asleep

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: She was awakened by a shock, so sudden and severe that if Dorothy had not been lying on the soft bed she might have been hurt.  As it was, the jar made her catch her breath and wonder what had happened; and Toto put his cold little nose into her face and whined dismally. Dorothy sat up and noticed that the house was not moving; nor was it dark, for the bright sunshine came in at the window, flooding the little room.  She sprang from her bed and with Toto at her heels ran and opened the door.
children.prevalue: She was awakened by a shock so sudden and severe that if Dorothy had not been lying on the soft bed she might have been hurt As it was the jar made her catch her breath and wonder what had happened and Toto put his cold little nose into her face and whined dismally Dorothy sat up and noticed that the house was not moving nor was it dark for the bright sunshine came in at the window flooding the little room She sprang from her bed and with Toto at her heels ran and opened the door

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The little girl gave a cry of amazement and looked about her, her eyes growing bigger and bigger at the wonderful sights she saw.
children.prevalue: The little girl gave a cry of amazement and looked about her her eyes growing bigger and bigger at the wonderful sights she saw

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: The cyclone had set the house down very gently--for a cyclone--in the midst of a country of marvelous beauty.  There were lovely patches of greensward all about, with stately trees bearing rich and luscious fruits.  Banks of gorgeous flowers were on every hand, and birds with rare and brilliant plumage sang and fluttered in the trees and bushes. A little way off was a small brook, rushing and sparkling along between green banks, and murmuring in a voice very grateful to a little girl who had lived so long on the dry, gray prairies.
children.prevalue: The cyclone had set the house down very gently for a cyclone in the midst of a country of marvelous beauty There were lovely patches of greensward all about with stately trees bearing rich and luscious fruits Banks of gorgeous flowers were on every hand and birds with rare and brilliant plumage sang and fluttered in the trees and bushes A little way off was a small brook rushing and sparkling along between green banks and murmuring in a voice very grateful to a little girl who had lived so long on the dry gray prairies

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: While she stood looking eagerly at the strange and beautiful sights, she noticed coming toward her a group of the queerest people she had ever seen.  They were not as big as the grown folk she had always been used to; but neither were they very small.  In fact, they seemed about as tall as Dorothy, who was a well-grown child for her age, although they were, so far as looks go, many years older.
children.prevalue: While she stood looking eagerly at the strange and beautiful sights she noticed coming toward her a group of the queerest people she had ever seen They were not as big as the grown folk she had always been used to but neither were they very small In fact they seemed about as tall as Dorothy who was a well grown child for her age although they were so far as looks go many years older

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Three were men and one a woman, and all were oddly dressed.  They wore round hats that rose to a small point a foot above their heads, with little bells around the brims that tinkled sweetly as they moved.  The hats of the men were blue; the little woman's hat was white, and she wore a white gown that hung in pleats from her shoulders.  Over it were sprinkled little stars that glistened in the sun like diamonds.  The men were dressed in blue, of the same shade as their hats, and wore well-polished boots with a deep roll of blue at the tops.  The men, Dorothy thought, were about as old as Uncle Henry, for two of them had beards.  But the little woman was doubtless much older.  Her face was covered with wrinkles, her hair was nearly white, and she walked rather stiffly.
children.prevalue: Three were men and one a woman and all were oddly dressed They wore round hats that rose to a small point a foot above their heads with little bells around the brims that tinkled sweetly as they moved The hats of the men were blue the little woman s hat was white and she wore a white gown that hung in pleats from her shoulders Over it were sprinkled little stars that glistened in the sun like diamonds The men were dressed in blue of the same shade as their hats and wore well polished boots with a deep roll of blue at the tops The men Dorothy thought were about as old as Uncle Henry for two of them had beards But the little woman was doubtless much older Her face was covered with wrinkles her hair was nearly white and she walked rather stiffly

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: When these people drew near the house where Dorothy was standing in the doorway, they paused and whispered among themselves, as if afraid to come farther.  But the little old woman walked up to Dorothy, made a low bow and said, in a sweet voice:
children.prevalue: When these people drew near the house where Dorothy was standing in the doorway they paused and whispered among themselves as if afraid to come farther But the little old woman walked up to Dorothy made a low bow and said in a sweet voice

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: You are welcome, most noble Sorceress, to the land of the Munchkins. We are so grateful to you for having killed the Wicked Witch of the East, and for setting our people free from bondage.
children.prevalue: You are welcome most noble Sorceress to the land of the Munchkins We are so grateful to you for having killed the Wicked Witch of the East and for setting our people free from bondage

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Dorothy listened to this speech with wonder.  What could the little woman possibly mean by calling her a sorceress, and saying she had killed the Wicked Witch of the East?  Dorothy was an innocent, harmless little girl, who had been carried by a cyclone many miles from home; and she had never killed anything in all her life.
children.prevalue: Dorothy listened to this speech with wonder What could the little woman possibly mean by calling her a sorceress and saying she had killed the Wicked Witch of the East Dorothy was an innocent harmless little girl who had been carried by a cyclone many miles from home and she had never killed anything in all her life

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: But the little woman evidently expected her to answer; so Dorothy said, with hesitation, You are very kind, but there must be some mistake.  I have not killed anything.
children.prevalue: But the little woman evidently expected her to answer so Dorothy said with hesitation You are very kind but there must be some mistake I have not killed anything

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Your house did, anyway, replied the little old woman, with a laugh, and that is the same thing.  See! she continued, pointing to the corner of the house.  There are her two feet, still sticking out from under a block of wood.
children.prevalue: Your house did anyway replied the little old woman with a laugh and that is the same thing See she continued pointing to the corner of the house There are her two feet still sticking out from under a block of wood

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Dorothy looked, and gave a little cry of fright.  There, indeed, just under the corner of the great beam the house rested on, two feet were sticking out, shod in silver shoes with pointed toes.
children.prevalue: Dorothy looked and gave a little cry of fright There indeed just under the corner of the great beam the house rested on two feet were sticking out shod in silver shoes with pointed toes

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Oh, dear!  Oh, dear! cried Dorothy, clasping her hands together in dismay.  The house must have fallen on her.  Whatever shall we do?
children.prevalue: Oh dear Oh dear cried Dorothy clasping her hands together in dismay The house must have fallen on her Whatever shall we do

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: There is nothing to be done, said the little woman calmly.
children.prevalue: There is nothing to be done said the little woman calmly

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: But who was she? asked Dorothy.
children.prevalue: But who was she asked Dorothy

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: She was the Wicked Witch of the East, as I said, answered the little woman.  She has held all the Munchkins in bondage for many years, making them slave for her night and day.  Now they are all set free, and are grateful to you for the favor.
children.prevalue: She was the Wicked Witch of the East as I said answered the little woman She has held all the Munchkins in bondage for many years making them slave for her night and day Now they are all set free and are grateful to you for the favor

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Who are the Munchkins? inquired Dorothy.
children.prevalue: Who are the Munchkins inquired Dorothy

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: They are the people who live in this land of the East  where the Wicked Witch ruled.
children.prevalue: They are the people who live in this land of the East where the Wicked Witch ruled

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Are you a Munchkin? asked Dorothy.
children.prevalue: Are you a Munchkin asked Dorothy

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: No, but I am their friend, although I live in the land of the North. When they saw the Witch of the East was dead the Munchkins sent a swift messenger to me, and I came at once.  I am the Witch of the North.
children.prevalue: No but I am their friend although I live in the land of the North When they saw the Witch of the East was dead the Munchkins sent a swift messenger to me and I came at once I am the Witch of the North

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Oh, gracious! cried Dorothy.  Are you a real witch?
children.prevalue: Oh gracious cried Dorothy Are you a real witch

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Yes, indeed, answered the little woman.  But I am a good witch, and the people love me.  I am not as powerful as the Wicked Witch was who ruled here, or I should have set the people free myself.
children.prevalue: Yes indeed answered the little woman But I am a good witch and the people love me I am not as powerful as the Wicked Witch was who ruled here or I should have set the people free myself

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: But I thought all witches were wicked, said the girl, who was half frightened at facing a real witch.  Oh, no, that is a great mistake. There were only four witches in all the Land of Oz, and two of them, those who live in the North and the South, are good witches.  I know this is true, for I am one of them myself, and cannot be mistaken. Those who dwelt in the East and the West were, indeed, wicked witches; but now that you have killed one of them, there is but one Wicked Witch in all the Land of Oz--the one who lives in the West.
children.prevalue: But I thought all witches were wicked said the girl who was half frightened at facing a real witch Oh no that is a great mistake There were only four witches in all the Land of Oz and two of them those who live in the North and the South are good witches I know this is true for I am one of them myself and cannot be mistaken Those who dwelt in the East and the West were indeed wicked witches but now that you have killed one of them there is but one Wicked Witch in all the Land of Oz the one who lives in the West

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: But, said Dorothy, after a moment's thought, Aunt Em has told me that the witches were all dead--years and years ago.
children.prevalue: But said Dorothy after a moment s thought Aunt Em has told me that the witches were all dead years and years ago

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Who is Aunt Em? inquired the little old woman.
children.prevalue: Who is Aunt Em inquired the little old woman

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: She is my aunt who lives in Kansas, where I came from.
children.prevalue: She is my aunt who lives in Kansas where I came from

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: The Witch of the North seemed to think for a time, with her head bowed and her eyes upon the ground.  Then she looked up and said, I do not know where Kansas is, for I have never heard that country mentioned before.  But tell me, is it a civilized country?
children.prevalue: The Witch of the North seemed to think for a time with her head bowed and her eyes upon the ground Then she looked up and said I do not know where Kansas is for I have never heard that country mentioned before But tell me is it a civilized country

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Oh, yes, replied Dorothy.
children.prevalue: Oh yes replied Dorothy

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Then that accounts for it.  In the civilized countries I believe there are no witches left, nor wizards, nor sorceresses, nor magicians.  But, you see, the Land of Oz has never been civilized, for we are cut off from all the rest of the world.  Therefore we still have witches and wizards amongst us.
children.prevalue: Then that accounts for it In the civilized countries I believe there are no witches left nor wizards nor sorceresses nor magicians But you see the Land of Oz has never been civilized for we are cut off from all the rest of the world Therefore we still have witches and wizards amongst us

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Who are the wizards? asked Dorothy.
children.prevalue: Who are the wizards asked Dorothy

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Oz himself is the Great Wizard, answered the Witch, sinking her voice to a whisper.  He is more powerful than all the rest of us together. He lives in the City of Emeralds.
children.prevalue: Oz himself is the Great Wizard answered the Witch sinking her voice to a whisper He is more powerful than all the rest of us together He lives in the City of Emeralds

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Dorothy was going to ask another question, but just then the Munchkins, who had been standing silently by, gave a loud shout and pointed to the corner of the house where the Wicked Witch had been lying.
children.prevalue: Dorothy was going to ask another question but just then the Munchkins who had been standing silently by gave a loud shout and pointed to the corner of the house where the Wicked Witch had been lying

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: What is it? asked the little old woman, and looked, and began to laugh.  The feet of the dead Witch had disappeared entirely, and nothing was left but the silver shoes.
children.prevalue: What is it asked the little old woman and looked and began to laugh The feet of the dead Witch had disappeared entirely and nothing was left but the silver shoes

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: She was so old, explained the Witch of the North, that she dried up quickly in the sun.  That is the end of her.  But the silver shoes are yours, and you shall have them to wear. She reached down and picked up the shoes, and after shaking the dust out of them handed them to Dorothy.
children.prevalue: She was so old explained the Witch of the North that she dried up quickly in the sun That is the end of her But the silver shoes are yours and you shall have them to wear She reached down and picked up the shoes and after shaking the dust out of them handed them to Dorothy

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: The Witch of the East was proud of those silver shoes, said one of the Munchkins, and there is some charm connected with them; but what it is we never knew.
children.prevalue: The Witch of the East was proud of those silver shoes said one of the Munchkins and there is some charm connected with them but what it is we never knew

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Dorothy carried the shoes into the house and placed them on the table. Then she came out again to the Munchkins and said:
children.prevalue: Dorothy carried the shoes into the house and placed them on the table Then she came out again to the Munchkins and said

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: I am anxious to get back to my aunt and uncle, for I am sure they will worry about me.  Can you help me find my way?
children.prevalue: I am anxious to get back to my aunt and uncle for I am sure they will worry about me Can you help me find my way

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: The Munchkins and the Witch first looked at one another, and then at Dorothy, and then shook their heads.
children.prevalue: The Munchkins and the Witch first looked at one another and then at Dorothy and then shook their heads

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: At the East, not far from here, said one, there is a great desert, and none could live to cross it.
children.prevalue: At the East not far from here said one there is a great desert and none could live to cross it

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: It is the same at the South, said another, for I have been there and seen it.  The South is the country of the Quadlings.
children.prevalue: It is the same at the South said another for I have been there and seen it The South is the country of the Quadlings

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: I am told, said the third man, that it is the same at the West.  And that country, where the Winkies live, is ruled by the Wicked Witch of the West, who would make you her slave if you passed her way.
children.prevalue: I am told said the third man that it is the same at the West And that country where the Winkies live is ruled by the Wicked Witch of the West who would make you her slave if you passed her way

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: The North is my home, said the old lady, and at its edge is the same great desert that surrounds this Land of Oz.  I'm afraid, my dear, you will have to live with us.
children.prevalue: The North is my home said the old lady and at its edge is the same great desert that surrounds this Land of Oz I m afraid my dear you will have to live with us

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Dorothy began to sob at this, for she felt lonely among all these strange people.  Her tears seemed to grieve the kind-hearted Munchkins, for they immediately took out their handkerchiefs and began to weep also.  As for the little old woman, she took off her cap and balanced the point on the end of her nose, while she counted One, two, three in a solemn voice.  At once the cap changed to a slate, on which was written in big, white chalk marks:
children.prevalue: Dorothy began to sob at this for she felt lonely among all these strange people Her tears seemed to grieve the kind hearted Munchkins for they immediately took out their handkerchiefs and began to weep also As for the little old woman she took off her cap and balanced the point on the end of her nose while she counted One two three in a solemn voice At once the cap changed to a slate on which was written in big white chalk marks

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: LET DOROTHY GO TO THE CITY OF EMERALDS
children.prevalue: LET DOROTHY GO TO THE CITY OF EMERALDS

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: The little old woman took the slate from her nose, and having read the words on it, asked, Is your name Dorothy, my dear?
children.prevalue: The little old woman took the slate from her nose and having read the words on it asked Is your name Dorothy my dear

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Yes, answered the child, looking up and drying her tears.
children.prevalue: Yes answered the child looking up and drying her tears

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Then you must go to the City of Emeralds.  Perhaps Oz will help you.
children.prevalue: Then you must go to the City of Emeralds Perhaps Oz will help you

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: Where is this city? asked Dorothy.
children.prevalue: Where is this city asked Dorothy

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: It is exactly in the center of the country, and is ruled by Oz, the Great Wizard I told you of.
children.prevalue: It is exactly in the center of the country and is ruled by Oz the Great Wizard I told you of

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Is he a good man? inquired the girl anxiously.
children.prevalue: Is he a good man inquired the girl anxiously

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: He is a good Wizard.  Whether he is a man or not I cannot tell, for I have never seen him.
children.prevalue: He is a good Wizard Whether he is a man or not I cannot tell for I have never seen him

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: How can I get there? asked Dorothy.
children.prevalue: How can I get there asked Dorothy

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: You must walk.  It is a long journey, through a country that is sometimes pleasant and sometimes dark and terrible.  However, I will use all the magic arts I know of to keep you from harm.
children.prevalue: You must walk It is a long journey through a country that is sometimes pleasant and sometimes dark and terrible However I will use all the magic arts I know of to keep you from harm

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Won't you go with me? pleaded the girl, who had begun to look upon the little old woman as her only friend.
children.prevalue: Won t you go with me pleaded the girl who had begun to look upon the little old woman as her only friend

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: No, I cannot do that, she replied, but I will give you my kiss, and no one will dare injure a person who has been kissed by the Witch of the North.
children.prevalue: No I cannot do that she replied but I will give you my kiss and no one will dare injure a person who has been kissed by the Witch of the North

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: She came close to Dorothy and kissed her gently on the forehead.  Where her lips touched the girl they left a round, shining mark, as Dorothy found out soon after.
children.prevalue: She came close to Dorothy and kissed her gently on the forehead Where her lips touched the girl they left a round shining mark as Dorothy found out soon after

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: The road to the City of Emeralds is paved with yellow brick, said the Witch, so you cannot miss it.  When you get to Oz do not be afraid of him, but tell your story and ask him to help you.  Good-bye, my dear.
children.prevalue: The road to the City of Emeralds is paved with yellow brick said the Witch so you cannot miss it When you get to Oz do not be afraid of him but tell your story and ask him to help you Good bye my dear

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: The three Munchkins bowed low to her and wished her a pleasant journey, after which they walked away through the trees.  The Witch gave Dorothy a friendly little nod, whirled around on her left heel three times, and straightway disappeared, much to the surprise of little Toto, who barked after her loudly enough when she had gone, because he had been afraid even to growl while she stood by.
children.prevalue: The three Munchkins bowed low to her and wished her a pleasant journey after which they walked away through the trees The Witch gave Dorothy a friendly little nod whirled around on her left heel three times and straightway disappeared much to the surprise of little Toto who barked after her loudly enough when she had gone because he had been afraid even to growl while she stood by

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: But Dorothy, knowing her to be a witch, had expected her to disappear in just that way, and was not surprised in the least.
children.prevalue: But Dorothy knowing her to be a witch had expected her to disappear in just that way and was not surprised in the least

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: When Dorothy was left alone she began to feel hungry.  So she went to the cupboard and cut herself some bread, which she spread with butter. She gave some to Toto, and taking a pail from the shelf she carried it down to the little brook and filled it with clear, sparkling water. Toto ran over to the trees and began to bark at the birds sitting there.  Dorothy went to get him, and saw such delicious fruit hanging from the branches that she gathered some of it, finding it just what she wanted to help out her breakfast.
children.prevalue: When Dorothy was left alone she began to feel hungry So she went to the cupboard and cut herself some bread which she spread with butter She gave some to Toto and taking a pail from the shelf she carried it down to the little brook and filled it with clear sparkling water Toto ran over to the trees and began to bark at the birds sitting there Dorothy went to get him and saw such delicious fruit hanging from the branches that she gathered some of it finding it just what she wanted to help out her breakfast

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Then she went back to the house, and having helped herself and Toto to a good drink of the cool, clear water, she set about making ready for the journey to the City of Emeralds.
children.prevalue: Then she went back to the house and having helped herself and Toto to a good drink of the cool clear water she set about making ready for the journey to the City of Emeralds

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Dorothy had only one other dress, but that happened to be clean and was hanging on a peg beside her bed.  It was gingham, with checks of white and blue; and although the blue was somewhat faded with many washings, it was still a pretty frock.  The girl washed herself carefully, dressed herself in the clean gingham, and tied her pink sunbonnet on her head.  She took a little basket and filled it with bread from the cupboard, laying a white cloth over the top.  Then she looked down at her feet and noticed how old and worn her shoes were.
children.prevalue: Dorothy had only one other dress but that happened to be clean and was hanging on a peg beside her bed It was gingham with checks of white and blue and although the blue was somewhat faded with many washings it was still a pretty frock The girl washed herself carefully dressed herself in the clean gingham and tied her pink sunbonnet on her head She took a little basket and filled it with bread from the cupboard laying a white cloth over the top Then she looked down at her feet and noticed how old and worn her shoes were

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: They surely will never do for a long journey, Toto, she said.  And Toto looked up into her face with his little black eyes and wagged his tail to show he knew what she meant.
children.prevalue: They surely will never do for a long journey Toto she said And Toto looked up into her face with his little black eyes and wagged his tail to show he knew what she meant

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: At that moment Dorothy saw lying on the table the silver shoes that had belonged to the Witch of the East.
children.prevalue: At that moment Dorothy saw lying on the table the silver shoes that had belonged to the Witch of the East

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: I wonder if they will fit me, she said to Toto.  They would be just the thing to take a long walk in, for they could not wear out.
children.prevalue: I wonder if they will fit me she said to Toto They would be just the thing to take a long walk in for they could not wear out

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: She took off her old leather shoes and tried on the silver ones, which fitted her as well as if they had been made for her.
children.prevalue: She took off her old leather shoes and tried on the silver ones which fitted her as well as if they had been made for her

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Finally she picked up her basket.
children.prevalue: Finally she picked up her basket

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Come along, Toto, she said.  We will go to the Emerald City and ask the Great Oz how to get back to Kansas again.
children.prevalue: Come along Toto she said We will go to the Emerald City and ask the Great Oz how to get back to Kansas again

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: She closed the door, locked it, and put the key carefully in the pocket of her dress.  And so, with Toto trotting along soberly behind her, she started on her journey.
children.prevalue: She closed the door locked it and put the key carefully in the pocket of her dress And so with Toto trotting along soberly behind her she started on her journey

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: There were several roads nearby, but it did not take her long to find the one paved with yellow bricks.  Within a short time she was walking briskly toward the Emerald City, her silver shoes tinkling merrily on the hard, yellow road-bed.  The sun shone bright and the birds sang sweetly, and Dorothy did not feel nearly so bad as you might think a little girl would who had been suddenly whisked away from her own country and set down in the midst of a strange land.
children.prevalue: There were several roads nearby but it did not take her long to find the one paved with yellow bricks Within a short time she was walking briskly toward the Emerald City her silver shoes tinkling merrily on the hard yellow road bed The sun shone bright and the birds sang sweetly and Dorothy did not feel nearly so bad as you might think a little girl would who had been suddenly whisked away from her own country and set down in the midst of a strange land

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: She was surprised, as she walked along, to see how pretty the country was about her.  There were neat fences at the sides of the road, painted a dainty blue color, and beyond them were fields of grain and vegetables in abundance.  Evidently the Munchkins were good farmers and able to raise large crops.  Once in a while she would pass a house, and the people came out to look at her and bow low as she went by; for everyone knew she had been the means of destroying the Wicked Witch and setting them free from bondage.  The houses of the Munchkins were odd-looking dwellings, for each was round, with a big dome for a roof. All were painted blue, for in this country of the East blue was the favorite color.
children.prevalue: She was surprised as she walked along to see how pretty the country was about her There were neat fences at the sides of the road painted a dainty blue color and beyond them were fields of grain and vegetables in abundance Evidently the Munchkins were good farmers and able to raise large crops Once in a while she would pass a house and the people came out to look at her and bow low as she went by for everyone knew she had been the means of destroying the Wicked Witch and setting them free from bondage The houses of the Munchkins were odd looking dwellings for each was round with a big dome for a roof All were painted blue for in this country of the East blue was the favorite color

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Toward evening, when Dorothy was tired with her long walk and began to wonder where she should pass the night, she came to a house rather larger than the rest.  On the green lawn before it many men and women were dancing.  Five little fiddlers played as loudly as possible, and the people were laughing and singing, while a big table near by was loaded with delicious fruits and nuts, pies and cakes, and many other good things to eat.
children.prevalue: Toward evening when Dorothy was tired with her long walk and began to wonder where she should pass the night she came to a house rather larger than the rest On the green lawn before it many men and women were dancing Five little fiddlers played as loudly as possible and the people were laughing and singing while a big table near by was loaded with delicious fruits and nuts pies and cakes and many other good things to eat

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: The people greeted Dorothy kindly, and invited her to supper and to pass the night with them; for this was the home of one of the richest Munchkins in the land, and his friends were gathered with him to celebrate their freedom from the bondage of the Wicked Witch.
children.prevalue: The people greeted Dorothy kindly and invited her to supper and to pass the night with them for this was the home of one of the richest Munchkins in the land and his friends were gathered with him to celebrate their freedom from the bondage of the Wicked Witch

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Dorothy ate a hearty supper and was waited upon by the rich Munchkin himself, whose name was Boq.  Then she sat upon a settee and watched the people dance.
children.prevalue: Dorothy ate a hearty supper and was waited upon by the rich Munchkin himself whose name was Boq Then she sat upon a settee and watched the people dance

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: When Boq saw her silver shoes he said, You must be a great sorceress.
children.prevalue: When Boq saw her silver shoes he said You must be a great sorceress

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Why? asked the girl.
children.prevalue: Why asked the girl

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Because you wear silver shoes and have killed the Wicked Witch. Besides, you have white in your frock, and only witches and sorceresses wear white.
children.prevalue: Because you wear silver shoes and have killed the Wicked Witch Besides you have white in your frock and only witches and sorceresses wear white

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: My dress is blue and white checked, said Dorothy, smoothing out the wrinkles in it.
children.prevalue: My dress is blue and white checked said Dorothy smoothing out the wrinkles in it

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: It is kind of you to wear that, said Boq.  Blue is the color of the Munchkins, and white is the witch color.  So we know you are a friendly witch.
children.prevalue: It is kind of you to wear that said Boq Blue is the color of the Munchkins and white is the witch color So we know you are a friendly witch

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Dorothy did not know what to say to this, for all the people seemed to think her a witch, and she knew very well she was only an ordinary little girl who had come by the chance of a cyclone into a strange land.
children.prevalue: Dorothy did not know what to say to this for all the people seemed to think her a witch and she knew very well she was only an ordinary little girl who had come by the chance of a cyclone into a strange land

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: When she had tired watching the dancing, Boq led her into the house, where he gave her a room with a pretty bed in it.  The sheets were made of blue cloth, and Dorothy slept soundly in them till morning, with Toto curled up on the blue rug beside her.
children.prevalue: When she had tired watching the dancing Boq led her into the house where he gave her a room with a pretty bed in it The sheets were made of blue cloth and Dorothy slept soundly in them till morning with Toto curled up on the blue rug beside her

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: She ate a hearty breakfast, and watched a wee Munchkin baby, who played with Toto and pulled his tail and crowed and laughed in a way that greatly amused Dorothy.  Toto was a fine curiosity to all the people, for they had never seen a dog before.
children.prevalue: She ate a hearty breakfast and watched a wee Munchkin baby who played with Toto and pulled his tail and crowed and laughed in a way that greatly amused Dorothy Toto was a fine curiosity to all the people for they had never seen a dog before

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: How far is it to the Emerald City? the girl asked.
children.prevalue: How far is it to the Emerald City the girl asked

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: I do not know, answered Boq gravely, for I have never been there. It is better for people to keep away from Oz, unless they have business with him.  But it is a long way to the Emerald City, and it will take you many days.  The country here is rich and pleasant, but you must pass through rough and dangerous places before you reach the end of your journey.
children.prevalue: I do not know answered Boq gravely for I have never been there It is better for people to keep away from Oz unless they have business with him But it is a long way to the Emerald City and it will take you many days The country here is rich and pleasant but you must pass through rough and dangerous places before you reach the end of your journey

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: This worried Dorothy a little, but she knew that only the Great Oz could help her get to Kansas again, so she bravely resolved not to turn back.
children.prevalue: This worried Dorothy a little but she knew that only the Great Oz could help her get to Kansas again so she bravely resolved not to turn back

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: She bade her friends good-bye, and again started along the road of yellow brick.  When she had gone several miles she thought she would stop to rest, and so climbed to the top of the fence beside the road and sat down.  There was a great cornfield beyond the fence, and not far away she saw a Scarecrow, placed high on a pole to keep the birds from the ripe corn.
children.prevalue: She bade her friends good bye and again started along the road of yellow brick When she had gone several miles she thought she would stop to rest and so climbed to the top of the fence beside the road and sat down There was a great cornfield beyond the fence and not far away she saw a Scarecrow placed high on a pole to keep the birds from the ripe corn

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Dorothy leaned her chin upon her hand and gazed thoughtfully at the Scarecrow.  Its head was a small sack stuffed with straw, with eyes, nose, and mouth painted on it to represent a face.  An old, pointed blue hat, that had belonged to some Munchkin, was perched on his head, and the rest of the figure was a blue suit of clothes, worn and faded, which had also been stuffed with straw.  On the feet were some old boots with blue tops, such as every man wore in this country, and the figure was raised above the stalks of corn by means of the pole stuck up its back.
children.prevalue: Dorothy leaned her chin upon her hand and gazed thoughtfully at the Scarecrow Its head was a small sack stuffed with straw with eyes nose and mouth painted on it to represent a face An old pointed blue hat that had belonged to some Munchkin was perched on his head and the rest of the figure was a blue suit of clothes worn and faded which had also been stuffed with straw On the feet were some old boots with blue tops such as every man wore in this country and the figure was raised above the stalks of corn by means of the pole stuck up its back

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: While Dorothy was looking earnestly into the queer, painted face of the Scarecrow, she was surprised to see one of the eyes slowly wink at her. She thought she must have been mistaken at first, for none of the scarecrows in Kansas ever wink; but presently the figure nodded its head to her in a friendly way.  Then she climbed down from the fence and walked up to it, while Toto ran around the pole and barked.
children.prevalue: While Dorothy was looking earnestly into the queer painted face of the Scarecrow she was surprised to see one of the eyes slowly wink at her She thought she must have been mistaken at first for none of the scarecrows in Kansas ever wink but presently the figure nodded its head to her in a friendly way Then she climbed down from the fence and walked up to it while Toto ran around the pole and barked

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Good day, said the Scarecrow, in a rather husky voice.
children.prevalue: Good day said the Scarecrow in a rather husky voice

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Did you speak? asked the girl, in wonder.
children.prevalue: Did you speak asked the girl in wonder

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Certainly, answered the Scarecrow.  How do you do?
children.prevalue: Certainly answered the Scarecrow How do you do

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: I'm pretty well, thank you, replied Dorothy politely.  How do you do?
children.prevalue: I m pretty well thank you replied Dorothy politely How do you do

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: I'm not feeling well, said the Scarecrow, with a smile, for it is very tedious being perched up here night and day to scare away crows.
children.prevalue: I m not feeling well said the Scarecrow with a smile for it is very tedious being perched up here night and day to scare away crows

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Can't you get down? asked Dorothy.
children.prevalue: Can t you get down asked Dorothy

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: No, for this pole is stuck up my back.  If you will please take away the pole I shall be greatly obliged to you.
children.prevalue: No for this pole is stuck up my back If you will please take away the pole I shall be greatly obliged to you

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Dorothy reached up both arms and lifted the figure off the pole, for, being stuffed with straw, it was quite light.
children.prevalue: Dorothy reached up both arms and lifted the figure off the pole for being stuffed with straw it was quite light

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Thank you very much, said the Scarecrow, when he had been set down on the ground.  I feel like a new man.
children.prevalue: Thank you very much said the Scarecrow when he had been set down on the ground I feel like a new man

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Dorothy was puzzled at this, for it sounded queer to hear a stuffed man speak, and to see him bow and walk along beside her.
children.prevalue: Dorothy was puzzled at this for it sounded queer to hear a stuffed man speak and to see him bow and walk along beside her

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Who are you? asked the Scarecrow when he had stretched himself and yawned.  And where are you going?
children.prevalue: Who are you asked the Scarecrow when he had stretched himself and yawned And where are you going

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: My name is Dorothy, said the girl, and I am going to the Emerald City, to ask the Great Oz to send me back to Kansas.
children.prevalue: My name is Dorothy said the girl and I am going to the Emerald City to ask the Great Oz to send me back to Kansas

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Where is the Emerald City? he inquired.  And who is Oz?
children.prevalue: Where is the Emerald City he inquired And who is Oz

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Why, don't you know? she returned, in surprise.
children.prevalue: Why don t you know she returned in surprise

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: No, indeed.  I don't know anything.  You see, I am stuffed, so I have no brains at all, he answered sadly.
children.prevalue: No indeed I don t know anything You see I am stuffed so I have no brains at all he answered sadly

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Oh, said Dorothy, I'm awfully sorry for you.
children.prevalue: Oh said Dorothy I m awfully sorry for you

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Do you think, he asked, if I go to the Emerald City with you, that Oz would give me some brains?
children.prevalue: Do you think he asked if I go to the Emerald City with you that Oz would give me some brains

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: I cannot tell, she returned, but you may come with me, if you like. If Oz will not give you any brains you will be no worse off than you are now.
children.prevalue: I cannot tell she returned but you may come with me if you like If Oz will not give you any brains you will be no worse off than you are now

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: That is true, said the Scarecrow.  You see, he continued confidentially, I don't mind my legs and arms and body being stuffed, because I cannot get hurt.  If anyone treads on my toes or sticks a pin into me, it doesn't matter, for I can't feel it.  But I do not want people to call me a fool, and if my head stays stuffed with straw instead of with brains, as yours is, how am I ever to know anything?
children.prevalue: That is true said the Scarecrow You see he continued confidentially I don t mind my legs and arms and body being stuffed because I cannot get hurt If anyone treads on my toes or sticks a pin into me it doesn t matter for I can t feel it But I do not want people to call me a fool and if my head stays stuffed with straw instead of with brains as yours is how am I ever to know anything

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: I understand how you feel, said the little girl, who was truly sorry for him.  If you will come with me I'll ask Oz to do all he can for you.
children.prevalue: I understand how you feel said the little girl who was truly sorry for him If you will come with me I ll ask Oz to do all he can for you

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Thank you, he answered gratefully.
children.prevalue: Thank you he answered gratefully

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: They walked back to the road.  Dorothy helped him over the fence, and they started along the path of yellow brick for the Emerald City.
children.prevalue: They walked back to the road Dorothy helped him over the fence and they started along the path of yellow brick for the Emerald City

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Toto did not like this addition to the party at first.  He smelled around the stuffed man as if he suspected there might be a nest of rats in the straw, and he often growled in an unfriendly way at the Scarecrow.
children.prevalue: Toto did not like this addition to the party at first He smelled around the stuffed man as if he suspected there might be a nest of rats in the straw and he often growled in an unfriendly way at the Scarecrow

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Don't mind Toto, said Dorothy to her new friend.  He never bites.
children.prevalue: Don t mind Toto said Dorothy to her new friend He never bites

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Oh, I'm not afraid, replied the Scarecrow.  He can't hurt the straw. Do let me carry that basket for you.  I shall not mind it, for I can't get tired.  I'll tell you a secret, he continued, as he walked along. There is only one thing in the world I am afraid of.
children.prevalue: Oh I m not afraid replied the Scarecrow He can t hurt the straw Do let me carry that basket for you I shall not mind it for I can t get tired I ll tell you a secret he continued as he walked along There is only one thing in the world I am afraid of

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: What is that? asked Dorothy; the Munchkin farmer who made you?
children.prevalue: What is that asked Dorothy the Munchkin farmer who made you

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: No, answered the Scarecrow; it's a lighted match.
children.prevalue: No answered the Scarecrow it s a lighted match

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: After a few hours the road began to be rough, and the walking grew so difficult that the Scarecrow often stumbled over the yellow bricks, which were here very uneven.  Sometimes, indeed, they were broken or missing altogether, leaving holes that Toto jumped across and Dorothy walked around.  As for the Scarecrow, having no brains, he walked straight ahead, and so stepped into the holes and fell at full length on the hard bricks.  It never hurt him, however, and Dorothy would pick him up and set him upon his feet again, while he joined her in laughing merrily at his own mishap.
children.prevalue: After a few hours the road began to be rough and the walking grew so difficult that the Scarecrow often stumbled over the yellow bricks which were here very uneven Sometimes indeed they were broken or missing altogether leaving holes that Toto jumped across and Dorothy walked around As for the Scarecrow having no brains he walked straight ahead and so stepped into the holes and fell at full length on the hard bricks It never hurt him however and Dorothy would pick him up and set him upon his feet again while he joined her in laughing merrily at his own mishap

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The farms were not nearly so well cared for here as they were farther back.  There were fewer houses and fewer fruit trees, and the farther they went the more dismal and lonesome the country became.
children.prevalue: The farms were not nearly so well cared for here as they were farther back There were fewer houses and fewer fruit trees and the farther they went the more dismal and lonesome the country became

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: At noon they sat down by the roadside, near a little brook, and Dorothy opened her basket and got out some bread.  She offered a piece to the Scarecrow, but he refused.
children.prevalue: At noon they sat down by the roadside near a little brook and Dorothy opened her basket and got out some bread She offered a piece to the Scarecrow but he refused

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: I am never hungry, he said, and it is a lucky thing I am not, for my mouth is only painted, and if I should cut a hole in it so I could eat, the straw I am stuffed with would come out, and that would spoil the shape of my head.
children.prevalue: I am never hungry he said and it is a lucky thing I am not for my mouth is only painted and if I should cut a hole in it so I could eat the straw I am stuffed with would come out and that would spoil the shape of my head

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Dorothy saw at once that this was true, so she only nodded and went on eating her bread.
children.prevalue: Dorothy saw at once that this was true so she only nodded and went on eating her bread

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Tell me something about yourself and the country you came from, said the Scarecrow, when she had finished her dinner.  So she told him all about Kansas, and how gray everything was there, and how the cyclone had carried her to this queer Land of Oz.
children.prevalue: Tell me something about yourself and the country you came from said the Scarecrow when she had finished her dinner So she told him all about Kansas and how gray everything was there and how the cyclone had carried her to this queer Land of Oz

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: The Scarecrow listened carefully, and said, I cannot understand why you should wish to leave this beautiful country and go back to the dry, gray place you call Kansas.
children.prevalue: The Scarecrow listened carefully and said I cannot understand why you should wish to leave this beautiful country and go back to the dry gray place you call Kansas

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: That is because you have no brains answered the girl.  No matter how dreary and gray our homes are, we people of flesh and blood would rather live there than in any other country, be it ever so beautiful. There is no place like home.
children.prevalue: That is because you have no brains answered the girl No matter how dreary and gray our homes are we people of flesh and blood would rather live there than in any other country be it ever so beautiful There is no place like home

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: The Scarecrow sighed.
children.prevalue: The Scarecrow sighed

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Of course I cannot understand it, he said.  If your heads were stuffed with straw, like mine, you would probably all live in the beautiful places, and then Kansas would have no people at all.  It is fortunate for Kansas that you have brains.
children.prevalue: Of course I cannot understand it he said If your heads were stuffed with straw like mine you would probably all live in the beautiful places and then Kansas would have no people at all It is fortunate for Kansas that you have brains

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Won't you tell me a story, while we are resting? asked the child.
children.prevalue: Won t you tell me a story while we are resting asked the child

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: The Scarecrow looked at her reproachfully, and answered:
children.prevalue: The Scarecrow looked at her reproachfully and answered

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: My life has been so short that I really know nothing whatever.  I was only made day before yesterday.  What happened in the world before that time is all unknown to me.  Luckily, when the farmer made my head, one of the first things he did was to paint my ears, so that I heard what was going on.  There was another Munchkin with him, and the first thing I heard was the farmer saying, 'How do you like those ears?'
children.prevalue: My life has been so short that I really know nothing whatever I was only made day before yesterday What happened in the world before that time is all unknown to me Luckily when the farmer made my head one of the first things he did was to paint my ears so that I heard what was going on There was another Munchkin with him and the first thing I heard was the farmer saying How do you like those ears

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: 'They aren't straight,' answered the other.
children.prevalue: They aren t straight answered the other

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: 'Never mind,' said the farmer.  'They are ears just the same,' which was true enough.
children.prevalue: Never mind said the farmer They are ears just the same which was true enough

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: 'Now I'll make the eyes,' said the farmer.  So he painted my right eye, and as soon as it was finished I found myself looking at him and at everything around me with a great deal of curiosity, for this was my first glimpse of the world.
children.prevalue: Now I ll make the eyes said the farmer So he painted my right eye and as soon as it was finished I found myself looking at him and at everything around me with a great deal of curiosity for this was my first glimpse of the world

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: 'That's a rather pretty eye,' remarked the Munchkin who was watching the farmer.  'Blue paint is just the color for eyes.'
children.prevalue: That s a rather pretty eye remarked the Munchkin who was watching the farmer Blue paint is just the color for eyes

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: 'I think I'll make the other a little bigger,' said the farmer.  And when the second eye was done I could see much better than before.  Then he made my nose and my mouth.  But I did not speak, because at that time I didn't know what a mouth was for.  I had the fun of watching them make my body and my arms and legs; and when they fastened on my head, at last, I felt very proud, for I thought I was just as good a man as anyone.
children.prevalue: I think I ll make the other a little bigger said the farmer And when the second eye was done I could see much better than before Then he made my nose and my mouth But I did not speak because at that time I didn t know what a mouth was for I had the fun of watching them make my body and my arms and legs and when they fastened on my head at last I felt very proud for I thought I was just as good a man as anyone

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: 'This fellow will scare the crows fast enough,' said the farmer.  'He looks just like a man.'
children.prevalue: This fellow will scare the crows fast enough said the farmer He looks just like a man

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: 'Why, he is a man,' said the other, and I quite agreed with him.  The farmer carried me under his arm to the cornfield, and set me up on a tall stick, where you found me.  He and his friend soon after walked away and left me alone.
children.prevalue: Why he is a man said the other and I quite agreed with him The farmer carried me under his arm to the cornfield and set me up on a tall stick where you found me He and his friend soon after walked away and left me alone

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: I did not like to be deserted this way.  So I tried to walk after them.  But my feet would not touch the ground, and I was forced to stay on that pole.  It was a lonely life to lead, for I had nothing to think of, having been made such a little while before.  Many crows and other birds flew into the cornfield, but as soon as they saw me they flew away again, thinking I was a Munchkin; and this pleased me and made me feel that I was quite an important person.  By and by an old crow flew near me, and after looking at me carefully he perched upon my shoulder and said:
children.prevalue: I did not like to be deserted this way So I tried to walk after them But my feet would not touch the ground and I was forced to stay on that pole It was a lonely life to lead for I had nothing to think of having been made such a little while before Many crows and other birds flew into the cornfield but as soon as they saw me they flew away again thinking I was a Munchkin and this pleased me and made me feel that I was quite an important person By and by an old crow flew near me and after looking at me carefully he perched upon my shoulder and said

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: 'I wonder if that farmer thought to fool me in this clumsy manner. Any crow of sense could see that you are only stuffed with straw.' Then he hopped down at my feet and ate all the corn he wanted.  The other birds, seeing he was not harmed by me, came to eat the corn too, so in a short time there was a great flock of them about me.
children.prevalue: I wonder if that farmer thought to fool me in this clumsy manner Any crow of sense could see that you are only stuffed with straw Then he hopped down at my feet and ate all the corn he wanted The other birds seeing he was not harmed by me came to eat the corn too so in a short time there was a great flock of them about me

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: I felt sad at this, for it showed I was not such a good Scarecrow after all; but the old crow comforted me, saying, 'If you only had brains in your head you would be as good a man as any of them, and a better man than some of them.  Brains are the only things worth having in this world, no matter whether one is a crow or a man.'
children.prevalue: I felt sad at this for it showed I was not such a good Scarecrow after all but the old crow comforted me saying If you only had brains in your head you would be as good a man as any of them and a better man than some of them Brains are the only things worth having in this world no matter whether one is a crow or a man

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: After the crows had gone I thought this over, and decided I would try hard to get some brains.  By good luck you came along and pulled me off the stake, and from what you say I am sure the Great Oz will give me brains as soon as we get to the Emerald City.
children.prevalue: After the crows had gone I thought this over and decided I would try hard to get some brains By good luck you came along and pulled me off the stake and from what you say I am sure the Great Oz will give me brains as soon as we get to the Emerald City

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: I hope so, said Dorothy earnestly, since you seem anxious to have them.
children.prevalue: I hope so said Dorothy earnestly since you seem anxious to have them

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Oh, yes; I am anxious, returned the Scarecrow.  It is such an uncomfortable feeling to know one is a fool.
children.prevalue: Oh yes I am anxious returned the Scarecrow It is such an uncomfortable feeling to know one is a fool

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Well, said the girl, let us go.  And she handed the basket to the Scarecrow.
children.prevalue: Well said the girl let us go And she handed the basket to the Scarecrow

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: There were no fences at all by the roadside now, and the land was rough and untilled.  Toward evening they came to a great forest, where the trees grew so big and close together that their branches met over the road of yellow brick.  It was almost dark under the trees, for the branches shut out the daylight; but the travelers did not stop, and went on into the forest.
children.prevalue: There were no fences at all by the roadside now and the land was rough and untilled Toward evening they came to a great forest where the trees grew so big and close together that their branches met over the road of yellow brick It was almost dark under the trees for the branches shut out the daylight but the travelers did not stop and went on into the forest

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: If this road goes in, it must come out, said the Scarecrow, and as the Emerald City is at the other end of the road, we must go wherever it leads us.
children.prevalue: If this road goes in it must come out said the Scarecrow and as the Emerald City is at the other end of the road we must go wherever it leads us

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Anyone would know that, said Dorothy.
children.prevalue: Anyone would know that said Dorothy

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Certainly; that is why I know it, returned the Scarecrow.  If it required brains to figure it out, I never should have said it.
children.prevalue: Certainly that is why I know it returned the Scarecrow If it required brains to figure it out I never should have said it

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: After an hour or so the light faded away, and they found themselves stumbling along in the darkness.  Dorothy could not see at all, but Toto could, for some dogs see very well in the dark; and the Scarecrow declared he could see as well as by day.  So she took hold of his arm and managed to get along fairly well.
children.prevalue: After an hour or so the light faded away and they found themselves stumbling along in the darkness Dorothy could not see at all but Toto could for some dogs see very well in the dark and the Scarecrow declared he could see as well as by day So she took hold of his arm and managed to get along fairly well

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: If you see any house, or any place where we can pass the night, she said, you must tell me; for it is very uncomfortable walking in the dark.
children.prevalue: If you see any house or any place where we can pass the night she said you must tell me for it is very uncomfortable walking in the dark

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Soon after the Scarecrow stopped.
children.prevalue: Soon after the Scarecrow stopped

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: I see a little cottage at the right of us, he said, built of logs and branches.  Shall we go there?
children.prevalue: I see a little cottage at the right of us he said built of logs and branches Shall we go there

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Yes, indeed, answered the child.  I am all tired out.
children.prevalue: Yes indeed answered the child I am all tired out

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: So the Scarecrow led her through the trees until they reached the cottage, and Dorothy entered and found a bed of dried leaves in one corner.  She lay down at once, and with Toto beside her soon fell into a sound sleep.  The Scarecrow, who was never tired, stood up in another corner and waited patiently until morning came.
children.prevalue: So the Scarecrow led her through the trees until they reached the cottage and Dorothy entered and found a bed of dried leaves in one corner She lay down at once and with Toto beside her soon fell into a sound sleep The Scarecrow who was never tired stood up in another corner and waited patiently until morning came

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: When Dorothy awoke the sun was shining through the trees and Toto had long been out chasing birds around him and squirrels.  She sat up and looked around her. There was the Scarecrow, still standing patiently in his corner, waiting for her.
children.prevalue: When Dorothy awoke the sun was shining through the trees and Toto had long been out chasing birds around him and squirrels She sat up and looked around her There was the Scarecrow still standing patiently in his corner waiting for her

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: We must go and search for water, she said to him.
children.prevalue: We must go and search for water she said to him

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Why do you want water? he asked.
children.prevalue: Why do you want water he asked

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: To wash my face clean after the dust of the road, and to drink, so the dry bread will not stick in my throat.
children.prevalue: To wash my face clean after the dust of the road and to drink so the dry bread will not stick in my throat

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: It must be inconvenient to be made of flesh, said the Scarecrow thoughtfully, for you must sleep, and eat and drink.  However, you have brains, and it is worth a lot of bother to be able to think properly.
children.prevalue: It must be inconvenient to be made of flesh said the Scarecrow thoughtfully for you must sleep and eat and drink However you have brains and it is worth a lot of bother to be able to think properly

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: They left the cottage and walked through the trees until they found a little spring of clear water, where Dorothy drank and bathed and ate her breakfast.  She saw there was not much bread left in the basket, and the girl was thankful the Scarecrow did not have to eat anything, for there was scarcely enough for herself and Toto for the day.
children.prevalue: They left the cottage and walked through the trees until they found a little spring of clear water where Dorothy drank and bathed and ate her breakfast She saw there was not much bread left in the basket and the girl was thankful the Scarecrow did not have to eat anything for there was scarcely enough for herself and Toto for the day
