children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: When she had finished her meal, and was about to go back to the road of yellow brick, she was startled to hear a deep groan near by.
children.prevalue: When she had finished her meal and was about to go back to the road of yellow brick she was startled to hear a deep groan near by

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: What was that? she asked timidly.
children.prevalue: What was that she asked timidly

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: I cannot imagine, replied the Scarecrow; but we can go and see.
children.prevalue: I cannot imagine replied the Scarecrow but we can go and see

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Just then another groan reached their ears, and the sound seemed to come from behind them.  They turned and walked through the forest a few steps, when Dorothy discovered something shining in a ray of sunshine that fell between the trees.  She ran to the place and then stopped short, with a little cry of surprise.
children.prevalue: Just then another groan reached their ears and the sound seemed to come from behind them They turned and walked through the forest a few steps when Dorothy discovered something shining in a ray of sunshine that fell between the trees She ran to the place and then stopped short with a little cry of surprise

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: One of the big trees had been partly chopped through, and standing beside it, with an uplifted axe in his hands, was a man made entirely of tin.  His head and arms and legs were jointed upon his body, but he stood perfectly motionless, as if he could not stir at all.
children.prevalue: One of the big trees had been partly chopped through and standing beside it with an uplifted axe in his hands was a man made entirely of tin His head and arms and legs were jointed upon his body but he stood perfectly motionless as if he could not stir at all

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Dorothy looked at him in amazement, and so did the Scarecrow, while Toto barked sharply and made a snap at the tin legs, which hurt his teeth.
children.prevalue: Dorothy looked at him in amazement and so did the Scarecrow while Toto barked sharply and made a snap at the tin legs which hurt his teeth

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Did you groan? asked Dorothy.
children.prevalue: Did you groan asked Dorothy

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Yes, answered the tin man, I did.  I've been groaning for more than a year, and no one has ever heard me before or come to help me.
children.prevalue: Yes answered the tin man I did I ve been groaning for more than a year and no one has ever heard me before or come to help me

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: What can I do for you? she inquired softly, for she was moved by the sad voice in which the man spoke.
children.prevalue: What can I do for you she inquired softly for she was moved by the sad voice in which the man spoke

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Get an oil-can and oil my joints, he answered.  They are rusted so badly that I cannot move them at all; if I am well oiled I shall soon be all right again.  You will find an oil-can on a shelf in my cottage.
children.prevalue: Get an oil can and oil my joints he answered They are rusted so badly that I cannot move them at all if I am well oiled I shall soon be all right again You will find an oil can on a shelf in my cottage

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Dorothy at once ran back to the cottage and found the oil-can, and then she returned and asked anxiously, Where are your joints?
children.prevalue: Dorothy at once ran back to the cottage and found the oil can and then she returned and asked anxiously Where are your joints

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Oil my neck, first, replied the Tin Woodman.  So she oiled it, and as it was quite badly rusted the Scarecrow took hold of the tin head and moved it gently from side to side until it worked freely, and then the man could turn it himself.
children.prevalue: Oil my neck first replied the Tin Woodman So she oiled it and as it was quite badly rusted the Scarecrow took hold of the tin head and moved it gently from side to side until it worked freely and then the man could turn it himself

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Now oil the joints in my arms, he said.  And Dorothy oiled them and the Scarecrow bent them carefully until they were quite free from rust and as good as new.
children.prevalue: Now oil the joints in my arms he said And Dorothy oiled them and the Scarecrow bent them carefully until they were quite free from rust and as good as new

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: The Tin Woodman gave a sigh of satisfaction and lowered his axe, which he leaned against the tree.
children.prevalue: The Tin Woodman gave a sigh of satisfaction and lowered his axe which he leaned against the tree

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: This is a great comfort, he said.  I have been holding that axe in the air ever since I rusted, and I'm glad to be able to put it down at last.  Now, if you will oil the joints of my legs, I shall be all right once more.
children.prevalue: This is a great comfort he said I have been holding that axe in the air ever since I rusted and I m glad to be able to put it down at last Now if you will oil the joints of my legs I shall be all right once more

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: So they oiled his legs until he could move them freely; and he thanked them again and again for his release, for he seemed a very polite creature, and very grateful.
children.prevalue: So they oiled his legs until he could move them freely and he thanked them again and again for his release for he seemed a very polite creature and very grateful

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: I might have stood there always if you had not come along, he said; so you have certainly saved my life.  How did you happen to be here?
children.prevalue: I might have stood there always if you had not come along he said so you have certainly saved my life How did you happen to be here

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: We are on our way to the Emerald City to see the Great Oz, she answered, and we stopped at your cottage to pass the night.
children.prevalue: We are on our way to the Emerald City to see the Great Oz she answered and we stopped at your cottage to pass the night

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Why do you wish to see Oz? he asked.
children.prevalue: Why do you wish to see Oz he asked

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: I want him to send me back to Kansas, and the Scarecrow wants him to put a few brains into his head, she replied.
children.prevalue: I want him to send me back to Kansas and the Scarecrow wants him to put a few brains into his head she replied

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: The Tin Woodman appeared to think deeply for a moment.  Then he said:
children.prevalue: The Tin Woodman appeared to think deeply for a moment Then he said

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Do you suppose Oz could give me a heart?
children.prevalue: Do you suppose Oz could give me a heart

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Why, I guess so, Dorothy answered.  It would be as easy as to give the Scarecrow brains.
children.prevalue: Why I guess so Dorothy answered It would be as easy as to give the Scarecrow brains

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: True, the Tin Woodman returned.  So, if you will allow me to join your party, I will also go to the Emerald City and ask Oz to help me.
children.prevalue: True the Tin Woodman returned So if you will allow me to join your party I will also go to the Emerald City and ask Oz to help me

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Come along, said the Scarecrow heartily, and Dorothy added that she would be pleased to have his company.  So the Tin Woodman shouldered his axe and they all passed through the forest until they came to the road that was paved with yellow brick.
children.prevalue: Come along said the Scarecrow heartily and Dorothy added that she would be pleased to have his company So the Tin Woodman shouldered his axe and they all passed through the forest until they came to the road that was paved with yellow brick

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: The Tin Woodman had asked Dorothy to put the oil-can in her basket. For, he said, if I should get caught in the rain, and rust again, I would need the oil-can badly.
children.prevalue: The Tin Woodman had asked Dorothy to put the oil can in her basket For he said if I should get caught in the rain and rust again I would need the oil can badly

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: It was a bit of good luck to have their new comrade join the party, for soon after they had begun their journey again they came to a place where the trees and branches grew so thick over the road that the travelers could not pass.  But the Tin Woodman set to work with his axe and chopped so well that soon he cleared a passage for the entire party.
children.prevalue: It was a bit of good luck to have their new comrade join the party for soon after they had begun their journey again they came to a place where the trees and branches grew so thick over the road that the travelers could not pass But the Tin Woodman set to work with his axe and chopped so well that soon he cleared a passage for the entire party

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Dorothy was thinking so earnestly as they walked along that she did not notice when the Scarecrow stumbled into a hole and rolled over to the side of the road.  Indeed he was obliged to call to her to help him up again.
children.prevalue: Dorothy was thinking so earnestly as they walked along that she did not notice when the Scarecrow stumbled into a hole and rolled over to the side of the road Indeed he was obliged to call to her to help him up again

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Why didn't you walk around the hole? asked the Tin Woodman.
children.prevalue: Why didn t you walk around the hole asked the Tin Woodman

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: I don't know enough, replied the Scarecrow cheerfully.  My head is stuffed with straw, you know, and that is why I am going to Oz to ask him for some brains.
children.prevalue: I don t know enough replied the Scarecrow cheerfully My head is stuffed with straw you know and that is why I am going to Oz to ask him for some brains

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Oh, I see, said the Tin Woodman.  But, after all, brains are not the best things in the world.
children.prevalue: Oh I see said the Tin Woodman But after all brains are not the best things in the world

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Have you any? inquired the Scarecrow.
children.prevalue: Have you any inquired the Scarecrow

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: No, my head is quite empty, answered the Woodman.  But once I had brains, and a heart also; so, having tried them both, I should much rather have a heart.
children.prevalue: No my head is quite empty answered the Woodman But once I had brains and a heart also so having tried them both I should much rather have a heart

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: And why is that? asked the Scarecrow.
children.prevalue: And why is that asked the Scarecrow

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: I will tell you my story, and then you will know.
children.prevalue: I will tell you my story and then you will know

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: So, while they were walking through the forest, the Tin Woodman told the following story:
children.prevalue: So while they were walking through the forest the Tin Woodman told the following story

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: I was born the son of a woodman who chopped down trees in the forest and sold the wood for a living.  When I grew up, I too became a woodchopper, and after my father died I took care of my old mother as long as she lived.  Then I made up my mind that instead of living alone I would marry, so that I might not become lonely.
children.prevalue: I was born the son of a woodman who chopped down trees in the forest and sold the wood for a living When I grew up I too became a woodchopper and after my father died I took care of my old mother as long as she lived Then I made up my mind that instead of living alone I would marry so that I might not become lonely

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: There was one of the Munchkin girls who was so beautiful that I soon grew to love her with all my heart.  She, on her part, promised to marry me as soon as I could earn enough money to build a better house for her; so I set to work harder than ever.  But the girl lived with an old woman who did not want her to marry anyone, for she was so lazy she wished the girl to remain with her and do the cooking and the housework.  So the old woman went to the Wicked Witch of the East, and promised her two sheep and a cow if she would prevent the marriage. Thereupon the Wicked Witch enchanted my axe, and when I was chopping away at my best one day, for I was anxious to get the new house and my wife as soon as possible, the axe slipped all at once and cut off my left leg.
children.prevalue: There was one of the Munchkin girls who was so beautiful that I soon grew to love her with all my heart She on her part promised to marry me as soon as I could earn enough money to build a better house for her so I set to work harder than ever But the girl lived with an old woman who did not want her to marry anyone for she was so lazy she wished the girl to remain with her and do the cooking and the housework So the old woman went to the Wicked Witch of the East and promised her two sheep and a cow if she would prevent the marriage Thereupon the Wicked Witch enchanted my axe and when I was chopping away at my best one day for I was anxious to get the new house and my wife as soon as possible the axe slipped all at once and cut off my left leg

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: This at first seemed a great misfortune, for I knew a one-legged man could not do very well as a wood-chopper.  So I went to a tinsmith and had him make me a new leg out of tin.  The leg worked very well, once I was used to it.  But my action angered the Wicked Witch of the East, for she had promised the old woman I should not marry the pretty Munchkin girl.  When I began chopping again, my axe slipped and cut off my right leg.  Again I went to the tinsmith, and again he made me a leg out of tin.  After this the enchanted axe cut off my arms, one after the other; but, nothing daunted, I had them replaced with tin ones. The Wicked Witch then made the axe slip and cut off my head, and at first I thought that was the end of me.  But the tinsmith happened to come along, and he made me a new head out of tin.
children.prevalue: This at first seemed a great misfortune for I knew a one legged man could not do very well as a wood chopper So I went to a tinsmith and had him make me a new leg out of tin The leg worked very well once I was used to it But my action angered the Wicked Witch of the East for she had promised the old woman I should not marry the pretty Munchkin girl When I began chopping again my axe slipped and cut off my right leg Again I went to the tinsmith and again he made me a leg out of tin After this the enchanted axe cut off my arms one after the other but nothing daunted I had them replaced with tin ones The Wicked Witch then made the axe slip and cut off my head and at first I thought that was the end of me But the tinsmith happened to come along and he made me a new head out of tin

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: I thought I had beaten the Wicked Witch then, and I worked harder than ever; but I little knew how cruel my enemy could be.  She thought of a new way to kill my love for the beautiful Munchkin maiden, and made my axe slip again, so that it cut right through my body, splitting me into two halves.  Once more the tinsmith came to my help and made me a body of tin, fastening my tin arms and legs and head to it, by means of joints, so that I could move around as well as ever.  But, alas!  I had now no heart, so that I lost all my love for the Munchkin girl, and did not care whether I married her or not.  I suppose she is still living with the old woman, waiting for me to come after her.
children.prevalue: I thought I had beaten the Wicked Witch then and I worked harder than ever but I little knew how cruel my enemy could be She thought of a new way to kill my love for the beautiful Munchkin maiden and made my axe slip again so that it cut right through my body splitting me into two halves Once more the tinsmith came to my help and made me a body of tin fastening my tin arms and legs and head to it by means of joints so that I could move around as well as ever But alas I had now no heart so that I lost all my love for the Munchkin girl and did not care whether I married her or not I suppose she is still living with the old woman waiting for me to come after her

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: My body shone so brightly in the sun that I felt very proud of it and it did not matter now if my axe slipped, for it could not cut me. There was only one danger--that my joints would rust; but I kept an oil-can in my cottage and took care to oil myself whenever I needed it. However, there came a day when I forgot to do this, and, being caught in a rainstorm, before I thought of the danger my joints had rusted, and I was left to stand in the woods until you came to help me.  It was a terrible thing to undergo, but during the year I stood there I had time to think that the greatest loss I had known was the loss of my heart.  While I was in love I was the happiest man on earth; but no one can love who has not a heart, and so I am resolved to ask Oz to give me one.  If he does, I will go back to the Munchkin maiden and marry her.
children.prevalue: My body shone so brightly in the sun that I felt very proud of it and it did not matter now if my axe slipped for it could not cut me There was only one danger that my joints would rust but I kept an oil can in my cottage and took care to oil myself whenever I needed it However there came a day when I forgot to do this and being caught in a rainstorm before I thought of the danger my joints had rusted and I was left to stand in the woods until you came to help me It was a terrible thing to undergo but during the year I stood there I had time to think that the greatest loss I had known was the loss of my heart While I was in love I was the happiest man on earth but no one can love who has not a heart and so I am resolved to ask Oz to give me one If he does I will go back to the Munchkin maiden and marry her

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Both Dorothy and the Scarecrow had been greatly interested in the story of the Tin Woodman, and now they knew why he was so anxious to get a new heart.
children.prevalue: Both Dorothy and the Scarecrow had been greatly interested in the story of the Tin Woodman and now they knew why he was so anxious to get a new heart

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: All the same, said the Scarecrow, I shall ask for brains instead of a heart; for a fool would not know what to do with a heart if he had one.
children.prevalue: All the same said the Scarecrow I shall ask for brains instead of a heart for a fool would not know what to do with a heart if he had one

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: I shall take the heart, returned the Tin Woodman; for brains do not make one happy, and happiness is the best thing in the world.
children.prevalue: I shall take the heart returned the Tin Woodman for brains do not make one happy and happiness is the best thing in the world

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Dorothy did not say anything, for she was puzzled to know which of her two friends was right, and she decided if she could only get back to Kansas and Aunt Em, it did not matter so much whether the Woodman had no brains and the Scarecrow no heart, or each got what he wanted.
children.prevalue: Dorothy did not say anything for she was puzzled to know which of her two friends was right and she decided if she could only get back to Kansas and Aunt Em it did not matter so much whether the Woodman had no brains and the Scarecrow no heart or each got what he wanted

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: What worried her most was that the bread was nearly gone, and another meal for herself and Toto would empty the basket.  To be sure, neither the Woodman nor the Scarecrow ever ate anything, but she was not made of tin nor straw, and could not live unless she was fed.
children.prevalue: What worried her most was that the bread was nearly gone and another meal for herself and Toto would empty the basket To be sure neither the Woodman nor the Scarecrow ever ate anything but she was not made of tin nor straw and could not live unless she was fed

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: All this time Dorothy and her companions had been walking through the thick woods.  The road was still paved with yellow brick, but these were much covered by dried branches and dead leaves from the trees, and the walking was not at all good.
children.prevalue: All this time Dorothy and her companions had been walking through the thick woods The road was still paved with yellow brick but these were much covered by dried branches and dead leaves from the trees and the walking was not at all good

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: There were few birds in this part of the forest, for birds love the open country where there is plenty of sunshine.  But now and then there came a deep growl from some wild animal hidden among the trees.  These sounds made the little girl's heart beat fast, for she did not know what made them; but Toto knew, and he walked close to Dorothy's side, and did not even bark in return.
children.prevalue: There were few birds in this part of the forest for birds love the open country where there is plenty of sunshine But now and then there came a deep growl from some wild animal hidden among the trees These sounds made the little girl s heart beat fast for she did not know what made them but Toto knew and he walked close to Dorothy s side and did not even bark in return

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: How long will it be, the child asked of the Tin Woodman, before we are out of the forest?
children.prevalue: How long will it be the child asked of the Tin Woodman before we are out of the forest

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: I cannot tell, was the answer, for I have never been to the Emerald City.  But my father went there once, when I was a boy, and he said it was a long journey through a dangerous country, although nearer to the city where Oz dwells the country is beautiful.  But I am not afraid so long as I have my oil-can, and nothing can hurt the Scarecrow, while you bear upon your forehead the mark of the Good Witch's kiss, and that will protect you from harm.
children.prevalue: I cannot tell was the answer for I have never been to the Emerald City But my father went there once when I was a boy and he said it was a long journey through a dangerous country although nearer to the city where Oz dwells the country is beautiful But I am not afraid so long as I have my oil can and nothing can hurt the Scarecrow while you bear upon your forehead the mark of the Good Witch s kiss and that will protect you from harm

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: But Toto! said the girl anxiously.  What will protect him?
children.prevalue: But Toto said the girl anxiously What will protect him

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: We must protect him ourselves if he is in danger, replied the Tin Woodman.
children.prevalue: We must protect him ourselves if he is in danger replied the Tin Woodman

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Just as he spoke there came from the forest a terrible roar, and the next moment a great Lion bounded into the road.  With one blow of his paw he sent the Scarecrow spinning over and over to the edge of the road, and then he struck at the Tin Woodman with his sharp claws.  But, to the Lion's surprise, he could make no impression on the tin, although the Woodman fell over in the road and lay still.
children.prevalue: Just as he spoke there came from the forest a terrible roar and the next moment a great Lion bounded into the road With one blow of his paw he sent the Scarecrow spinning over and over to the edge of the road and then he struck at the Tin Woodman with his sharp claws But to the Lion s surprise he could make no impression on the tin although the Woodman fell over in the road and lay still

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Little Toto, now that he had an enemy to face, ran barking toward the Lion, and the great beast had opened his mouth to bite the dog, when Dorothy, fearing Toto would be killed, and heedless of danger, rushed forward and slapped the Lion upon his nose as hard as she could, while she cried out:
children.prevalue: Little Toto now that he had an enemy to face ran barking toward the Lion and the great beast had opened his mouth to bite the dog when Dorothy fearing Toto would be killed and heedless of danger rushed forward and slapped the Lion upon his nose as hard as she could while she cried out

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Don't you dare to bite Toto!  You ought to be ashamed of yourself, a big beast like you, to bite a poor little dog!
children.prevalue: Don t you dare to bite Toto You ought to be ashamed of yourself a big beast like you to bite a poor little dog

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: I didn't bite him, said the Lion, as he rubbed his nose with his paw where Dorothy had hit it.
children.prevalue: I didn t bite him said the Lion as he rubbed his nose with his paw where Dorothy had hit it

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: No, but you tried to, she retorted.  You are nothing but a big coward.
children.prevalue: No but you tried to she retorted You are nothing but a big coward

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: I know it, said the Lion, hanging his head in shame.  I've always known it.  But how can I help it?
children.prevalue: I know it said the Lion hanging his head in shame I ve always known it But how can I help it

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: I don't know, I'm sure.  To think of your striking a stuffed man, like the poor Scarecrow!
children.prevalue: I don t know I m sure To think of your striking a stuffed man like the poor Scarecrow

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Is he stuffed? asked the Lion in surprise, as he watched her pick up the Scarecrow and set him upon his feet, while she patted him into shape again.
children.prevalue: Is he stuffed asked the Lion in surprise as he watched her pick up the Scarecrow and set him upon his feet while she patted him into shape again

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Of course he's stuffed, replied Dorothy, who was still angry.
children.prevalue: Of course he s stuffed replied Dorothy who was still angry

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: That's why he went over so easily, remarked the Lion.  It astonished me to see him whirl around so.  Is the other one stuffed also?
children.prevalue: That s why he went over so easily remarked the Lion It astonished me to see him whirl around so Is the other one stuffed also

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: No, said Dorothy, he's made of tin.  And she helped the Woodman up again.
children.prevalue: No said Dorothy he s made of tin And she helped the Woodman up again

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: That's why he nearly blunted my claws, said the Lion.  When they scratched against the tin it made a cold shiver run down my back.  What is that little animal you are so tender of?
children.prevalue: That s why he nearly blunted my claws said the Lion When they scratched against the tin it made a cold shiver run down my back What is that little animal you are so tender of

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: He is my dog, Toto, answered Dorothy.
children.prevalue: He is my dog Toto answered Dorothy

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Is he made of tin, or stuffed? asked the Lion.
children.prevalue: Is he made of tin or stuffed asked the Lion

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Neither.  He's a--a--a meat dog, said the girl.
children.prevalue: Neither He s a a a meat dog said the girl

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Oh!  He's a curious animal and seems remarkably small, now that I look at him.  No one would think of biting such a little thing, except a coward like me, continued the Lion sadly.
children.prevalue: Oh He s a curious animal and seems remarkably small now that I look at him No one would think of biting such a little thing except a coward like me continued the Lion sadly

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: What makes you a coward? asked Dorothy, looking at the great beast in wonder, for he was as big as a small horse.
children.prevalue: What makes you a coward asked Dorothy looking at the great beast in wonder for he was as big as a small horse

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: It's a mystery, replied the Lion.  I suppose I was born that way. All the other animals in the forest naturally expect me to be brave, for the Lion is everywhere thought to be the King of Beasts.  I learned that if I roared very loudly every living thing was frightened and got out of my way.  Whenever I've met a man I've been awfully scared; but I just roared at him, and he has always run away as fast as he could go. If the elephants and the tigers and the bears had ever tried to fight me, I should have run myself--I'm such a coward; but just as soon as they hear me roar they all try to get away from me, and of course I let them go.
children.prevalue: It s a mystery replied the Lion I suppose I was born that way All the other animals in the forest naturally expect me to be brave for the Lion is everywhere thought to be the King of Beasts I learned that if I roared very loudly every living thing was frightened and got out of my way Whenever I ve met a man I ve been awfully scared but I just roared at him and he has always run away as fast as he could go If the elephants and the tigers and the bears had ever tried to fight me I should have run myself I m such a coward but just as soon as they hear me roar they all try to get away from me and of course I let them go

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: But that isn't right.  The King of Beasts shouldn't be a coward, said the Scarecrow.
children.prevalue: But that isn t right The King of Beasts shouldn t be a coward said the Scarecrow

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: I know it, returned the Lion, wiping a tear from his eye with the tip of his tail.  It is my great sorrow, and makes my life very unhappy. But whenever there is danger, my heart begins to beat fast.
children.prevalue: I know it returned the Lion wiping a tear from his eye with the tip of his tail It is my great sorrow and makes my life very unhappy But whenever there is danger my heart begins to beat fast

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Perhaps you have heart disease, said the Tin Woodman.
children.prevalue: Perhaps you have heart disease said the Tin Woodman

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: It may be, said the Lion.
children.prevalue: It may be said the Lion

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: If you have, continued the Tin Woodman, you ought to be glad, for it proves you have a heart.  For my part, I have no heart; so I cannot have heart disease.
children.prevalue: If you have continued the Tin Woodman you ought to be glad for it proves you have a heart For my part I have no heart so I cannot have heart disease

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Perhaps, said the Lion thoughtfully, if I had no heart I should not be a coward.
children.prevalue: Perhaps said the Lion thoughtfully if I had no heart I should not be a coward

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Have you brains? asked the Scarecrow.
children.prevalue: Have you brains asked the Scarecrow

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: I suppose so.  I've never looked to see, replied the Lion.
children.prevalue: I suppose so I ve never looked to see replied the Lion

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: I am going to the Great Oz to ask him to give me some, remarked the Scarecrow, for my head is stuffed with straw.
children.prevalue: I am going to the Great Oz to ask him to give me some remarked the Scarecrow for my head is stuffed with straw

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: And I am going to ask him to give me a heart, said the Woodman.
children.prevalue: And I am going to ask him to give me a heart said the Woodman

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: And I am going to ask him to send Toto and me back to Kansas, added Dorothy.
children.prevalue: And I am going to ask him to send Toto and me back to Kansas added Dorothy

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Do you think Oz could give me courage? asked the Cowardly Lion.
children.prevalue: Do you think Oz could give me courage asked the Cowardly Lion

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Just as easily as he could give me brains, said the Scarecrow.
children.prevalue: Just as easily as he could give me brains said the Scarecrow

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Or give me a heart, said the Tin Woodman.
children.prevalue: Or give me a heart said the Tin Woodman

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Or send me back to Kansas, said Dorothy.
children.prevalue: Or send me back to Kansas said Dorothy

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Then, if you don't mind, I'll go with you, said the Lion, for my life is simply unbearable without a bit of courage.
children.prevalue: Then if you don t mind I ll go with you said the Lion for my life is simply unbearable without a bit of courage

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: You will be very welcome, answered Dorothy, for you will help to keep away the other wild beasts.  It seems to me they must be more cowardly than you are if they allow you to scare them so easily.
children.prevalue: You will be very welcome answered Dorothy for you will help to keep away the other wild beasts It seems to me they must be more cowardly than you are if they allow you to scare them so easily

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: They really are, said the Lion, but that doesn't make me any braver, and as long as I know myself to be a coward I shall be unhappy.
children.prevalue: They really are said the Lion but that doesn t make me any braver and as long as I know myself to be a coward I shall be unhappy

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: So once more the little company set off upon the journey, the Lion walking with stately strides at Dorothy's side.  Toto did not approve of this new comrade at first, for he could not forget how nearly he had been crushed between the Lion's great jaws.  But after a time he became more at ease, and presently Toto and the Cowardly Lion had grown to be good friends.
children.prevalue: So once more the little company set off upon the journey the Lion walking with stately strides at Dorothy s side Toto did not approve of this new comrade at first for he could not forget how nearly he had been crushed between the Lion s great jaws But after a time he became more at ease and presently Toto and the Cowardly Lion had grown to be good friends

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: During the rest of that day there was no other adventure to mar the peace of their journey.  Once, indeed, the Tin Woodman stepped upon a beetle that was crawling along the road, and killed the poor little thing.  This made the Tin Woodman very unhappy, for he was always careful not to hurt any living creature; and as he walked along he wept several tears of sorrow and regret.  These tears ran slowly down his face and over the hinges of his jaw, and there they rusted.  When Dorothy presently asked him a question the Tin Woodman could not open his mouth, for his jaws were tightly rusted together.  He became greatly frightened at this and made many motions to Dorothy to relieve him, but she could not understand.  The Lion was also puzzled to know what was wrong.  But the Scarecrow seized the oil-can from Dorothy's basket and oiled the Woodman's jaws, so that after a few moments he could talk as well as before.
children.prevalue: During the rest of that day there was no other adventure to mar the peace of their journey Once indeed the Tin Woodman stepped upon a beetle that was crawling along the road and killed the poor little thing This made the Tin Woodman very unhappy for he was always careful not to hurt any living creature and as he walked along he wept several tears of sorrow and regret These tears ran slowly down his face and over the hinges of his jaw and there they rusted When Dorothy presently asked him a question the Tin Woodman could not open his mouth for his jaws were tightly rusted together He became greatly frightened at this and made many motions to Dorothy to relieve him but she could not understand The Lion was also puzzled to know what was wrong But the Scarecrow seized the oil can from Dorothy s basket and oiled the Woodman s jaws so that after a few moments he could talk as well as before

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: This will serve me a lesson, said he, to look where I step.  For if I should kill another bug or beetle I should surely cry again, and crying rusts my jaws so that I cannot speak.
children.prevalue: This will serve me a lesson said he to look where I step For if I should kill another bug or beetle I should surely cry again and crying rusts my jaws so that I cannot speak

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Thereafter he walked very carefully, with his eyes on the road, and when he saw a tiny ant toiling by he would step over it, so as not to harm it.  The Tin Woodman knew very well he had no heart, and therefore he took great care never to be cruel or unkind to anything.
children.prevalue: Thereafter he walked very carefully with his eyes on the road and when he saw a tiny ant toiling by he would step over it so as not to harm it The Tin Woodman knew very well he had no heart and therefore he took great care never to be cruel or unkind to anything

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: You people with hearts, he said, have something to guide you, and need never do wrong; but I have no heart, and so I must be very careful.  When Oz gives me a heart of course I needn't mind so much.
children.prevalue: You people with hearts he said have something to guide you and need never do wrong but I have no heart and so I must be very careful When Oz gives me a heart of course I needn t mind so much

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: They were obliged to camp out that night under a large tree in the forest, for there were no houses near.  The tree made a good, thick covering to protect them from the dew, and the Tin Woodman chopped a great pile of wood with his axe and Dorothy built a splendid fire that warmed her and made her feel less lonely.  She and Toto ate the last of their bread, and now she did not know what they would do for breakfast.
children.prevalue: They were obliged to camp out that night under a large tree in the forest for there were no houses near The tree made a good thick covering to protect them from the dew and the Tin Woodman chopped a great pile of wood with his axe and Dorothy built a splendid fire that warmed her and made her feel less lonely She and Toto ate the last of their bread and now she did not know what they would do for breakfast

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: If you wish, said the Lion, I will go into the forest and kill a deer for you.  You can roast it by the fire, since your tastes are so peculiar that you prefer cooked food, and then you will have a very good breakfast.
children.prevalue: If you wish said the Lion I will go into the forest and kill a deer for you You can roast it by the fire since your tastes are so peculiar that you prefer cooked food and then you will have a very good breakfast

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Don't!  Please don't, begged the Tin Woodman.  I should certainly weep if you killed a poor deer, and then my jaws would rust again.
children.prevalue: Don t Please don t begged the Tin Woodman I should certainly weep if you killed a poor deer and then my jaws would rust again

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: But the Lion went away into the forest and found his own supper, and no one ever knew what it was, for he didn't mention it.  And the Scarecrow found a tree full of nuts and filled Dorothy's basket with them, so that she would not be hungry for a long time.  She thought this was very kind and thoughtful of the Scarecrow, but she laughed heartily at the awkward way in which the poor creature picked up the nuts.  His padded hands were so clumsy and the nuts were so small that he dropped almost as many as he put in the basket.  But the Scarecrow did not mind how long it took him to fill the basket, for it enabled him to keep away from the fire, as he feared a spark might get into his straw and burn him up.  So he kept a good distance away from the flames, and only came near to cover Dorothy with dry leaves when she lay down to sleep. These kept her very snug and warm, and she slept soundly until morning.
children.prevalue: But the Lion went away into the forest and found his own supper and no one ever knew what it was for he didn t mention it And the Scarecrow found a tree full of nuts and filled Dorothy s basket with them so that she would not be hungry for a long time She thought this was very kind and thoughtful of the Scarecrow but she laughed heartily at the awkward way in which the poor creature picked up the nuts His padded hands were so clumsy and the nuts were so small that he dropped almost as many as he put in the basket But the Scarecrow did not mind how long it took him to fill the basket for it enabled him to keep away from the fire as he feared a spark might get into his straw and burn him up So he kept a good distance away from the flames and only came near to cover Dorothy with dry leaves when she lay down to sleep These kept her very snug and warm and she slept soundly until morning

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: When it was daylight, the girl bathed her face in a little rippling brook, and soon after they all started toward the Emerald City.
children.prevalue: When it was daylight the girl bathed her face in a little rippling brook and soon after they all started toward the Emerald City

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: This was to be an eventful day for the travelers.  They had hardly been walking an hour when they saw before them a great ditch that crossed the road and divided the forest as far as they could see on either side.  It was a very wide ditch, and when they crept up to the edge and looked into it they could see it was also very deep, and there were many big, jagged rocks at the bottom.  The sides were so steep that none of them could climb down, and for a moment it seemed that their journey must end.
children.prevalue: This was to be an eventful day for the travelers They had hardly been walking an hour when they saw before them a great ditch that crossed the road and divided the forest as far as they could see on either side It was a very wide ditch and when they crept up to the edge and looked into it they could see it was also very deep and there were many big jagged rocks at the bottom The sides were so steep that none of them could climb down and for a moment it seemed that their journey must end

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: What shall we do? asked Dorothy despairingly.
children.prevalue: What shall we do asked Dorothy despairingly

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: I haven't the faintest idea, said the Tin Woodman, and the Lion shook his shaggy mane and looked thoughtful.
children.prevalue: I haven t the faintest idea said the Tin Woodman and the Lion shook his shaggy mane and looked thoughtful

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: But the Scarecrow said, We cannot fly, that is certain.  Neither can we climb down into this great ditch.  Therefore, if we cannot jump over it, we must stop where we are.
children.prevalue: But the Scarecrow said We cannot fly that is certain Neither can we climb down into this great ditch Therefore if we cannot jump over it we must stop where we are

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: I think I could jump over it, said the Cowardly Lion, after measuring the distance carefully in his mind.
children.prevalue: I think I could jump over it said the Cowardly Lion after measuring the distance carefully in his mind

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Then we are all right, answered the Scarecrow, for you can carry us all over on your back, one at a time.
children.prevalue: Then we are all right answered the Scarecrow for you can carry us all over on your back one at a time

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Well, I'll try it, said the Lion.  Who will go first?
children.prevalue: Well I ll try it said the Lion Who will go first

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: I will, declared the Scarecrow, for, if you found that you could not jump over the gulf, Dorothy would be killed, or the Tin Woodman badly dented on the rocks below.  But if I am on your back it will not matter so much, for the fall would not hurt me at all.
children.prevalue: I will declared the Scarecrow for if you found that you could not jump over the gulf Dorothy would be killed or the Tin Woodman badly dented on the rocks below But if I am on your back it will not matter so much for the fall would not hurt me at all

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: I am terribly afraid of falling, myself, said the Cowardly Lion, but I suppose there is nothing to do but try it.  So get on my back and we will make the attempt.
children.prevalue: I am terribly afraid of falling myself said the Cowardly Lion but I suppose there is nothing to do but try it So get on my back and we will make the attempt

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: The Scarecrow sat upon the Lion's back, and the big beast walked to the edge of the gulf and crouched down.
children.prevalue: The Scarecrow sat upon the Lion s back and the big beast walked to the edge of the gulf and crouched down

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Why don't you run and jump? asked the Scarecrow.
children.prevalue: Why don t you run and jump asked the Scarecrow

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Because that isn't the way we Lions do these things, he replied. Then giving a great spring, he shot through the air and landed safely on the other side.  They were all greatly pleased to see how easily he did it, and after the Scarecrow had got down from his back the Lion sprang across the ditch again.
children.prevalue: Because that isn t the way we Lions do these things he replied Then giving a great spring he shot through the air and landed safely on the other side They were all greatly pleased to see how easily he did it and after the Scarecrow had got down from his back the Lion sprang across the ditch again

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Dorothy thought she would go next; so she took Toto in her arms and climbed on the Lion's back, holding tightly to his mane with one hand. The next moment it seemed as if she were flying through the air; and then, before she had time to think about it, she was safe on the other side.  The Lion went back a third time and got the Tin Woodman, and then they all sat down for a few moments to give the beast a chance to rest, for his great leaps had made his breath short, and he panted like a big dog that has been running too long.
children.prevalue: Dorothy thought she would go next so she took Toto in her arms and climbed on the Lion s back holding tightly to his mane with one hand The next moment it seemed as if she were flying through the air and then before she had time to think about it she was safe on the other side The Lion went back a third time and got the Tin Woodman and then they all sat down for a few moments to give the beast a chance to rest for his great leaps had made his breath short and he panted like a big dog that has been running too long

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: They found the forest very thick on this side, and it looked dark and gloomy.  After the Lion had rested they started along the road of yellow brick, silently wondering, each in his own mind, if ever they would come to the end of the woods and reach the bright sunshine again. To add to their discomfort, they soon heard strange noises in the depths of the forest, and the Lion whispered to them that it was in this part of the country that the Kalidahs lived.
children.prevalue: They found the forest very thick on this side and it looked dark and gloomy After the Lion had rested they started along the road of yellow brick silently wondering each in his own mind if ever they would come to the end of the woods and reach the bright sunshine again To add to their discomfort they soon heard strange noises in the depths of the forest and the Lion whispered to them that it was in this part of the country that the Kalidahs lived

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: What are the Kalidahs? asked the girl.
children.prevalue: What are the Kalidahs asked the girl

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: They are monstrous beasts with bodies like bears and heads like tigers, replied the Lion, and with claws so long and sharp that they could tear me in two as easily as I could kill Toto.  I'm terribly afraid of the Kalidahs.
children.prevalue: They are monstrous beasts with bodies like bears and heads like tigers replied the Lion and with claws so long and sharp that they could tear me in two as easily as I could kill Toto I m terribly afraid of the Kalidahs

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: I'm not surprised that you are, returned Dorothy.  They must be dreadful beasts.
children.prevalue: I m not surprised that you are returned Dorothy They must be dreadful beasts

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: The Lion was about to reply when suddenly they came to another gulf across the road.  But this one was so broad and deep that the Lion knew at once he could not leap across it.
children.prevalue: The Lion was about to reply when suddenly they came to another gulf across the road But this one was so broad and deep that the Lion knew at once he could not leap across it

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: So they sat down to consider what they should do, and after serious thought the Scarecrow said:
children.prevalue: So they sat down to consider what they should do and after serious thought the Scarecrow said

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Here is a great tree, standing close to the ditch.  If the Tin Woodman can chop it down, so that it will fall to the other side, we can walk across it easily.
children.prevalue: Here is a great tree standing close to the ditch If the Tin Woodman can chop it down so that it will fall to the other side we can walk across it easily

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: That is a first-rate idea, said the Lion.  One would almost suspect you had brains in your head, instead of straw.
children.prevalue: That is a first rate idea said the Lion One would almost suspect you had brains in your head instead of straw

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: The Woodman set to work at once, and so sharp was his axe that the tree was soon chopped nearly through.  Then the Lion put his strong front legs against the tree and pushed with all his might, and slowly the big tree tipped and fell with a crash across the ditch, with its top branches on the other side.
children.prevalue: The Woodman set to work at once and so sharp was his axe that the tree was soon chopped nearly through Then the Lion put his strong front legs against the tree and pushed with all his might and slowly the big tree tipped and fell with a crash across the ditch with its top branches on the other side

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: They had just started to cross this queer bridge when a sharp growl made them all look up, and to their horror they saw running toward them two great beasts with bodies like bears and heads like tigers.
children.prevalue: They had just started to cross this queer bridge when a sharp growl made them all look up and to their horror they saw running toward them two great beasts with bodies like bears and heads like tigers

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: They are the Kalidahs! said the Cowardly Lion, beginning to tremble.
children.prevalue: They are the Kalidahs said the Cowardly Lion beginning to tremble

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Quick! cried the Scarecrow.  Let us cross over.
children.prevalue: Quick cried the Scarecrow Let us cross over

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: So Dorothy went first, holding Toto in her arms, the Tin Woodman followed, and the Scarecrow came next.  The Lion, although he was certainly afraid, turned to face the Kalidahs, and then he gave so loud and terrible a roar that Dorothy screamed and the Scarecrow fell over backward, while even the fierce beasts stopped short and looked at him in surprise.
children.prevalue: So Dorothy went first holding Toto in her arms the Tin Woodman followed and the Scarecrow came next The Lion although he was certainly afraid turned to face the Kalidahs and then he gave so loud and terrible a roar that Dorothy screamed and the Scarecrow fell over backward while even the fierce beasts stopped short and looked at him in surprise

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: But, seeing they were bigger than the Lion, and remembering that there were two of them and only one of him, the Kalidahs again rushed forward, and the Lion crossed over the tree and turned to see what they would do next.  Without stopping an instant the fierce beasts also began to cross the tree.  And the Lion said to Dorothy:
children.prevalue: But seeing they were bigger than the Lion and remembering that there were two of them and only one of him the Kalidahs again rushed forward and the Lion crossed over the tree and turned to see what they would do next Without stopping an instant the fierce beasts also began to cross the tree And the Lion said to Dorothy

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: We are lost, for they will surely tear us to pieces with their sharp claws.  But stand close behind me, and I will fight them as long as I am alive.
children.prevalue: We are lost for they will surely tear us to pieces with their sharp claws But stand close behind me and I will fight them as long as I am alive

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Wait a minute! called the Scarecrow.  He had been thinking what was best to be done, and now he asked the Woodman to chop away the end of the tree that rested on their side of the ditch.  The Tin Woodman began to use his axe at once, and, just as the two Kalidahs were nearly across, the tree fell with a crash into the gulf, carrying the ugly, snarling brutes with it, and both were dashed to pieces on the sharp rocks at the bottom.
children.prevalue: Wait a minute called the Scarecrow He had been thinking what was best to be done and now he asked the Woodman to chop away the end of the tree that rested on their side of the ditch The Tin Woodman began to use his axe at once and just as the two Kalidahs were nearly across the tree fell with a crash into the gulf carrying the ugly snarling brutes with it and both were dashed to pieces on the sharp rocks at the bottom

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Well, said the Cowardly Lion, drawing a long breath of relief, I see we are going to live a little while longer, and I am glad of it, for it must be a very uncomfortable thing not to be alive.  Those creatures frightened me so badly that my heart is beating yet.
children.prevalue: Well said the Cowardly Lion drawing a long breath of relief I see we are going to live a little while longer and I am glad of it for it must be a very uncomfortable thing not to be alive Those creatures frightened me so badly that my heart is beating yet

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Ah, said the Tin Woodman sadly, I wish I had a heart to beat.
children.prevalue: Ah said the Tin Woodman sadly I wish I had a heart to beat

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: This adventure made the travelers more anxious than ever to get out of the forest, and they walked so fast that Dorothy became tired, and had to ride on the Lion's back.  To their great joy the trees became thinner the farther they advanced, and in the afternoon they suddenly came upon a broad river, flowing swiftly just before them.  On the other side of the water they could see the road of yellow brick running through a beautiful country, with green meadows dotted with bright flowers and all the road bordered with trees hanging full of delicious fruits.  They were greatly pleased to see this delightful country before them.
children.prevalue: This adventure made the travelers more anxious than ever to get out of the forest and they walked so fast that Dorothy became tired and had to ride on the Lion s back To their great joy the trees became thinner the farther they advanced and in the afternoon they suddenly came upon a broad river flowing swiftly just before them On the other side of the water they could see the road of yellow brick running through a beautiful country with green meadows dotted with bright flowers and all the road bordered with trees hanging full of delicious fruits They were greatly pleased to see this delightful country before them

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: How shall we cross the river? asked Dorothy.
children.prevalue: How shall we cross the river asked Dorothy

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: That is easily done, replied the Scarecrow.  The Tin Woodman must build us a raft, so we can float to the other side.
children.prevalue: That is easily done replied the Scarecrow The Tin Woodman must build us a raft so we can float to the other side

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: So the Woodman took his axe and began to chop down small trees to make a raft, and while he was busy at this the Scarecrow found on the riverbank a tree full of fine fruit.  This pleased Dorothy, who had eaten nothing but nuts all day, and she made a hearty meal of the ripe fruit.
children.prevalue: So the Woodman took his axe and began to chop down small trees to make a raft and while he was busy at this the Scarecrow found on the riverbank a tree full of fine fruit This pleased Dorothy who had eaten nothing but nuts all day and she made a hearty meal of the ripe fruit

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: But it takes time to make a raft, even when one is as industrious and untiring as the Tin Woodman, and when night came the work was not done. So they found a cozy place under the trees where they slept well until the morning; and Dorothy dreamed of the Emerald City, and of the good Wizard Oz, who would soon send her back to her own home again.
children.prevalue: But it takes time to make a raft even when one is as industrious and untiring as the Tin Woodman and when night came the work was not done So they found a cozy place under the trees where they slept well until the morning and Dorothy dreamed of the Emerald City and of the good Wizard Oz who would soon send her back to her own home again

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Our little party of travelers awakened the next morning refreshed and full of hope, and Dorothy breakfasted like a princess off peaches and plums from the trees beside the river.  Behind them was the dark forest they had passed safely through, although they had suffered many discouragements; but before them was a lovely, sunny country that seemed to beckon them on to the Emerald City.
children.prevalue: Our little party of travelers awakened the next morning refreshed and full of hope and Dorothy breakfasted like a princess off peaches and plums from the trees beside the river Behind them was the dark forest they had passed safely through although they had suffered many discouragements but before them was a lovely sunny country that seemed to beckon them on to the Emerald City

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: To be sure, the broad river now cut them off from this beautiful land. But the raft was nearly done, and after the Tin Woodman had cut a few more logs and fastened them together with wooden pins, they were ready to start.  Dorothy sat down in the middle of the raft and held Toto in her arms.  When the Cowardly Lion stepped upon the raft it tipped badly, for he was big and heavy; but the Scarecrow and the Tin Woodman stood upon the other end to steady it, and they had long poles in their hands to push the raft through the water.
children.prevalue: To be sure the broad river now cut them off from this beautiful land But the raft was nearly done and after the Tin Woodman had cut a few more logs and fastened them together with wooden pins they were ready to start Dorothy sat down in the middle of the raft and held Toto in her arms When the Cowardly Lion stepped upon the raft it tipped badly for he was big and heavy but the Scarecrow and the Tin Woodman stood upon the other end to steady it and they had long poles in their hands to push the raft through the water

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: They got along quite well at first, but when they reached the middle of the river the swift current swept the raft downstream, farther and farther away from the road of yellow brick.  And the water grew so deep that the long poles would not touch the bottom.
children.prevalue: They got along quite well at first but when they reached the middle of the river the swift current swept the raft downstream farther and farther away from the road of yellow brick And the water grew so deep that the long poles would not touch the bottom

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: This is bad, said the Tin Woodman, for if we cannot get to the land we shall be carried into the country of the Wicked Witch of the West, and she will enchant us and make us her slaves.
children.prevalue: This is bad said the Tin Woodman for if we cannot get to the land we shall be carried into the country of the Wicked Witch of the West and she will enchant us and make us her slaves

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: And then I should get no brains, said the Scarecrow.
children.prevalue: And then I should get no brains said the Scarecrow

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: And I should get no courage, said the Cowardly Lion.
children.prevalue: And I should get no courage said the Cowardly Lion

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: And I should get no heart, said the Tin Woodman.
children.prevalue: And I should get no heart said the Tin Woodman

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: And I should never get back to Kansas, said Dorothy.
children.prevalue: And I should never get back to Kansas said Dorothy

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: We must certainly get to the Emerald City if we can, the Scarecrow continued, and he pushed so hard on his long pole that it stuck fast in the mud at the bottom of the river.  Then, before he could pull it out again--or let go--the raft was swept away, and the poor Scarecrow was left clinging to the pole in the middle of the river.
children.prevalue: We must certainly get to the Emerald City if we can the Scarecrow continued and he pushed so hard on his long pole that it stuck fast in the mud at the bottom of the river Then before he could pull it out again or let go the raft was swept away and the poor Scarecrow was left clinging to the pole in the middle of the river

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Good-bye! he called after them, and they were very sorry to leave him.  Indeed, the Tin Woodman began to cry, but fortunately remembered that he might rust, and so dried his tears on Dorothy's apron.
children.prevalue: Good bye he called after them and they were very sorry to leave him Indeed the Tin Woodman began to cry but fortunately remembered that he might rust and so dried his tears on Dorothy s apron

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Of course this was a bad thing for the Scarecrow.
children.prevalue: Of course this was a bad thing for the Scarecrow

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: I am now worse off than when I first met Dorothy, he thought.  Then, I was stuck on a pole in a cornfield, where I could make-believe scare the crows, at any rate.  But surely there is no use for a Scarecrow stuck on a pole in the middle of a river.  I am afraid I shall never have any brains, after all!
children.prevalue: I am now worse off than when I first met Dorothy he thought Then I was stuck on a pole in a cornfield where I could make believe scare the crows at any rate But surely there is no use for a Scarecrow stuck on a pole in the middle of a river I am afraid I shall never have any brains after all

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Down the stream the raft floated, and the poor Scarecrow was left far behind.  Then the Lion said:
children.prevalue: Down the stream the raft floated and the poor Scarecrow was left far behind Then the Lion said

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Something must be done to save us.  I think I can swim to the shore and pull the raft after me, if you will only hold fast to the tip of my tail.
children.prevalue: Something must be done to save us I think I can swim to the shore and pull the raft after me if you will only hold fast to the tip of my tail

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: So he sprang into the water, and the Tin Woodman caught fast hold of his tail.  Then the Lion began to swim with all his might toward the shore.  It was hard work, although he was so big; but by and by they were drawn out of the current, and then Dorothy took the Tin Woodman's long pole and helped push the raft to the land.
children.prevalue: So he sprang into the water and the Tin Woodman caught fast hold of his tail Then the Lion began to swim with all his might toward the shore It was hard work although he was so big but by and by they were drawn out of the current and then Dorothy took the Tin Woodman s long pole and helped push the raft to the land

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: They were all tired out when they reached the shore at last and stepped off upon the pretty green grass, and they also knew that the stream had carried them a long way past the road of yellow brick that led to the Emerald City.
children.prevalue: They were all tired out when they reached the shore at last and stepped off upon the pretty green grass and they also knew that the stream had carried them a long way past the road of yellow brick that led to the Emerald City

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: What shall we do now? asked the Tin Woodman, as the Lion lay down on the grass to let the sun dry him.
children.prevalue: What shall we do now asked the Tin Woodman as the Lion lay down on the grass to let the sun dry him

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: We must get back to the road, in some way, said Dorothy.
children.prevalue: We must get back to the road in some way said Dorothy

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: The best plan will be to walk along the riverbank until we come to the road again, remarked the Lion.
children.prevalue: The best plan will be to walk along the riverbank until we come to the road again remarked the Lion

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: So, when they were rested, Dorothy picked up her basket and they started along the grassy bank, to the road from which the river had carried them.  It was a lovely country, with plenty of flowers and fruit trees and sunshine to cheer them, and had they not felt so sorry for the poor Scarecrow, they could have been very happy.
children.prevalue: So when they were rested Dorothy picked up her basket and they started along the grassy bank to the road from which the river had carried them It was a lovely country with plenty of flowers and fruit trees and sunshine to cheer them and had they not felt so sorry for the poor Scarecrow they could have been very happy

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: They walked along as fast as they could, Dorothy only stopping once to pick a beautiful flower; and after a time the Tin Woodman cried out: Look!
children.prevalue: They walked along as fast as they could Dorothy only stopping once to pick a beautiful flower and after a time the Tin Woodman cried out Look

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Then they all looked at the river and saw the Scarecrow perched upon his pole in the middle of the water, looking very lonely and sad.
children.prevalue: Then they all looked at the river and saw the Scarecrow perched upon his pole in the middle of the water looking very lonely and sad

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: What can we do to save him? asked Dorothy.
children.prevalue: What can we do to save him asked Dorothy

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: The Lion and the Woodman both shook their heads, for they did not know. So they sat down upon the bank and gazed wistfully at the Scarecrow until a Stork flew by, who, upon seeing them, stopped to rest at the water's edge.
children.prevalue: The Lion and the Woodman both shook their heads for they did not know So they sat down upon the bank and gazed wistfully at the Scarecrow until a Stork flew by who upon seeing them stopped to rest at the water s edge

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Who are you and where are you going? asked the Stork.
children.prevalue: Who are you and where are you going asked the Stork

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: I am Dorothy, answered the girl, and these are my friends, the Tin Woodman and the Cowardly Lion;  and we are going to the Emerald City.
children.prevalue: I am Dorothy answered the girl and these are my friends the Tin Woodman and the Cowardly Lion and we are going to the Emerald City

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: This isn't the road, said the Stork, as she twisted her long neck and looked sharply at the queer party.
children.prevalue: This isn t the road said the Stork as she twisted her long neck and looked sharply at the queer party

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: I know it, returned Dorothy, but we have lost the Scarecrow, and are wondering how we shall get him again.
children.prevalue: I know it returned Dorothy but we have lost the Scarecrow and are wondering how we shall get him again

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Where is he? asked the Stork.
children.prevalue: Where is he asked the Stork

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Over there in the river, answered the little girl.
children.prevalue: Over there in the river answered the little girl

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: If he wasn't so big and heavy I would get him for you, remarked the Stork.
children.prevalue: If he wasn t so big and heavy I would get him for you remarked the Stork

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: He isn't heavy a bit, said Dorothy eagerly, for he is stuffed with straw; and if you will bring him back to us, we shall thank you ever and ever so much.
children.prevalue: He isn t heavy a bit said Dorothy eagerly for he is stuffed with straw and if you will bring him back to us we shall thank you ever and ever so much

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Well, I'll try, said the Stork, but if I find he is too heavy to carry I shall have to drop him in the river again.
children.prevalue: Well I ll try said the Stork but if I find he is too heavy to carry I shall have to drop him in the river again

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: So the big bird flew into the air and over the water till she came to where the Scarecrow was perched upon his pole.  Then the Stork with her great claws grabbed the Scarecrow by the arm and carried him up into the air and back to the bank, where Dorothy and the Lion and the Tin Woodman and Toto were sitting.
children.prevalue: So the big bird flew into the air and over the water till she came to where the Scarecrow was perched upon his pole Then the Stork with her great claws grabbed the Scarecrow by the arm and carried him up into the air and back to the bank where Dorothy and the Lion and the Tin Woodman and Toto were sitting

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: When the Scarecrow found himself among his friends again, he was so happy that he hugged them all, even the Lion and Toto; and as they walked along he sang Tol-de-ri-de-oh! at every step, he felt so gay.
children.prevalue: When the Scarecrow found himself among his friends again he was so happy that he hugged them all even the Lion and Toto and as they walked along he sang Tol de ri de oh at every step he felt so gay

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: I was afraid I should have to stay in the river forever, he said, but the kind Stork saved me, and if I ever get any brains I shall find the Stork again and do her some kindness in return.
children.prevalue: I was afraid I should have to stay in the river forever he said but the kind Stork saved me and if I ever get any brains I shall find the Stork again and do her some kindness in return

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: That's all right, said the Stork, who was flying along beside them. I always like to help anyone in trouble.  But I must go now, for my babies are waiting in the nest for me.  I hope you will find the Emerald City and that Oz will help you.
children.prevalue: That s all right said the Stork who was flying along beside them I always like to help anyone in trouble But I must go now for my babies are waiting in the nest for me I hope you will find the Emerald City and that Oz will help you

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Thank you, replied Dorothy, and then the kind Stork flew into the air and was soon out of sight.
children.prevalue: Thank you replied Dorothy and then the kind Stork flew into the air and was soon out of sight

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: They walked along listening to the singing of the brightly colored birds and looking at the lovely flowers which now became so thick that the ground was carpeted with them.  There were big yellow and white and blue and purple blossoms, besides great clusters of scarlet poppies, which were so brilliant in color they almost dazzled Dorothy's eyes.
children.prevalue: They walked along listening to the singing of the brightly colored birds and looking at the lovely flowers which now became so thick that the ground was carpeted with them There were big yellow and white and blue and purple blossoms besides great clusters of scarlet poppies which were so brilliant in color they almost dazzled Dorothy s eyes

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Aren't they beautiful? the girl asked, as she breathed in the spicy scent of the bright flowers.
children.prevalue: Aren t they beautiful the girl asked as she breathed in the spicy scent of the bright flowers

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: I suppose so, answered the Scarecrow.  When I have brains, I shall probably like them better.
children.prevalue: I suppose so answered the Scarecrow When I have brains I shall probably like them better

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: If I only had a heart, I should love them, added the Tin Woodman.
children.prevalue: If I only had a heart I should love them added the Tin Woodman

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: I always did like flowers, said the Lion.  They seem so helpless and frail.  But there are none in the forest so bright as these.
children.prevalue: I always did like flowers said the Lion They seem so helpless and frail But there are none in the forest so bright as these

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: They now came upon more and more of the big scarlet poppies, and fewer and fewer of the other flowers; and soon they found themselves in the midst of a great meadow of poppies.  Now it is well known that when there are many of these flowers together their odor is so powerful that anyone who breathes it falls asleep, and if the sleeper is not carried away from the scent of the flowers, he sleeps on and on forever.  But Dorothy did not know this, nor could she get away from the bright red flowers that were everywhere about; so presently her eyes grew heavy and she felt she must sit down to rest and to sleep.
children.prevalue: They now came upon more and more of the big scarlet poppies and fewer and fewer of the other flowers and soon they found themselves in the midst of a great meadow of poppies Now it is well known that when there are many of these flowers together their odor is so powerful that anyone who breathes it falls asleep and if the sleeper is not carried away from the scent of the flowers he sleeps on and on forever But Dorothy did not know this nor could she get away from the bright red flowers that were everywhere about so presently her eyes grew heavy and she felt she must sit down to rest and to sleep

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: But the Tin Woodman would not let her do this.
children.prevalue: But the Tin Woodman would not let her do this

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: We must hurry and get back to the road of yellow brick before dark, he said; and the Scarecrow agreed with him.  So they kept walking until Dorothy could stand no longer.  Her eyes closed in spite of herself and she forgot where she was and fell among the poppies, fast asleep.
children.prevalue: We must hurry and get back to the road of yellow brick before dark he said and the Scarecrow agreed with him So they kept walking until Dorothy could stand no longer Her eyes closed in spite of herself and she forgot where she was and fell among the poppies fast asleep

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: What shall we do? asked the Tin Woodman.
children.prevalue: What shall we do asked the Tin Woodman

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: If we leave her here she will die, said the Lion.  The smell of the flowers is killing us all.  I myself can scarcely keep my eyes open, and the dog is asleep already.
children.prevalue: If we leave her here she will die said the Lion The smell of the flowers is killing us all I myself can scarcely keep my eyes open and the dog is asleep already

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: It was true; Toto had fallen down beside his little mistress.  But the Scarecrow and the Tin Woodman, not being made of flesh, were not troubled by the scent of the flowers.
children.prevalue: It was true Toto had fallen down beside his little mistress But the Scarecrow and the Tin Woodman not being made of flesh were not troubled by the scent of the flowers

children.name: Paragraph_50
