children.value: Run fast, said the Scarecrow to the Lion, and get out of this deadly flower bed as soon as you can.  We will bring the little girl with us, but if you should fall asleep you are too big to be carried.
children.prevalue: Run fast said the Scarecrow to the Lion and get out of this deadly flower bed as soon as you can We will bring the little girl with us but if you should fall asleep you are too big to be carried

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: So the Lion aroused himself and bounded forward as fast as he could go. In a moment he was out of sight.
children.prevalue: So the Lion aroused himself and bounded forward as fast as he could go In a moment he was out of sight

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: Let us make a chair with our hands and carry her, said the Scarecrow. So they picked up Toto and put the dog in Dorothy's lap, and then they made a chair with their hands for the seat and their arms for the arms and carried the sleeping girl between them through the flowers.
children.prevalue: Let us make a chair with our hands and carry her said the Scarecrow So they picked up Toto and put the dog in Dorothy s lap and then they made a chair with their hands for the seat and their arms for the arms and carried the sleeping girl between them through the flowers

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: On and on they walked, and it seemed that the great carpet of deadly flowers that surrounded them would never end.  They followed the bend of the river, and at last came upon their friend the Lion, lying fast asleep among the poppies.  The flowers had been too strong for the huge beast and he had given up at last, and fallen only a short distance from the end of the poppy bed, where the sweet grass spread in beautiful green fields before them.
children.prevalue: On and on they walked and it seemed that the great carpet of deadly flowers that surrounded them would never end They followed the bend of the river and at last came upon their friend the Lion lying fast asleep among the poppies The flowers had been too strong for the huge beast and he had given up at last and fallen only a short distance from the end of the poppy bed where the sweet grass spread in beautiful green fields before them

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: We can do nothing for him, said the Tin Woodman, sadly; for he is much too heavy to lift.  We must leave him here to sleep on forever, and perhaps he will dream that he has found courage at last.
children.prevalue: We can do nothing for him said the Tin Woodman sadly for he is much too heavy to lift We must leave him here to sleep on forever and perhaps he will dream that he has found courage at last

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: I'm sorry, said the Scarecrow.  The Lion was a very good comrade for one so cowardly.  But let us go on.
children.prevalue: I m sorry said the Scarecrow The Lion was a very good comrade for one so cowardly But let us go on

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: They carried the sleeping girl to a pretty spot beside the river, far enough from the poppy field to prevent her breathing any more of the poison of the flowers, and here they laid her gently on the soft grass and waited for the fresh breeze to waken her.
children.prevalue: They carried the sleeping girl to a pretty spot beside the river far enough from the poppy field to prevent her breathing any more of the poison of the flowers and here they laid her gently on the soft grass and waited for the fresh breeze to waken her

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: We cannot be far from the road of yellow brick, now, remarked the Scarecrow, as he stood beside the girl, for we have come nearly as far as the river carried us away.
children.prevalue: We cannot be far from the road of yellow brick now remarked the Scarecrow as he stood beside the girl for we have come nearly as far as the river carried us away

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The Tin Woodman was about to reply when he heard a low growl, and turning his head (which worked beautifully on hinges) he saw a strange beast come bounding over the grass toward them.  It was, indeed, a great yellow Wildcat, and the Woodman thought it must be chasing something, for its ears were lying close to its head and its mouth was wide open, showing two rows of ugly teeth, while its red eyes glowed like balls of fire.  As it came nearer the Tin Woodman saw that running before the beast was a little gray field mouse, and although he had no heart he knew it was wrong for the Wildcat to try to kill such a pretty, harmless creature.
children.prevalue: The Tin Woodman was about to reply when he heard a low growl and turning his head which worked beautifully on hinges he saw a strange beast come bounding over the grass toward them It was indeed a great yellow Wildcat and the Woodman thought it must be chasing something for its ears were lying close to its head and its mouth was wide open showing two rows of ugly teeth while its red eyes glowed like balls of fire As it came nearer the Tin Woodman saw that running before the beast was a little gray field mouse and although he had no heart he knew it was wrong for the Wildcat to try to kill such a pretty harmless creature

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: So the Woodman raised his axe, and as the Wildcat ran by he gave it a quick blow that cut the beast's head clean off from its body, and it rolled over at his feet in two pieces.
children.prevalue: So the Woodman raised his axe and as the Wildcat ran by he gave it a quick blow that cut the beast s head clean off from its body and it rolled over at his feet in two pieces

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: The field mouse, now that it was freed from its enemy, stopped short; and coming slowly up to the Woodman it said, in a squeaky little voice:
children.prevalue: The field mouse now that it was freed from its enemy stopped short and coming slowly up to the Woodman it said in a squeaky little voice

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Oh, thank you!  Thank you ever so much for saving my life.
children.prevalue: Oh thank you Thank you ever so much for saving my life

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Don't speak of it, I beg of you, replied the Woodman.  I have no heart, you know, so I am careful to help all those who may need a friend, even if it happens to be only a mouse.
children.prevalue: Don t speak of it I beg of you replied the Woodman I have no heart you know so I am careful to help all those who may need a friend even if it happens to be only a mouse

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Only a mouse! cried the little animal, indignantly.  Why, I am a Queen--the Queen of all the Field Mice!
children.prevalue: Only a mouse cried the little animal indignantly Why I am a Queen the Queen of all the Field Mice

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Oh, indeed, said the Woodman, making a bow.
children.prevalue: Oh indeed said the Woodman making a bow

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Therefore you have done a great deed, as well as a brave one, in saving my life, added the Queen.
children.prevalue: Therefore you have done a great deed as well as a brave one in saving my life added the Queen

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: At that moment several mice were seen running up as fast as their little legs could carry them, and when they saw their Queen they exclaimed:
children.prevalue: At that moment several mice were seen running up as fast as their little legs could carry them and when they saw their Queen they exclaimed

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Oh, your Majesty, we thought you would be killed!  How did you manage to escape the great Wildcat?  They all bowed so low to the little Queen that they almost stood upon their heads.
children.prevalue: Oh your Majesty we thought you would be killed How did you manage to escape the great Wildcat They all bowed so low to the little Queen that they almost stood upon their heads

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: This funny tin man, she answered, killed the Wildcat and saved my life.  So hereafter you must all serve him, and obey his slightest wish.
children.prevalue: This funny tin man she answered killed the Wildcat and saved my life So hereafter you must all serve him and obey his slightest wish

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: We will! cried all the mice, in a shrill chorus.  And then they scampered in all directions, for Toto had awakened from his sleep, and seeing all these mice around him he gave one bark of delight and jumped right into the middle of the group.  Toto had always loved to chase mice when he lived in Kansas, and he saw no harm in it.
children.prevalue: We will cried all the mice in a shrill chorus And then they scampered in all directions for Toto had awakened from his sleep and seeing all these mice around him he gave one bark of delight and jumped right into the middle of the group Toto had always loved to chase mice when he lived in Kansas and he saw no harm in it

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: But the Tin Woodman caught the dog in his arms and held him tight, while he called to the mice, Come back!  Come back!  Toto shall not hurt you.
children.prevalue: But the Tin Woodman caught the dog in his arms and held him tight while he called to the mice Come back Come back Toto shall not hurt you

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: At this the Queen of the Mice stuck her head out from underneath a clump of grass and asked, in a timid voice, Are you sure he will not bite us?
children.prevalue: At this the Queen of the Mice stuck her head out from underneath a clump of grass and asked in a timid voice Are you sure he will not bite us

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: I will not let him, said the Woodman; so do not be afraid.
children.prevalue: I will not let him said the Woodman so do not be afraid

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: One by one the mice came creeping back, and Toto did not bark again, although he tried to get out of the Woodman's arms, and would have bitten him had he not known very well he was made of tin.  Finally one of the biggest mice spoke.
children.prevalue: One by one the mice came creeping back and Toto did not bark again although he tried to get out of the Woodman s arms and would have bitten him had he not known very well he was made of tin Finally one of the biggest mice spoke

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Is there anything we can do, it asked, to repay you for saving the life of our Queen?
children.prevalue: Is there anything we can do it asked to repay you for saving the life of our Queen

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Nothing that I know of, answered the Woodman; but the Scarecrow, who had been trying to think, but could not because his head was stuffed with straw, said, quickly, Oh, yes; you can save our friend, the Cowardly Lion, who is asleep in the poppy bed.
children.prevalue: Nothing that I know of answered the Woodman but the Scarecrow who had been trying to think but could not because his head was stuffed with straw said quickly Oh yes you can save our friend the Cowardly Lion who is asleep in the poppy bed

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: A Lion! cried the little Queen.  Why, he would eat us all up.
children.prevalue: A Lion cried the little Queen Why he would eat us all up

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Oh, no, declared the Scarecrow; this Lion is a coward.
children.prevalue: Oh no declared the Scarecrow this Lion is a coward

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Really? asked the Mouse.
children.prevalue: Really asked the Mouse

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: He says so himself, answered the Scarecrow, and he would never hurt anyone who is our friend.  If you will help us to save him I promise that he shall treat you all with kindness.
children.prevalue: He says so himself answered the Scarecrow and he would never hurt anyone who is our friend If you will help us to save him I promise that he shall treat you all with kindness

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Very well, said the Queen, we trust you.  But what shall we do?
children.prevalue: Very well said the Queen we trust you But what shall we do

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Are there many of these mice which call you Queen and are willing to obey you?
children.prevalue: Are there many of these mice which call you Queen and are willing to obey you

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Oh, yes; there are thousands, she replied.
children.prevalue: Oh yes there are thousands she replied

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Then send for them all to come here as soon as possible, and let each one bring a long piece of string.
children.prevalue: Then send for them all to come here as soon as possible and let each one bring a long piece of string

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: The Queen turned to the mice that attended her and told them to go at once and get all her people.  As soon as they heard her orders they ran away in every direction as fast as possible.
children.prevalue: The Queen turned to the mice that attended her and told them to go at once and get all her people As soon as they heard her orders they ran away in every direction as fast as possible

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Now, said the Scarecrow to the Tin Woodman, you must go to those trees by the riverside and make a truck that will carry the Lion.
children.prevalue: Now said the Scarecrow to the Tin Woodman you must go to those trees by the riverside and make a truck that will carry the Lion

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: So the Woodman went at once to the trees and began to work; and he soon made a truck out of the limbs of trees, from which he chopped away all the leaves and branches.  He fastened it together with wooden pegs and made the four wheels out of short pieces of a big tree trunk.  So fast and so well did he work that by the time the mice began to arrive the truck was all ready for them.
children.prevalue: So the Woodman went at once to the trees and began to work and he soon made a truck out of the limbs of trees from which he chopped away all the leaves and branches He fastened it together with wooden pegs and made the four wheels out of short pieces of a big tree trunk So fast and so well did he work that by the time the mice began to arrive the truck was all ready for them

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: They came from all directions, and there were thousands of them: big mice and little mice and middle-sized mice; and each one brought a piece of string in his mouth.  It was about this time that Dorothy woke from her long sleep and opened her eyes.  She was greatly astonished to find herself lying upon the grass, with thousands of mice standing around and looking at her timidly.  But the Scarecrow told her about everything, and turning to the dignified little Mouse, he said:
children.prevalue: They came from all directions and there were thousands of them big mice and little mice and middle sized mice and each one brought a piece of string in his mouth It was about this time that Dorothy woke from her long sleep and opened her eyes She was greatly astonished to find herself lying upon the grass with thousands of mice standing around and looking at her timidly But the Scarecrow told her about everything and turning to the dignified little Mouse he said

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Permit me to introduce to you her Majesty, the Queen.
children.prevalue: Permit me to introduce to you her Majesty the Queen

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Dorothy nodded gravely and the Queen made a curtsy, after which she became quite friendly with the little girl.
children.prevalue: Dorothy nodded gravely and the Queen made a curtsy after which she became quite friendly with the little girl

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: The Scarecrow and the Woodman now began to fasten the mice to the truck, using the strings they had brought.  One end of a string was tied around the neck of each mouse and the other end to the truck.  Of course the truck was a thousand times bigger than any of the mice who were to draw it; but when all the mice had been harnessed, they were able to pull it quite easily.  Even the Scarecrow and the Tin Woodman could sit on it, and were drawn swiftly by their queer little horses to the place where the Lion lay asleep.
children.prevalue: The Scarecrow and the Woodman now began to fasten the mice to the truck using the strings they had brought One end of a string was tied around the neck of each mouse and the other end to the truck Of course the truck was a thousand times bigger than any of the mice who were to draw it but when all the mice had been harnessed they were able to pull it quite easily Even the Scarecrow and the Tin Woodman could sit on it and were drawn swiftly by their queer little horses to the place where the Lion lay asleep

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: After a great deal of hard work, for the Lion was heavy, they managed to get him up on the truck.  Then the Queen hurriedly gave her people the order to start, for she feared if the mice stayed among the poppies too long they also would fall asleep.
children.prevalue: After a great deal of hard work for the Lion was heavy they managed to get him up on the truck Then the Queen hurriedly gave her people the order to start for she feared if the mice stayed among the poppies too long they also would fall asleep

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: At first the little creatures, many though they were, could hardly stir the heavily loaded truck; but the Woodman and the Scarecrow both pushed from behind, and they got along better.  Soon they rolled the Lion out of the poppy bed to the green fields, where he could breathe the sweet, fresh air again, instead of the poisonous scent of the flowers.
children.prevalue: At first the little creatures many though they were could hardly stir the heavily loaded truck but the Woodman and the Scarecrow both pushed from behind and they got along better Soon they rolled the Lion out of the poppy bed to the green fields where he could breathe the sweet fresh air again instead of the poisonous scent of the flowers

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Dorothy came to meet them and thanked the little mice warmly for saving her companion from death.  She had grown so fond of the big Lion she was glad he had been rescued.
children.prevalue: Dorothy came to meet them and thanked the little mice warmly for saving her companion from death She had grown so fond of the big Lion she was glad he had been rescued

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Then the mice were unharnessed from the truck and scampered away through the grass to their homes.  The Queen of the Mice was the last to leave.
children.prevalue: Then the mice were unharnessed from the truck and scampered away through the grass to their homes The Queen of the Mice was the last to leave

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: If ever you need us again, she said, come out into the field and call, and we shall hear you and come to your assistance.  Good-bye!
children.prevalue: If ever you need us again she said come out into the field and call and we shall hear you and come to your assistance Good bye

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Good-bye! they all answered, and away the Queen ran, while Dorothy held Toto tightly lest he should run after her and frighten her.
children.prevalue: Good bye they all answered and away the Queen ran while Dorothy held Toto tightly lest he should run after her and frighten her

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: After this they sat down beside the Lion until he should awaken; and the Scarecrow brought Dorothy some fruit from a tree near by, which she ate for her dinner.
children.prevalue: After this they sat down beside the Lion until he should awaken and the Scarecrow brought Dorothy some fruit from a tree near by which she ate for her dinner

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: It was some time before the Cowardly Lion awakened, for he had lain among the poppies a long while, breathing in their deadly fragrance; but when he did open his eyes and roll off the truck he was very glad to find himself still alive.
children.prevalue: It was some time before the Cowardly Lion awakened for he had lain among the poppies a long while breathing in their deadly fragrance but when he did open his eyes and roll off the truck he was very glad to find himself still alive

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: I ran as fast as I could, he said, sitting down and yawning, but the flowers were too strong for me.  How did you get me out?
children.prevalue: I ran as fast as I could he said sitting down and yawning but the flowers were too strong for me How did you get me out

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Then they told him of the field mice, and how they had generously saved him from death; and the Cowardly Lion laughed, and said:
children.prevalue: Then they told him of the field mice and how they had generously saved him from death and the Cowardly Lion laughed and said

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: I have always thought myself very big and terrible; yet such little things as flowers came near to killing me, and such small animals as mice have saved my life.  How strange it all is!  But, comrades, what shall we do now?
children.prevalue: I have always thought myself very big and terrible yet such little things as flowers came near to killing me and such small animals as mice have saved my life How strange it all is But comrades what shall we do now

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: We must journey on until we find the road of yellow brick again, said Dorothy, and then we can keep on to the Emerald City.
children.prevalue: We must journey on until we find the road of yellow brick again said Dorothy and then we can keep on to the Emerald City

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: So, the Lion being fully refreshed, and feeling quite himself again, they all started upon the journey, greatly enjoying the walk through the soft, fresh grass; and it was not long before they reached the road of yellow brick and turned again toward the Emerald City where the Great Oz dwelt.
children.prevalue: So the Lion being fully refreshed and feeling quite himself again they all started upon the journey greatly enjoying the walk through the soft fresh grass and it was not long before they reached the road of yellow brick and turned again toward the Emerald City where the Great Oz dwelt

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: The road was smooth and well paved, now, and the country about was beautiful, so that the travelers rejoiced in leaving the forest far behind, and with it the many dangers they had met in its gloomy shades. Once more they could see fences built beside the road; but these were painted green, and when they came to a small house, in which a farmer evidently lived, that also was painted green.  They passed by several of these houses during the afternoon, and sometimes people came to the doors and looked at them as if they would like to ask questions; but no one came near them nor spoke to them because of the great Lion, of which they were very much afraid.  The people were all dressed in clothing of a lovely emerald-green color and wore peaked hats like those of the Munchkins.
children.prevalue: The road was smooth and well paved now and the country about was beautiful so that the travelers rejoiced in leaving the forest far behind and with it the many dangers they had met in its gloomy shades Once more they could see fences built beside the road but these were painted green and when they came to a small house in which a farmer evidently lived that also was painted green They passed by several of these houses during the afternoon and sometimes people came to the doors and looked at them as if they would like to ask questions but no one came near them nor spoke to them because of the great Lion of which they were very much afraid The people were all dressed in clothing of a lovely emerald green color and wore peaked hats like those of the Munchkins

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: This must be the Land of Oz, said Dorothy, and we are surely getting near the Emerald City.
children.prevalue: This must be the Land of Oz said Dorothy and we are surely getting near the Emerald City

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Yes, answered the Scarecrow.  Everything is green here, while in the country of the Munchkins blue was the favorite color.  But the people do not seem to be as friendly as the Munchkins, and I'm afraid we shall be unable to find a place to pass the night.
children.prevalue: Yes answered the Scarecrow Everything is green here while in the country of the Munchkins blue was the favorite color But the people do not seem to be as friendly as the Munchkins and I m afraid we shall be unable to find a place to pass the night

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: I should like something to eat besides fruit, said the girl, and I'm sure Toto is nearly starved.  Let us stop at the next house and talk to the people.
children.prevalue: I should like something to eat besides fruit said the girl and I m sure Toto is nearly starved Let us stop at the next house and talk to the people

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: So, when they came to a good-sized farmhouse, Dorothy walked boldly up to the door and knocked.
children.prevalue: So when they came to a good sized farmhouse Dorothy walked boldly up to the door and knocked

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: A woman opened it just far enough to look out, and said, What do you want, child, and why is that great Lion with you?
children.prevalue: A woman opened it just far enough to look out and said What do you want child and why is that great Lion with you

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: We wish to pass the night with you, if you will allow us, answered Dorothy; and the Lion is my friend and comrade, and would not hurt you for the world.
children.prevalue: We wish to pass the night with you if you will allow us answered Dorothy and the Lion is my friend and comrade and would not hurt you for the world

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Is he tame? asked the woman, opening the door a little wider.
children.prevalue: Is he tame asked the woman opening the door a little wider

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Oh, yes, said the girl, and he is a great coward, too.  He will be more afraid of you than you are of him.
children.prevalue: Oh yes said the girl and he is a great coward too He will be more afraid of you than you are of him

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Well, said the woman, after thinking it over and taking another peep at the Lion, if that is the case you may come in, and I will give you some supper and a place to sleep.
children.prevalue: Well said the woman after thinking it over and taking another peep at the Lion if that is the case you may come in and I will give you some supper and a place to sleep

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: So they all entered the house, where there were, besides the woman, two children and a man.  The man had hurt his leg, and was lying on the couch in a corner.  They seemed greatly surprised to see so strange a company, and while the woman was busy laying the table the man asked:
children.prevalue: So they all entered the house where there were besides the woman two children and a man The man had hurt his leg and was lying on the couch in a corner They seemed greatly surprised to see so strange a company and while the woman was busy laying the table the man asked

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Where are you all going?
children.prevalue: Where are you all going

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: To the Emerald City, said Dorothy, to see the Great Oz.
children.prevalue: To the Emerald City said Dorothy to see the Great Oz

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Oh, indeed! exclaimed the man.  Are you sure that Oz will see you?
children.prevalue: Oh indeed exclaimed the man Are you sure that Oz will see you

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Why not? she replied.
children.prevalue: Why not she replied

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Why, it is said that he never lets anyone come into his presence.  I have been to the Emerald City many times, and it is a beautiful and wonderful place; but I have never been permitted to see the Great Oz, nor do I know of any living person who has seen him.
children.prevalue: Why it is said that he never lets anyone come into his presence I have been to the Emerald City many times and it is a beautiful and wonderful place but I have never been permitted to see the Great Oz nor do I know of any living person who has seen him

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Does he never go out? asked the Scarecrow.
children.prevalue: Does he never go out asked the Scarecrow

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Never.  He sits day after day in the great Throne Room of his Palace, and even those who wait upon him do not see him face to face.
children.prevalue: Never He sits day after day in the great Throne Room of his Palace and even those who wait upon him do not see him face to face

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: What is he like? asked the girl.
children.prevalue: What is he like asked the girl

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: That is hard to tell, said the man thoughtfully.  You see, Oz is a Great Wizard, and can take on any form he wishes.  So that some say he looks like a bird; and some say he looks like an elephant; and some say he looks like a cat.  To others he appears as a beautiful fairy, or a brownie, or in any other form that pleases him.  But who the real Oz is, when he is in his own form, no living person can tell.
children.prevalue: That is hard to tell said the man thoughtfully You see Oz is a Great Wizard and can take on any form he wishes So that some say he looks like a bird and some say he looks like an elephant and some say he looks like a cat To others he appears as a beautiful fairy or a brownie or in any other form that pleases him But who the real Oz is when he is in his own form no living person can tell

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: That is very strange, said Dorothy, but we must try, in some way, to see him, or we shall have made our journey for nothing.
children.prevalue: That is very strange said Dorothy but we must try in some way to see him or we shall have made our journey for nothing

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Why do you wish to see the terrible Oz? asked the man.
children.prevalue: Why do you wish to see the terrible Oz asked the man

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: I want him to give me some brains, said the Scarecrow eagerly.
children.prevalue: I want him to give me some brains said the Scarecrow eagerly

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Oh, Oz could do that easily enough, declared the man.  He has more brains than he needs.
children.prevalue: Oh Oz could do that easily enough declared the man He has more brains than he needs

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: And I want him to give me a heart, said the Tin Woodman.
children.prevalue: And I want him to give me a heart said the Tin Woodman

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: That will not trouble him, continued the man, for Oz has a large collection of hearts, of all sizes and shapes.
children.prevalue: That will not trouble him continued the man for Oz has a large collection of hearts of all sizes and shapes

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: And I want him to give me courage, said the Cowardly Lion.
children.prevalue: And I want him to give me courage said the Cowardly Lion

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Oz keeps a great pot of courage in his Throne Room, said the man, which he has covered with a golden plate, to keep it from running over.  He will be glad to give you some.
children.prevalue: Oz keeps a great pot of courage in his Throne Room said the man which he has covered with a golden plate to keep it from running over He will be glad to give you some

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: And I want him to send me back to Kansas, said Dorothy.
children.prevalue: And I want him to send me back to Kansas said Dorothy

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Where is Kansas? asked the man, with surprise.
children.prevalue: Where is Kansas asked the man with surprise

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: I don't know, replied Dorothy sorrowfully, but it is my home, and I'm sure it's somewhere.
children.prevalue: I don t know replied Dorothy sorrowfully but it is my home and I m sure it s somewhere

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Very likely.  Well, Oz can do anything; so I suppose he will find Kansas for you.  But first you must get to see him, and that will be a hard task; for the Great Wizard does not like to see anyone, and he usually has his own way.  But what do YOU want? he continued, speaking to Toto.  Toto only wagged his tail; for, strange to say, he could not speak.
children.prevalue: Very likely Well Oz can do anything so I suppose he will find Kansas for you But first you must get to see him and that will be a hard task for the Great Wizard does not like to see anyone and he usually has his own way But what do YOU want he continued speaking to Toto Toto only wagged his tail for strange to say he could not speak

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: The woman now called to them that supper was ready, so they gathered around the table and Dorothy ate some delicious porridge and a dish of scrambled eggs and a plate of nice white bread, and enjoyed her meal. The Lion ate some of the porridge, but did not care for it, saying it was made from oats and oats were food for horses, not for lions.  The Scarecrow and the Tin Woodman ate nothing at all.  Toto ate a little of everything, and was glad to get a good supper again.
children.prevalue: The woman now called to them that supper was ready so they gathered around the table and Dorothy ate some delicious porridge and a dish of scrambled eggs and a plate of nice white bread and enjoyed her meal The Lion ate some of the porridge but did not care for it saying it was made from oats and oats were food for horses not for lions The Scarecrow and the Tin Woodman ate nothing at all Toto ate a little of everything and was glad to get a good supper again

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: The woman now gave Dorothy a bed to sleep in, and Toto lay down beside her, while the Lion guarded the door of her room so she might not be disturbed.  The Scarecrow and the Tin Woodman stood up in a corner and kept quiet all night, although of course they could not sleep.
children.prevalue: The woman now gave Dorothy a bed to sleep in and Toto lay down beside her while the Lion guarded the door of her room so she might not be disturbed The Scarecrow and the Tin Woodman stood up in a corner and kept quiet all night although of course they could not sleep

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: The next morning, as soon as the sun was up, they started on their way, and soon saw a beautiful green glow in the sky just before them.
children.prevalue: The next morning as soon as the sun was up they started on their way and soon saw a beautiful green glow in the sky just before them

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: That must be the Emerald City, said Dorothy.
children.prevalue: That must be the Emerald City said Dorothy

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: As they walked on, the green glow became brighter and brighter, and it seemed that at last they were nearing the end of their travels.  Yet it was afternoon before they came to the great wall that surrounded the City.  It was high and thick and of a bright green color.
children.prevalue: As they walked on the green glow became brighter and brighter and it seemed that at last they were nearing the end of their travels Yet it was afternoon before they came to the great wall that surrounded the City It was high and thick and of a bright green color

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: In front of them, and at the end of the road of yellow brick, was a big gate, all studded with emeralds that glittered so in the sun that even the painted eyes of the Scarecrow were dazzled by their brilliancy.
children.prevalue: In front of them and at the end of the road of yellow brick was a big gate all studded with emeralds that glittered so in the sun that even the painted eyes of the Scarecrow were dazzled by their brilliancy

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: There was a bell beside the gate, and Dorothy pushed the button and heard a silvery tinkle sound within.  Then the big gate swung slowly open, and they all passed through and found themselves in a high arched room, the walls of which glistened with countless emeralds.
children.prevalue: There was a bell beside the gate and Dorothy pushed the button and heard a silvery tinkle sound within Then the big gate swung slowly open and they all passed through and found themselves in a high arched room the walls of which glistened with countless emeralds

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Before them stood a little man about the same size as the Munchkins. He was clothed all in green, from his head to his feet, and even his skin was of a greenish tint.  At his side was a large green box.
children.prevalue: Before them stood a little man about the same size as the Munchkins He was clothed all in green from his head to his feet and even his skin was of a greenish tint At his side was a large green box

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: When he saw Dorothy and her companions the man asked, What do you wish in the Emerald City?
children.prevalue: When he saw Dorothy and her companions the man asked What do you wish in the Emerald City

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: We came here to see the Great Oz, said Dorothy.
children.prevalue: We came here to see the Great Oz said Dorothy

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: The man was so surprised at this answer that he sat down to think it over.
children.prevalue: The man was so surprised at this answer that he sat down to think it over

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: It has been many years since anyone asked me to see Oz, he said, shaking his head in perplexity.  He is powerful and terrible, and if you come on an idle or foolish errand to bother the wise reflections of the Great Wizard, he might be angry and destroy you all in an instant.
children.prevalue: It has been many years since anyone asked me to see Oz he said shaking his head in perplexity He is powerful and terrible and if you come on an idle or foolish errand to bother the wise reflections of the Great Wizard he might be angry and destroy you all in an instant

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: But it is not a foolish errand, nor an idle one, replied the Scarecrow; it is important.  And we have been told that Oz is a good Wizard.
children.prevalue: But it is not a foolish errand nor an idle one replied the Scarecrow it is important And we have been told that Oz is a good Wizard

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: So he is, said the green man, and he rules the Emerald City wisely and well.  But to those who are not honest, or who approach him from curiosity, he is most terrible, and few have ever dared ask to see his face.  I am the Guardian of the Gates, and since you demand to see the Great Oz I must take you to his Palace.  But first you must put on the spectacles.
children.prevalue: So he is said the green man and he rules the Emerald City wisely and well But to those who are not honest or who approach him from curiosity he is most terrible and few have ever dared ask to see his face I am the Guardian of the Gates and since you demand to see the Great Oz I must take you to his Palace But first you must put on the spectacles

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Why? asked Dorothy.
children.prevalue: Why asked Dorothy

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: Because if you did not wear spectacles the brightness and glory of the Emerald City would blind you.  Even those who live in the City must wear spectacles night and day.  They are all locked on, for Oz so ordered it when the City was first built, and I have the only key that will unlock them.
children.prevalue: Because if you did not wear spectacles the brightness and glory of the Emerald City would blind you Even those who live in the City must wear spectacles night and day They are all locked on for Oz so ordered it when the City was first built and I have the only key that will unlock them

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: He opened the big box, and Dorothy saw that it was filled with spectacles of every size and shape.  All of them had green glasses in them.  The Guardian of the Gates found a pair that would just fit Dorothy and put them over her eyes.  There were two golden bands fastened to them that passed around the back of her head, where they were locked together by a little key that was at the end of a chain the Guardian of the Gates wore around his neck.  When they were on, Dorothy could not take them off had she wished, but of course she did not wish to be blinded by the glare of the Emerald City, so she said nothing.
children.prevalue: He opened the big box and Dorothy saw that it was filled with spectacles of every size and shape All of them had green glasses in them The Guardian of the Gates found a pair that would just fit Dorothy and put them over her eyes There were two golden bands fastened to them that passed around the back of her head where they were locked together by a little key that was at the end of a chain the Guardian of the Gates wore around his neck When they were on Dorothy could not take them off had she wished but of course she did not wish to be blinded by the glare of the Emerald City so she said nothing

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: Then the green man fitted spectacles for the Scarecrow and the Tin Woodman and the Lion, and even on little Toto; and all were locked fast with the key.
children.prevalue: Then the green man fitted spectacles for the Scarecrow and the Tin Woodman and the Lion and even on little Toto and all were locked fast with the key

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Then the Guardian of the Gates put on his own glasses and told them he was ready to show them to the Palace.  Taking a big golden key from a peg on the wall, he opened another gate, and they all followed him through the portal into the streets of the Emerald City.
children.prevalue: Then the Guardian of the Gates put on his own glasses and told them he was ready to show them to the Palace Taking a big golden key from a peg on the wall he opened another gate and they all followed him through the portal into the streets of the Emerald City

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Even with eyes protected by the green spectacles, Dorothy and her friends were at first dazzled by the brilliancy of the wonderful City. The streets were lined with beautiful houses all built of green marble and studded everywhere with sparkling emeralds.  They walked over a pavement of the same green marble, and where the blocks were joined together were rows of emeralds, set closely, and glittering in the brightness of the sun.  The window panes were of green glass; even the sky above the City had a green tint, and the rays of the sun were green.
children.prevalue: Even with eyes protected by the green spectacles Dorothy and her friends were at first dazzled by the brilliancy of the wonderful City The streets were lined with beautiful houses all built of green marble and studded everywhere with sparkling emeralds They walked over a pavement of the same green marble and where the blocks were joined together were rows of emeralds set closely and glittering in the brightness of the sun The window panes were of green glass even the sky above the City had a green tint and the rays of the sun were green

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: There were many people--men, women, and children--walking about, and these were all dressed in green clothes and had greenish skins.  They looked at Dorothy and her strangely assorted company with wondering eyes, and the children all ran away and hid behind their mothers when they saw the Lion; but no one spoke to them.  Many shops stood in the street, and Dorothy saw that everything in them was green.  Green candy and green pop corn were offered for sale, as well as green shoes, green hats, and green clothes of all sorts.  At one place a man was selling green lemonade, and when the children bought it Dorothy could see that they paid for it with green pennies.
children.prevalue: There were many people men women and children walking about and these were all dressed in green clothes and had greenish skins They looked at Dorothy and her strangely assorted company with wondering eyes and the children all ran away and hid behind their mothers when they saw the Lion but no one spoke to them Many shops stood in the street and Dorothy saw that everything in them was green Green candy and green pop corn were offered for sale as well as green shoes green hats and green clothes of all sorts At one place a man was selling green lemonade and when the children bought it Dorothy could see that they paid for it with green pennies

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: There seemed to be no horses nor animals of any kind; the men carried things around in little green carts, which they pushed before them. Everyone seemed happy and contented and prosperous.
children.prevalue: There seemed to be no horses nor animals of any kind the men carried things around in little green carts which they pushed before them Everyone seemed happy and contented and prosperous

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: The Guardian of the Gates led them through the streets until they came to a big building, exactly in the middle of the City, which was the Palace of Oz, the Great Wizard.  There was a soldier before the door, dressed in a green uniform and wearing a long green beard.
children.prevalue: The Guardian of the Gates led them through the streets until they came to a big building exactly in the middle of the City which was the Palace of Oz the Great Wizard There was a soldier before the door dressed in a green uniform and wearing a long green beard

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Here are strangers, said the Guardian of the Gates to him, and they demand to see the Great Oz.
children.prevalue: Here are strangers said the Guardian of the Gates to him and they demand to see the Great Oz

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Step inside, answered the soldier, and I will carry your message to him.
children.prevalue: Step inside answered the soldier and I will carry your message to him

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: So they passed through the Palace Gates and were led into a big room with a green carpet and lovely green furniture set with emeralds.  The soldier made them all wipe their feet upon a green mat before entering this room, and when they were seated he said politely:
children.prevalue: So they passed through the Palace Gates and were led into a big room with a green carpet and lovely green furniture set with emeralds The soldier made them all wipe their feet upon a green mat before entering this room and when they were seated he said politely

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Please make yourselves comfortable while I go to the door of the Throne Room and tell Oz you are here.
children.prevalue: Please make yourselves comfortable while I go to the door of the Throne Room and tell Oz you are here

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: They had to wait a long time before the soldier returned.  When, at last, he came back, Dorothy asked:
children.prevalue: They had to wait a long time before the soldier returned When at last he came back Dorothy asked

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Have you seen Oz?
children.prevalue: Have you seen Oz

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Oh, no, returned the soldier; I have never seen him.  But I spoke to him as he sat behind his screen and gave him your message.  He said he will grant you an audience, if you so desire; but each one of you must enter his presence alone, and he will admit but one each day. Therefore, as you must remain in the Palace for several days, I will have you shown to rooms where you may rest in comfort after your journey.
children.prevalue: Oh no returned the soldier I have never seen him But I spoke to him as he sat behind his screen and gave him your message He said he will grant you an audience if you so desire but each one of you must enter his presence alone and he will admit but one each day Therefore as you must remain in the Palace for several days I will have you shown to rooms where you may rest in comfort after your journey

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Thank you, replied the girl; that is very kind of Oz.
children.prevalue: Thank you replied the girl that is very kind of Oz

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: The soldier now blew upon a green whistle, and at once a young girl, dressed in a pretty green silk gown, entered the room.  She had lovely green hair and green eyes, and she bowed low before Dorothy as she said, Follow me and I will show you your room.
children.prevalue: The soldier now blew upon a green whistle and at once a young girl dressed in a pretty green silk gown entered the room She had lovely green hair and green eyes and she bowed low before Dorothy as she said Follow me and I will show you your room

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: So Dorothy said good-bye to all her friends except Toto, and taking the dog in her arms followed the green girl through seven passages and up three flights of stairs until they came to a room at the front of the Palace.  It was the sweetest little room in the world, with a soft comfortable bed that had sheets of green silk and a green velvet counterpane.  There was a tiny fountain in the middle of the room, that shot a spray of green perfume into the air, to fall back into a beautifully carved green marble basin.  Beautiful green flowers stood in the windows, and there was a shelf with a row of little green books. When Dorothy had time to open these books she found them full of queer green pictures that made her laugh, they were so funny.
children.prevalue: So Dorothy said good bye to all her friends except Toto and taking the dog in her arms followed the green girl through seven passages and up three flights of stairs until they came to a room at the front of the Palace It was the sweetest little room in the world with a soft comfortable bed that had sheets of green silk and a green velvet counterpane There was a tiny fountain in the middle of the room that shot a spray of green perfume into the air to fall back into a beautifully carved green marble basin Beautiful green flowers stood in the windows and there was a shelf with a row of little green books When Dorothy had time to open these books she found them full of queer green pictures that made her laugh they were so funny

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: In a wardrobe were many green dresses, made of silk and satin and velvet; and all of them fitted Dorothy exactly.
children.prevalue: In a wardrobe were many green dresses made of silk and satin and velvet and all of them fitted Dorothy exactly

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Make yourself perfectly at home, said the green girl, and if you wish for anything ring the bell.  Oz will send for you tomorrow morning.
children.prevalue: Make yourself perfectly at home said the green girl and if you wish for anything ring the bell Oz will send for you tomorrow morning

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: She left Dorothy alone and went back to the others.  These she also led to rooms, and each one of them found himself lodged in a very pleasant part of the Palace.  Of course this politeness was wasted on the Scarecrow; for when he found himself alone in his room he stood stupidly in one spot, just within the doorway, to wait till morning. It would not rest him to lie down, and he could not close his eyes; so he remained all night staring at a little spider which was weaving its web in a corner of the room, just as if it were not one of the most wonderful rooms in the world.  The Tin Woodman lay down on his bed from force of habit, for he remembered when he was made of flesh; but not being able to sleep, he passed the night moving his joints up and down to make sure they kept in good working order.  The Lion would have preferred a bed of dried leaves in the forest, and did not like being shut up in a room; but he had too much sense to let this worry him, so he sprang upon the bed and rolled himself up like a cat and purred himself asleep in a minute.
children.prevalue: She left Dorothy alone and went back to the others These she also led to rooms and each one of them found himself lodged in a very pleasant part of the Palace Of course this politeness was wasted on the Scarecrow for when he found himself alone in his room he stood stupidly in one spot just within the doorway to wait till morning It would not rest him to lie down and he could not close his eyes so he remained all night staring at a little spider which was weaving its web in a corner of the room just as if it were not one of the most wonderful rooms in the world The Tin Woodman lay down on his bed from force of habit for he remembered when he was made of flesh but not being able to sleep he passed the night moving his joints up and down to make sure they kept in good working order The Lion would have preferred a bed of dried leaves in the forest and did not like being shut up in a room but he had too much sense to let this worry him so he sprang upon the bed and rolled himself up like a cat and purred himself asleep in a minute

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: The next morning, after breakfast, the green maiden came to fetch Dorothy, and she dressed her in one of the prettiest gowns, made of green brocaded satin.  Dorothy put on a green silk apron and tied a green ribbon around Toto's neck, and they started for the Throne Room of the Great Oz.
children.prevalue: The next morning after breakfast the green maiden came to fetch Dorothy and she dressed her in one of the prettiest gowns made of green brocaded satin Dorothy put on a green silk apron and tied a green ribbon around Toto s neck and they started for the Throne Room of the Great Oz

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: First they came to a great hall in which were many ladies and gentlemen of the court, all dressed in rich costumes.  These people had nothing to do but talk to each other, but they always came to wait outside the Throne Room every morning, although they were never permitted to see Oz.  As Dorothy entered they looked at her curiously, and one of them whispered:
children.prevalue: First they came to a great hall in which were many ladies and gentlemen of the court all dressed in rich costumes These people had nothing to do but talk to each other but they always came to wait outside the Throne Room every morning although they were never permitted to see Oz As Dorothy entered they looked at her curiously and one of them whispered

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Are you really going to look upon the face of Oz the Terrible?
children.prevalue: Are you really going to look upon the face of Oz the Terrible

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Of course, answered the girl, if he will see me.
children.prevalue: Of course answered the girl if he will see me

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Oh, he will see you, said the soldier who had taken her message to the Wizard, although he does not like to have people ask to see him. Indeed, at first he was angry and said I should send you back where you came from.  Then he asked me what you looked like, and when I mentioned your silver shoes he was very much interested.  At last I told him about the mark upon your forehead, and he decided he would admit you to his presence.
children.prevalue: Oh he will see you said the soldier who had taken her message to the Wizard although he does not like to have people ask to see him Indeed at first he was angry and said I should send you back where you came from Then he asked me what you looked like and when I mentioned your silver shoes he was very much interested At last I told him about the mark upon your forehead and he decided he would admit you to his presence

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Just then a bell rang, and the green girl said to Dorothy, That is the signal.  You must go into the Throne Room alone.
children.prevalue: Just then a bell rang and the green girl said to Dorothy That is the signal You must go into the Throne Room alone

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: She opened a little door and Dorothy walked boldly through and found herself in a wonderful place.  It was a big, round room with a high arched roof, and the walls and ceiling and floor were covered with large emeralds set closely together.  In the center of the roof was a great light, as bright as the sun, which made the emeralds sparkle in a wonderful manner.
children.prevalue: She opened a little door and Dorothy walked boldly through and found herself in a wonderful place It was a big round room with a high arched roof and the walls and ceiling and floor were covered with large emeralds set closely together In the center of the roof was a great light as bright as the sun which made the emeralds sparkle in a wonderful manner

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: But what interested Dorothy most was the big throne of green marble that stood in the middle of the room.  It was shaped like a chair and sparkled with gems, as did everything else.  In the center of the chair was an enormous Head, without a body to support it or any arms or legs whatever.  There was no hair upon this head, but it had eyes and a nose and mouth, and was much bigger than the head of the biggest giant.
children.prevalue: But what interested Dorothy most was the big throne of green marble that stood in the middle of the room It was shaped like a chair and sparkled with gems as did everything else In the center of the chair was an enormous Head without a body to support it or any arms or legs whatever There was no hair upon this head but it had eyes and a nose and mouth and was much bigger than the head of the biggest giant

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: As Dorothy gazed upon this in wonder and fear, the eyes turned slowly and looked at her sharply and steadily.  Then the mouth moved, and Dorothy heard a voice say:
children.prevalue: As Dorothy gazed upon this in wonder and fear the eyes turned slowly and looked at her sharply and steadily Then the mouth moved and Dorothy heard a voice say

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: I am Oz, the Great and Terrible.  Who are you, and why do you seek me?
children.prevalue: I am Oz the Great and Terrible Who are you and why do you seek me

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: It was not such an awful voice as she had expected to come from the big Head; so she took courage and answered:
children.prevalue: It was not such an awful voice as she had expected to come from the big Head so she took courage and answered

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: I am Dorothy, the Small and Meek.  I have come to you for help.
children.prevalue: I am Dorothy the Small and Meek I have come to you for help

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: The eyes looked at her thoughtfully for a full minute.  Then said the voice:
children.prevalue: The eyes looked at her thoughtfully for a full minute Then said the voice

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Where did you get the silver shoes?
children.prevalue: Where did you get the silver shoes

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: I got them from the Wicked Witch of the East, when my house fell on her and killed her, she replied.
children.prevalue: I got them from the Wicked Witch of the East when my house fell on her and killed her she replied

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Where did you get the mark upon your forehead? continued the voice.
children.prevalue: Where did you get the mark upon your forehead continued the voice

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: That is where the Good Witch of the North kissed me when she bade me good-bye and sent me to you, said the girl.
children.prevalue: That is where the Good Witch of the North kissed me when she bade me good bye and sent me to you said the girl

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Again the eyes looked at her sharply, and they saw she was telling the truth.  Then Oz asked, What do you wish me to do?
children.prevalue: Again the eyes looked at her sharply and they saw she was telling the truth Then Oz asked What do you wish me to do

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Send me back to Kansas, where my Aunt Em and Uncle Henry are, she answered earnestly.  I don't like your country, although it is so beautiful.  And I am sure Aunt Em will be dreadfully worried over my being away so long.
children.prevalue: Send me back to Kansas where my Aunt Em and Uncle Henry are she answered earnestly I don t like your country although it is so beautiful And I am sure Aunt Em will be dreadfully worried over my being away so long

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: The eyes winked three times, and then they turned up to the ceiling and down to the floor and rolled around so queerly that they seemed to see every part of the room.  And at last they looked at Dorothy again.
children.prevalue: The eyes winked three times and then they turned up to the ceiling and down to the floor and rolled around so queerly that they seemed to see every part of the room And at last they looked at Dorothy again

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Why should I do this for you? asked Oz.
children.prevalue: Why should I do this for you asked Oz

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Because you are strong and I am weak; because you are a Great Wizard and I am only a little girl.
children.prevalue: Because you are strong and I am weak because you are a Great Wizard and I am only a little girl

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: But you were strong enough to kill the Wicked Witch of the East, said Oz.
children.prevalue: But you were strong enough to kill the Wicked Witch of the East said Oz

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: That just happened, returned Dorothy simply; I could not help it.
children.prevalue: That just happened returned Dorothy simply I could not help it

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Well, said the Head, I will give you my answer.  You have no right to expect me to send you back to Kansas unless you do something for me in return.  In this country everyone must pay for everything he gets. If you wish me to use my magic power to send you home again you must do something for me first.  Help me and I will help you.
children.prevalue: Well said the Head I will give you my answer You have no right to expect me to send you back to Kansas unless you do something for me in return In this country everyone must pay for everything he gets If you wish me to use my magic power to send you home again you must do something for me first Help me and I will help you

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: What must I do? asked the girl.
children.prevalue: What must I do asked the girl

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Kill the Wicked Witch of the West, answered Oz.
children.prevalue: Kill the Wicked Witch of the West answered Oz

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: But I cannot! exclaimed Dorothy, greatly surprised.
children.prevalue: But I cannot exclaimed Dorothy greatly surprised

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: You killed the Witch of the East and you wear the silver shoes, which bear a powerful charm.  There is now but one Wicked Witch left in all this land, and when you can tell me she is dead I will send you back to Kansas--but not before.
children.prevalue: You killed the Witch of the East and you wear the silver shoes which bear a powerful charm There is now but one Wicked Witch left in all this land and when you can tell me she is dead I will send you back to Kansas but not before

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: The little girl began to weep, she was so much disappointed; and the eyes winked again and looked upon her anxiously, as if the Great Oz felt that she could help him if she would.
children.prevalue: The little girl began to weep she was so much disappointed and the eyes winked again and looked upon her anxiously as if the Great Oz felt that she could help him if she would

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: I never killed anything, willingly, she sobbed.  Even if I wanted to, how could I kill the Wicked Witch?  If you, who are Great and Terrible, cannot kill her yourself, how do you expect me to do it?
children.prevalue: I never killed anything willingly she sobbed Even if I wanted to how could I kill the Wicked Witch If you who are Great and Terrible cannot kill her yourself how do you expect me to do it

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: I do not know, said the Head; but that is my answer, and until the Wicked Witch dies you will not see your uncle and aunt again.  Remember that the Witch is Wicked--tremendously Wicked--and ought to be killed. Now go, and do not ask to see me again until you have done your task.
children.prevalue: I do not know said the Head but that is my answer and until the Wicked Witch dies you will not see your uncle and aunt again Remember that the Witch is Wicked tremendously Wicked and ought to be killed Now go and do not ask to see me again until you have done your task

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Sorrowfully Dorothy left the Throne Room and went back where the Lion and the Scarecrow and the Tin Woodman were waiting to hear what Oz had said to her.  There is no hope for me, she said sadly, for Oz will not send me home until I have killed the Wicked Witch of the West; and that I can never do.
children.prevalue: Sorrowfully Dorothy left the Throne Room and went back where the Lion and the Scarecrow and the Tin Woodman were waiting to hear what Oz had said to her There is no hope for me she said sadly for Oz will not send me home until I have killed the Wicked Witch of the West and that I can never do

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Her friends were sorry, but could do nothing to help her; so Dorothy went to her own room and lay down on the bed and cried herself to sleep.
children.prevalue: Her friends were sorry but could do nothing to help her so Dorothy went to her own room and lay down on the bed and cried herself to sleep

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: The next morning the soldier with the green whiskers came to the Scarecrow and said:
children.prevalue: The next morning the soldier with the green whiskers came to the Scarecrow and said

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: Come with me, for Oz has sent for you.
children.prevalue: Come with me for Oz has sent for you

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: So the Scarecrow followed him and was admitted into the great Throne Room, where he saw, sitting in the emerald throne, a most lovely Lady. She was dressed in green silk gauze and wore upon her flowing green locks a crown of jewels.  Growing from her shoulders were wings, gorgeous in color and so light that they fluttered if the slightest breath of air reached them.
children.prevalue: So the Scarecrow followed him and was admitted into the great Throne Room where he saw sitting in the emerald throne a most lovely Lady She was dressed in green silk gauze and wore upon her flowing green locks a crown of jewels Growing from her shoulders were wings gorgeous in color and so light that they fluttered if the slightest breath of air reached them

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: When the Scarecrow had bowed, as prettily as his straw stuffing would let him, before this beautiful creature, she looked upon him sweetly, and said:
children.prevalue: When the Scarecrow had bowed as prettily as his straw stuffing would let him before this beautiful creature she looked upon him sweetly and said

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: I am Oz, the Great and Terrible.  Who are you, and why do you seek me?
children.prevalue: I am Oz the Great and Terrible Who are you and why do you seek me

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Now the Scarecrow, who had expected to see the great Head Dorothy had told him of, was much astonished; but he answered her bravely.
children.prevalue: Now the Scarecrow who had expected to see the great Head Dorothy had told him of was much astonished but he answered her bravely

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: I am only a Scarecrow, stuffed with straw.  Therefore I have no brains, and I come to you praying that you will put brains in my head instead of straw, so that I may become as much a man as any other in your dominions.
children.prevalue: I am only a Scarecrow stuffed with straw Therefore I have no brains and I come to you praying that you will put brains in my head instead of straw so that I may become as much a man as any other in your dominions

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Why should I do this for you? asked the Lady.
children.prevalue: Why should I do this for you asked the Lady

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Because you are wise and powerful, and no one else can help me, answered the Scarecrow.
children.prevalue: Because you are wise and powerful and no one else can help me answered the Scarecrow

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: I never grant favors without some return, said Oz; but this much I will promise.  If you will kill for me the Wicked Witch of the West, I will bestow upon you a great many brains, and such good brains that you will be the wisest man in all the Land of Oz.
children.prevalue: I never grant favors without some return said Oz but this much I will promise If you will kill for me the Wicked Witch of the West I will bestow upon you a great many brains and such good brains that you will be the wisest man in all the Land of Oz

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: I thought you asked Dorothy to kill the Witch, said the Scarecrow, in surprise.
children.prevalue: I thought you asked Dorothy to kill the Witch said the Scarecrow in surprise

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: So I did.  I don't care who kills her.  But until she is dead I will not grant your wish.  Now go, and do not seek me again until you have earned the brains you so greatly desire.
children.prevalue: So I did I don t care who kills her But until she is dead I will not grant your wish Now go and do not seek me again until you have earned the brains you so greatly desire

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: The Scarecrow went sorrowfully back to his friends and told them what Oz had said; and Dorothy was surprised to find that the Great Wizard was not a Head, as she had seen him, but a lovely Lady.
children.prevalue: The Scarecrow went sorrowfully back to his friends and told them what Oz had said and Dorothy was surprised to find that the Great Wizard was not a Head as she had seen him but a lovely Lady

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: All the same, said the Scarecrow, she needs a heart as much as the Tin Woodman.
children.prevalue: All the same said the Scarecrow she needs a heart as much as the Tin Woodman

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: On the next morning the soldier with the green whiskers came to the Tin Woodman and said:
children.prevalue: On the next morning the soldier with the green whiskers came to the Tin Woodman and said

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Oz has sent for you.  Follow me.
children.prevalue: Oz has sent for you Follow me

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: So the Tin Woodman followed him and came to the great Throne Room.  He did not know whether he would find Oz a lovely Lady or a Head, but he hoped it would be the lovely Lady.  For, he said to himself, if it is the head, I am sure I shall not be given a heart, since a head has no heart of its own and therefore cannot feel for me.  But if it is the lovely Lady I shall beg hard for a heart, for all ladies are themselves said to be kindly hearted.
children.prevalue: So the Tin Woodman followed him and came to the great Throne Room He did not know whether he would find Oz a lovely Lady or a Head but he hoped it would be the lovely Lady For he said to himself if it is the head I am sure I shall not be given a heart since a head has no heart of its own and therefore cannot feel for me But if it is the lovely Lady I shall beg hard for a heart for all ladies are themselves said to be kindly hearted

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: But when the Woodman entered the great Throne Room he saw neither the Head nor the Lady, for Oz had taken the shape of a most terrible Beast. It was nearly as big as an elephant, and the green throne seemed hardly strong enough to hold its weight.  The Beast had a head like that of a rhinoceros, only there were five eyes in its face.  There were five long arms growing out of its body, and it also had five long, slim legs.  Thick, woolly hair covered every part of it, and a more dreadful-looking monster could not be imagined.  It was fortunate the Tin Woodman had no heart at that moment, for it would have beat loud and fast from terror.  But being only tin, the Woodman was not at all afraid, although he was much disappointed.
children.prevalue: But when the Woodman entered the great Throne Room he saw neither the Head nor the Lady for Oz had taken the shape of a most terrible Beast It was nearly as big as an elephant and the green throne seemed hardly strong enough to hold its weight The Beast had a head like that of a rhinoceros only there were five eyes in its face There were five long arms growing out of its body and it also had five long slim legs Thick woolly hair covered every part of it and a more dreadful looking monster could not be imagined It was fortunate the Tin Woodman had no heart at that moment for it would have beat loud and fast from terror But being only tin the Woodman was not at all afraid although he was much disappointed

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: I am Oz, the Great and Terrible, spoke the Beast, in a voice that was one great roar.  Who are you, and why do you seek me?
children.prevalue: I am Oz the Great and Terrible spoke the Beast in a voice that was one great roar Who are you and why do you seek me

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: I am a Woodman, and made of tin.  Therefore I have no heart, and cannot love.  I pray you to give me a heart that I may be as other men are.
children.prevalue: I am a Woodman and made of tin Therefore I have no heart and cannot love I pray you to give me a heart that I may be as other men are

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: Why should I do this? demanded the Beast.
children.prevalue: Why should I do this demanded the Beast

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: Because I ask it, and you alone can grant my request, answered the Woodman.
children.prevalue: Because I ask it and you alone can grant my request answered the Woodman

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: Oz gave a low growl at this, but said, gruffly: If you indeed desire a heart, you must earn it.
children.prevalue: Oz gave a low growl at this but said gruffly If you indeed desire a heart you must earn it

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: How? asked the Woodman.
children.prevalue: How asked the Woodman

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Help Dorothy to kill the Wicked Witch of the West, replied the Beast. When the Witch is dead, come to me, and I will then give you the biggest and kindest and most loving heart in all the Land of Oz.
children.prevalue: Help Dorothy to kill the Wicked Witch of the West replied the Beast When the Witch is dead come to me and I will then give you the biggest and kindest and most loving heart in all the Land of Oz

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: So the Tin Woodman was forced to return sorrowfully to his friends and tell them of the terrible Beast he had seen.  They all wondered greatly at the many forms the Great Wizard could take upon himself, and the Lion said:
children.prevalue: So the Tin Woodman was forced to return sorrowfully to his friends and tell them of the terrible Beast he had seen They all wondered greatly at the many forms the Great Wizard could take upon himself and the Lion said

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: If he is a Beast when I go to see him, I shall roar my loudest, and so frighten him that he will grant all I ask.  And if he is the lovely Lady, I shall pretend to spring upon her, and so compel her to do my bidding.  And if he is the great Head, he will be at my mercy; for I will roll this head all about the room until he promises to give us what we desire.  So be of good cheer, my friends, for all will yet be well.
children.prevalue: If he is a Beast when I go to see him I shall roar my loudest and so frighten him that he will grant all I ask And if he is the lovely Lady I shall pretend to spring upon her and so compel her to do my bidding And if he is the great Head he will be at my mercy for I will roll this head all about the room until he promises to give us what we desire So be of good cheer my friends for all will yet be well

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: The next morning the soldier with the green whiskers led the Lion to the great Throne Room and bade him enter the presence of Oz.
children.prevalue: The next morning the soldier with the green whiskers led the Lion to the great Throne Room and bade him enter the presence of Oz

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: The Lion at once passed through the door, and glancing around saw, to his surprise, that before the throne was a Ball of Fire, so fierce and glowing he could scarcely bear to gaze upon it.  His first thought was that Oz had by accident caught on fire and was burning up; but when he tried to go nearer, the heat was so intense that it singed his whiskers, and he crept back tremblingly to a spot nearer the door.
children.prevalue: The Lion at once passed through the door and glancing around saw to his surprise that before the throne was a Ball of Fire so fierce and glowing he could scarcely bear to gaze upon it His first thought was that Oz had by accident caught on fire and was burning up but when he tried to go nearer the heat was so intense that it singed his whiskers and he crept back tremblingly to a spot nearer the door

children.name: Paragraph_81
