children.value: Then a low, quiet voice came from the Ball of Fire, and these were the words it spoke:
children.prevalue: Then a low quiet voice came from the Ball of Fire and these were the words it spoke

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: I am Oz, the Great and Terrible.  Who are you, and why do you seek me?
children.prevalue: I am Oz the Great and Terrible Who are you and why do you seek me

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: And the Lion answered, I am a Cowardly Lion, afraid of everything.  I came to you to beg that you give me courage, so that in reality I may become the King of Beasts, as men call me.
children.prevalue: And the Lion answered I am a Cowardly Lion afraid of everything I came to you to beg that you give me courage so that in reality I may become the King of Beasts as men call me

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Why should I give you courage? demanded Oz.
children.prevalue: Why should I give you courage demanded Oz

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Because of all Wizards you are the greatest, and alone have power to grant my request, answered the Lion.
children.prevalue: Because of all Wizards you are the greatest and alone have power to grant my request answered the Lion

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: The Ball of Fire burned fiercely for a time, and the voice said, Bring me proof that the Wicked Witch is dead, and that moment I will give you courage.  But as long as the Witch lives, you must remain a coward.
children.prevalue: The Ball of Fire burned fiercely for a time and the voice said Bring me proof that the Wicked Witch is dead and that moment I will give you courage But as long as the Witch lives you must remain a coward

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: The Lion was angry at this speech, but could say nothing in reply, and while he stood silently gazing at the Ball of Fire it became so furiously hot that he turned tail and rushed from the room.  He was glad to find his friends waiting for him, and told them of his terrible interview with the Wizard.
children.prevalue: The Lion was angry at this speech but could say nothing in reply and while he stood silently gazing at the Ball of Fire it became so furiously hot that he turned tail and rushed from the room He was glad to find his friends waiting for him and told them of his terrible interview with the Wizard

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: What shall we do now? asked Dorothy sadly.
children.prevalue: What shall we do now asked Dorothy sadly

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: There is only one thing we can do, returned the Lion, and that is to go to the land of the Winkies, seek out the Wicked Witch, and destroy her.
children.prevalue: There is only one thing we can do returned the Lion and that is to go to the land of the Winkies seek out the Wicked Witch and destroy her

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: But suppose we cannot? said the girl.
children.prevalue: But suppose we cannot said the girl

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: Then I shall never have courage, declared the Lion.
children.prevalue: Then I shall never have courage declared the Lion

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: And I shall never have brains, added the Scarecrow.
children.prevalue: And I shall never have brains added the Scarecrow

children.name: Paragraph_93
children.value: And I shall never have a heart, spoke the Tin Woodman.
children.prevalue: And I shall never have a heart spoke the Tin Woodman

children.name: Paragraph_94
children.value: And I shall never see Aunt Em and Uncle Henry, said Dorothy, beginning to cry.
children.prevalue: And I shall never see Aunt Em and Uncle Henry said Dorothy beginning to cry

children.name: Paragraph_95
children.value: Be careful! cried the green girl.  The tears will fall on your green silk gown and spot it.
children.prevalue: Be careful cried the green girl The tears will fall on your green silk gown and spot it

children.name: Paragraph_96
children.value: So Dorothy dried her eyes and said, I suppose we must try it; but I am sure I do not want to kill anybody, even to see Aunt Em again.
children.prevalue: So Dorothy dried her eyes and said I suppose we must try it but I am sure I do not want to kill anybody even to see Aunt Em again

children.name: Paragraph_97
children.value: I will go with you; but I'm too much of a coward to kill the Witch, said the Lion.
children.prevalue: I will go with you but I m too much of a coward to kill the Witch said the Lion

children.name: Paragraph_98
children.value: I will go too, declared the Scarecrow; but I shall not be of much help to you, I am such a fool.
children.prevalue: I will go too declared the Scarecrow but I shall not be of much help to you I am such a fool

children.name: Paragraph_99
children.value: I haven't the heart to harm even a Witch, remarked the Tin Woodman; but if you go I certainly shall go with you.
children.prevalue: I haven t the heart to harm even a Witch remarked the Tin Woodman but if you go I certainly shall go with you

children.name: Paragraph_100
children.value: Therefore it was decided to start upon their journey the next morning, and the Woodman sharpened his axe on a green grindstone and had all his joints properly oiled.  The Scarecrow stuffed himself with fresh straw and Dorothy put new paint on his eyes that he might see better.  The green girl, who was very kind to them, filled Dorothy's basket with good things to eat, and fastened a little bell around Toto's neck with a green ribbon.
children.prevalue: Therefore it was decided to start upon their journey the next morning and the Woodman sharpened his axe on a green grindstone and had all his joints properly oiled The Scarecrow stuffed himself with fresh straw and Dorothy put new paint on his eyes that he might see better The green girl who was very kind to them filled Dorothy s basket with good things to eat and fastened a little bell around Toto s neck with a green ribbon

children.name: Paragraph_101
children.value: They went to bed quite early and slept soundly until daylight, when they were awakened by the crowing of a green cock that lived in the back yard of the Palace, and the cackling of a hen that had laid a green egg.
children.prevalue: They went to bed quite early and slept soundly until daylight when they were awakened by the crowing of a green cock that lived in the back yard of the Palace and the cackling of a hen that had laid a green egg

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The soldier with the green whiskers led them through the streets of the Emerald City until they reached the room where the Guardian of the Gates lived.  This officer unlocked their spectacles to put them back in his great box, and then he politely opened the gate for our friends.
children.prevalue: The soldier with the green whiskers led them through the streets of the Emerald City until they reached the room where the Guardian of the Gates lived This officer unlocked their spectacles to put them back in his great box and then he politely opened the gate for our friends

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Which road leads to the Wicked Witch of the West? asked Dorothy.
children.prevalue: Which road leads to the Wicked Witch of the West asked Dorothy

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: There is no road, answered the Guardian of the Gates.  No one ever wishes to go that way.
children.prevalue: There is no road answered the Guardian of the Gates No one ever wishes to go that way

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: How, then, are we to find her? inquired the girl.
children.prevalue: How then are we to find her inquired the girl

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: That will be easy, replied the man, for when she knows you are in the country of the Winkies she will find you, and make you all her slaves.
children.prevalue: That will be easy replied the man for when she knows you are in the country of the Winkies she will find you and make you all her slaves

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Perhaps not, said the Scarecrow, for we mean to destroy her.
children.prevalue: Perhaps not said the Scarecrow for we mean to destroy her

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Oh, that is different, said the Guardian of the Gates.  No one has ever destroyed her before, so I naturally thought she would make slaves of you, as she has of the rest.  But take care; for she is wicked and fierce, and may not allow you to destroy her.  Keep to the West, where the sun sets, and you cannot fail to find her.
children.prevalue: Oh that is different said the Guardian of the Gates No one has ever destroyed her before so I naturally thought she would make slaves of you as she has of the rest But take care for she is wicked and fierce and may not allow you to destroy her Keep to the West where the sun sets and you cannot fail to find her

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: They thanked him and bade him good-bye, and turned toward the West, walking over fields of soft grass dotted here and there with daisies and buttercups.  Dorothy still wore the pretty silk dress she had put on in the palace, but now, to her surprise, she found it was no longer green, but pure white.  The ribbon around Toto's neck had also lost its green color and was as white as Dorothy's dress.
children.prevalue: They thanked him and bade him good bye and turned toward the West walking over fields of soft grass dotted here and there with daisies and buttercups Dorothy still wore the pretty silk dress she had put on in the palace but now to her surprise she found it was no longer green but pure white The ribbon around Toto s neck had also lost its green color and was as white as Dorothy s dress

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: The Emerald City was soon left far behind.  As they advanced the ground became rougher and hillier, for there were no farms nor houses in this country of the West, and the ground was untilled.
children.prevalue: The Emerald City was soon left far behind As they advanced the ground became rougher and hillier for there were no farms nor houses in this country of the West and the ground was untilled

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: In the afternoon the sun shone hot in their faces, for there were no trees to offer them shade; so that before night Dorothy and Toto and the Lion were tired, and lay down upon the grass and fell asleep, with the Woodman and the Scarecrow keeping watch.
children.prevalue: In the afternoon the sun shone hot in their faces for there were no trees to offer them shade so that before night Dorothy and Toto and the Lion were tired and lay down upon the grass and fell asleep with the Woodman and the Scarecrow keeping watch

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Now the Wicked Witch of the West had but one eye, yet that was as powerful as a telescope, and could see everywhere.  So, as she sat in the door of her castle, she happened to look around and saw Dorothy lying asleep, with her friends all about her.  They were a long distance off, but the Wicked Witch was angry to find them in her country; so she blew upon a silver whistle that hung around her neck.
children.prevalue: Now the Wicked Witch of the West had but one eye yet that was as powerful as a telescope and could see everywhere So as she sat in the door of her castle she happened to look around and saw Dorothy lying asleep with her friends all about her They were a long distance off but the Wicked Witch was angry to find them in her country so she blew upon a silver whistle that hung around her neck

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: At once there came running to her from all directions a pack of great wolves.  They had long legs and fierce eyes and sharp teeth.
children.prevalue: At once there came running to her from all directions a pack of great wolves They had long legs and fierce eyes and sharp teeth

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Go to those people, said the Witch, and tear them to pieces.
children.prevalue: Go to those people said the Witch and tear them to pieces

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Are you not going to make them your slaves? asked the leader of the wolves.
children.prevalue: Are you not going to make them your slaves asked the leader of the wolves

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: No, she answered, one is of tin, and one of straw; one is a girl and another a Lion.  None of them is fit to work, so you may tear them into small pieces.
children.prevalue: No she answered one is of tin and one of straw one is a girl and another a Lion None of them is fit to work so you may tear them into small pieces

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Very well, said the wolf, and he dashed away at full speed, followed by the others.
children.prevalue: Very well said the wolf and he dashed away at full speed followed by the others

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: It was lucky the Scarecrow and the Woodman were wide awake and heard the wolves coming.
children.prevalue: It was lucky the Scarecrow and the Woodman were wide awake and heard the wolves coming

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: This is my fight, said the Woodman, so get behind me and I will meet them as they come.
children.prevalue: This is my fight said the Woodman so get behind me and I will meet them as they come

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: He seized his axe, which he had made very sharp, and as the leader of the wolves came on the Tin Woodman swung his arm and chopped the wolf's head from its body, so that it immediately died.  As soon as he could raise his axe another wolf came up, and he also fell under the sharp edge of the Tin Woodman's weapon.  There were forty wolves, and forty times a wolf was killed, so that at last they all lay dead in a heap before the Woodman.
children.prevalue: He seized his axe which he had made very sharp and as the leader of the wolves came on the Tin Woodman swung his arm and chopped the wolf s head from its body so that it immediately died As soon as he could raise his axe another wolf came up and he also fell under the sharp edge of the Tin Woodman s weapon There were forty wolves and forty times a wolf was killed so that at last they all lay dead in a heap before the Woodman

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Then he put down his axe and sat beside the Scarecrow, who said, It was a good fight, friend.
children.prevalue: Then he put down his axe and sat beside the Scarecrow who said It was a good fight friend

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: They waited until Dorothy awoke the next morning.  The little girl was quite frightened when she saw the great pile of shaggy wolves, but the Tin Woodman told her all.  She thanked him for saving them and sat down to breakfast, after which they started again upon their journey.
children.prevalue: They waited until Dorothy awoke the next morning The little girl was quite frightened when she saw the great pile of shaggy wolves but the Tin Woodman told her all She thanked him for saving them and sat down to breakfast after which they started again upon their journey

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Now this same morning the Wicked Witch came to the door of her castle and looked out with her one eye that could see far off.  She saw all her wolves lying dead, and the strangers still traveling through her country.  This made her angrier than before, and she blew her silver whistle twice.
children.prevalue: Now this same morning the Wicked Witch came to the door of her castle and looked out with her one eye that could see far off She saw all her wolves lying dead and the strangers still traveling through her country This made her angrier than before and she blew her silver whistle twice

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Straightway a great flock of wild crows came flying toward her, enough to darken the sky.
children.prevalue: Straightway a great flock of wild crows came flying toward her enough to darken the sky

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: And the Wicked Witch said to the King Crow, Fly at once to the strangers; peck out their eyes and tear them to pieces.
children.prevalue: And the Wicked Witch said to the King Crow Fly at once to the strangers peck out their eyes and tear them to pieces

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: The wild crows flew in one great flock toward Dorothy and her companions.  When the little girl saw them coming she was afraid.
children.prevalue: The wild crows flew in one great flock toward Dorothy and her companions When the little girl saw them coming she was afraid

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: But the Scarecrow said, This is my battle, so lie down beside me and you will not be harmed.
children.prevalue: But the Scarecrow said This is my battle so lie down beside me and you will not be harmed

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: So they all lay upon the ground except the Scarecrow, and he stood up and stretched out his arms.  And when the crows saw him they were frightened, as these birds always are by scarecrows, and did not dare to come any nearer.  But the King Crow said:
children.prevalue: So they all lay upon the ground except the Scarecrow and he stood up and stretched out his arms And when the crows saw him they were frightened as these birds always are by scarecrows and did not dare to come any nearer But the King Crow said

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: It is only a stuffed man.  I will peck his eyes out.
children.prevalue: It is only a stuffed man I will peck his eyes out

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: The King Crow flew at the Scarecrow, who caught it by the head and twisted its neck until it died.  And then another crow flew at him, and the Scarecrow twisted its neck also.  There were forty crows, and forty times the Scarecrow twisted a neck, until at last all were lying dead beside him.  Then he called to his companions to rise, and again they went upon their journey.
children.prevalue: The King Crow flew at the Scarecrow who caught it by the head and twisted its neck until it died And then another crow flew at him and the Scarecrow twisted its neck also There were forty crows and forty times the Scarecrow twisted a neck until at last all were lying dead beside him Then he called to his companions to rise and again they went upon their journey

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: When the Wicked Witch looked out again and saw all her crows lying in a heap, she got into a terrible rage, and blew three times upon her silver whistle.
children.prevalue: When the Wicked Witch looked out again and saw all her crows lying in a heap she got into a terrible rage and blew three times upon her silver whistle

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Forthwith there was heard a great buzzing in the air, and a swarm of black bees came flying toward her.
children.prevalue: Forthwith there was heard a great buzzing in the air and a swarm of black bees came flying toward her

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Go to the strangers and sting them to death! commanded the Witch, and the bees turned and flew rapidly until they came to where Dorothy and her friends were walking.  But the Woodman had seen them coming, and the Scarecrow had decided what to do.
children.prevalue: Go to the strangers and sting them to death commanded the Witch and the bees turned and flew rapidly until they came to where Dorothy and her friends were walking But the Woodman had seen them coming and the Scarecrow had decided what to do

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Take out my straw and scatter it over the little girl and the dog and the Lion, he said to the Woodman, and the bees cannot sting them. This the Woodman did, and as Dorothy lay close beside the Lion and held Toto in her arms, the straw covered them entirely.
children.prevalue: Take out my straw and scatter it over the little girl and the dog and the Lion he said to the Woodman and the bees cannot sting them This the Woodman did and as Dorothy lay close beside the Lion and held Toto in her arms the straw covered them entirely

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: The bees came and found no one but the Woodman to sting, so they flew at him and broke off all their stings against the tin, without hurting the Woodman at all.  And as bees cannot live when their stings are broken that was the end of the black bees, and they lay scattered thick about the Woodman, like little heaps of fine coal.
children.prevalue: The bees came and found no one but the Woodman to sting so they flew at him and broke off all their stings against the tin without hurting the Woodman at all And as bees cannot live when their stings are broken that was the end of the black bees and they lay scattered thick about the Woodman like little heaps of fine coal

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Then Dorothy and the Lion got up, and the girl helped the Tin Woodman put the straw back into the Scarecrow again, until he was as good as ever.  So they started upon their journey once more.
children.prevalue: Then Dorothy and the Lion got up and the girl helped the Tin Woodman put the straw back into the Scarecrow again until he was as good as ever So they started upon their journey once more

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: The Wicked Witch was so angry when she saw her black bees in little heaps like fine coal that she stamped her foot and tore her hair and gnashed her teeth.  And then she called a dozen of her slaves, who were the Winkies, and gave them sharp spears, telling them to go to the strangers and destroy them.
children.prevalue: The Wicked Witch was so angry when she saw her black bees in little heaps like fine coal that she stamped her foot and tore her hair and gnashed her teeth And then she called a dozen of her slaves who were the Winkies and gave them sharp spears telling them to go to the strangers and destroy them

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: The Winkies were not a brave people, but they had to do as they were told.  So they marched away until they came near to Dorothy.  Then the Lion gave a great roar and sprang towards them, and the poor Winkies were so frightened that they ran back as fast as they could.
children.prevalue: The Winkies were not a brave people but they had to do as they were told So they marched away until they came near to Dorothy Then the Lion gave a great roar and sprang towards them and the poor Winkies were so frightened that they ran back as fast as they could

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: When they returned to the castle the Wicked Witch beat them well with a strap, and sent them back to their work, after which she sat down to think what she should do next.  She could not understand how all her plans to destroy these strangers had failed; but she was a powerful Witch, as well as a wicked one, and she soon made up her mind how to act.
children.prevalue: When they returned to the castle the Wicked Witch beat them well with a strap and sent them back to their work after which she sat down to think what she should do next She could not understand how all her plans to destroy these strangers had failed but she was a powerful Witch as well as a wicked one and she soon made up her mind how to act

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: There was, in her cupboard, a Golden Cap, with a circle of diamonds and rubies running round it.  This Golden Cap had a charm.  Whoever owned it could call three times upon the Winged Monkeys, who would obey any order they were given.  But no person could command these strange creatures more than three times.  Twice already the Wicked Witch had used the charm of the Cap.  Once was when she had made the Winkies her slaves, and set herself to rule over their country.  The Winged Monkeys had helped her do this.  The second time was when she had fought against the Great Oz himself, and driven him out of the land of the West.  The Winged Monkeys had also helped her in doing this.  Only once more could she use this Golden Cap, for which reason she did not like to do so until all her other powers were exhausted.  But now that her fierce wolves and her wild crows and her stinging bees were gone, and her slaves had been scared away by the Cowardly Lion, she saw there was only one way left to destroy Dorothy and her friends.
children.prevalue: There was in her cupboard a Golden Cap with a circle of diamonds and rubies running round it This Golden Cap had a charm Whoever owned it could call three times upon the Winged Monkeys who would obey any order they were given But no person could command these strange creatures more than three times Twice already the Wicked Witch had used the charm of the Cap Once was when she had made the Winkies her slaves and set herself to rule over their country The Winged Monkeys had helped her do this The second time was when she had fought against the Great Oz himself and driven him out of the land of the West The Winged Monkeys had also helped her in doing this Only once more could she use this Golden Cap for which reason she did not like to do so until all her other powers were exhausted But now that her fierce wolves and her wild crows and her stinging bees were gone and her slaves had been scared away by the Cowardly Lion she saw there was only one way left to destroy Dorothy and her friends

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: So the Wicked Witch took the Golden Cap from her cupboard and placed it upon her head.  Then she stood upon her left foot and said slowly:
children.prevalue: So the Wicked Witch took the Golden Cap from her cupboard and placed it upon her head Then she stood upon her left foot and said slowly

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Ep-pe, pep-pe, kak-ke!
children.prevalue: Ep pe pep pe kak ke

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Next she stood upon her right foot and said:
children.prevalue: Next she stood upon her right foot and said

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Hil-lo, hol-lo, hel-lo!
children.prevalue: Hil lo hol lo hel lo

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: After this she stood upon both feet and cried in a loud voice:
children.prevalue: After this she stood upon both feet and cried in a loud voice

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Ziz-zy, zuz-zy, zik!
children.prevalue: Ziz zy zuz zy zik

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Now the charm began to work.  The sky was darkened, and a low rumbling sound was heard in the air.  There was a rushing of many wings, a great chattering and laughing, and the sun came out of the dark sky to show the Wicked Witch surrounded by a crowd of monkeys, each with a pair of immense and powerful wings on his shoulders.
children.prevalue: Now the charm began to work The sky was darkened and a low rumbling sound was heard in the air There was a rushing of many wings a great chattering and laughing and the sun came out of the dark sky to show the Wicked Witch surrounded by a crowd of monkeys each with a pair of immense and powerful wings on his shoulders

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: One, much bigger than the others, seemed to be their leader.  He flew close to the Witch and said, You have called us for the third and last time.  What do you command?
children.prevalue: One much bigger than the others seemed to be their leader He flew close to the Witch and said You have called us for the third and last time What do you command

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Go to the strangers who are within my land and destroy them all except the Lion, said the Wicked Witch.  Bring that beast to me, for I have a mind to harness him like a horse, and make him work.
children.prevalue: Go to the strangers who are within my land and destroy them all except the Lion said the Wicked Witch Bring that beast to me for I have a mind to harness him like a horse and make him work

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Your commands shall be obeyed, said the leader.  Then, with a great deal of chattering and noise, the Winged Monkeys flew away to the place where Dorothy and her friends were walking.
children.prevalue: Your commands shall be obeyed said the leader Then with a great deal of chattering and noise the Winged Monkeys flew away to the place where Dorothy and her friends were walking

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: Some of the Monkeys seized the Tin Woodman and carried him through the air until they were over a country thickly covered with sharp rocks. Here they dropped the poor Woodman, who fell a great distance to the rocks, where he lay so battered and dented that he could neither move nor groan.
children.prevalue: Some of the Monkeys seized the Tin Woodman and carried him through the air until they were over a country thickly covered with sharp rocks Here they dropped the poor Woodman who fell a great distance to the rocks where he lay so battered and dented that he could neither move nor groan

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Others of the Monkeys caught the Scarecrow, and with their long fingers pulled all of the straw out of his clothes and head.  They made his hat and boots and clothes into a small bundle and threw it into the top branches of a tall tree.
children.prevalue: Others of the Monkeys caught the Scarecrow and with their long fingers pulled all of the straw out of his clothes and head They made his hat and boots and clothes into a small bundle and threw it into the top branches of a tall tree

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: The remaining Monkeys threw pieces of stout rope around the Lion and wound many coils about his body and head and legs, until he was unable to bite or scratch or struggle in any way.  Then they lifted him up and flew away with him to the Witch's castle, where he was placed in a small yard with a high iron fence around it, so that he could not escape.
children.prevalue: The remaining Monkeys threw pieces of stout rope around the Lion and wound many coils about his body and head and legs until he was unable to bite or scratch or struggle in any way Then they lifted him up and flew away with him to the Witch s castle where he was placed in a small yard with a high iron fence around it so that he could not escape

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: But Dorothy they did not harm at all.  She stood, with Toto in her arms, watching the sad fate of her comrades and thinking it would soon be her turn.  The leader of the Winged Monkeys flew up to her, his long, hairy arms stretched out and his ugly face grinning terribly; but he saw the mark of the Good Witch's kiss upon her forehead and stopped short, motioning the others not to touch her.
children.prevalue: But Dorothy they did not harm at all She stood with Toto in her arms watching the sad fate of her comrades and thinking it would soon be her turn The leader of the Winged Monkeys flew up to her his long hairy arms stretched out and his ugly face grinning terribly but he saw the mark of the Good Witch s kiss upon her forehead and stopped short motioning the others not to touch her

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: We dare not harm this little girl, he said to them, for she is protected by the Power of Good, and that is greater than the Power of Evil.  All we can do is to carry her to the castle of the Wicked Witch and leave her there.
children.prevalue: We dare not harm this little girl he said to them for she is protected by the Power of Good and that is greater than the Power of Evil All we can do is to carry her to the castle of the Wicked Witch and leave her there

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: So, carefully and gently, they lifted Dorothy in their arms and carried her swiftly through the air until they came to the castle, where they set her down upon the front doorstep.  Then the leader said to the Witch:
children.prevalue: So carefully and gently they lifted Dorothy in their arms and carried her swiftly through the air until they came to the castle where they set her down upon the front doorstep Then the leader said to the Witch

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: We have obeyed you as far as we were able.  The Tin Woodman and the Scarecrow are destroyed, and the Lion is tied up in your yard.  The little girl we dare not harm, nor the dog she carries in her arms. Your power over our band is now ended, and you will never see us again.
children.prevalue: We have obeyed you as far as we were able The Tin Woodman and the Scarecrow are destroyed and the Lion is tied up in your yard The little girl we dare not harm nor the dog she carries in her arms Your power over our band is now ended and you will never see us again

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: Then all the Winged Monkeys, with much laughing and chattering and noise, flew into the air and were soon out of sight.
children.prevalue: Then all the Winged Monkeys with much laughing and chattering and noise flew into the air and were soon out of sight

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: The Wicked Witch was both surprised and worried when she saw the mark on Dorothy's forehead, for she knew well that neither the Winged Monkeys nor she, herself, dare hurt the girl in any way.  She looked down at Dorothy's feet, and seeing the Silver Shoes, began to tremble with fear, for she knew what a powerful charm belonged to them.  At first the Witch was tempted to run away from Dorothy; but she happened to look into the child's eyes and saw how simple the soul behind them was, and that the little girl did not know of the wonderful power the Silver Shoes gave her.  So the Wicked Witch laughed to herself, and thought, I can still make her my slave, for she does not know how to use her power. Then she said to Dorothy, harshly and severely:
children.prevalue: The Wicked Witch was both surprised and worried when she saw the mark on Dorothy s forehead for she knew well that neither the Winged Monkeys nor she herself dare hurt the girl in any way She looked down at Dorothy s feet and seeing the Silver Shoes began to tremble with fear for she knew what a powerful charm belonged to them At first the Witch was tempted to run away from Dorothy but she happened to look into the child s eyes and saw how simple the soul behind them was and that the little girl did not know of the wonderful power the Silver Shoes gave her So the Wicked Witch laughed to herself and thought I can still make her my slave for she does not know how to use her power Then she said to Dorothy harshly and severely

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Come with me; and see that you mind everything I tell you, for if you do not I will make an end of you, as I did of the Tin Woodman and the Scarecrow.
children.prevalue: Come with me and see that you mind everything I tell you for if you do not I will make an end of you as I did of the Tin Woodman and the Scarecrow

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: Dorothy followed her through many of the beautiful rooms in her castle until they came to the kitchen, where the Witch bade her clean the pots and kettles and sweep the floor and keep the fire fed with wood.
children.prevalue: Dorothy followed her through many of the beautiful rooms in her castle until they came to the kitchen where the Witch bade her clean the pots and kettles and sweep the floor and keep the fire fed with wood

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: Dorothy went to work meekly, with her mind made up to work as hard as she could; for she was glad the Wicked Witch had decided not to kill her.
children.prevalue: Dorothy went to work meekly with her mind made up to work as hard as she could for she was glad the Wicked Witch had decided not to kill her

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: With Dorothy hard at work, the Witch thought she would go into the courtyard and harness the Cowardly Lion like a horse; it would amuse her, she was sure, to make him draw her chariot whenever she wished to go to drive.  But as she opened the gate the Lion gave a loud roar and bounded at her so fiercely that the Witch was afraid, and ran out and shut the gate again.
children.prevalue: With Dorothy hard at work the Witch thought she would go into the courtyard and harness the Cowardly Lion like a horse it would amuse her she was sure to make him draw her chariot whenever she wished to go to drive But as she opened the gate the Lion gave a loud roar and bounded at her so fiercely that the Witch was afraid and ran out and shut the gate again

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: If I cannot harness you, said the Witch to the Lion, speaking through the bars of the gate, I can starve you.  You shall have nothing to eat until you do as I wish.
children.prevalue: If I cannot harness you said the Witch to the Lion speaking through the bars of the gate I can starve you You shall have nothing to eat until you do as I wish

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: So after that she took no food to the imprisoned Lion; but every day she came to the gate at noon and asked, Are you ready to be harnessed like a horse?
children.prevalue: So after that she took no food to the imprisoned Lion but every day she came to the gate at noon and asked Are you ready to be harnessed like a horse

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: And the Lion would answer, No.  If you come in this yard, I will bite you.
children.prevalue: And the Lion would answer No If you come in this yard I will bite you

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: The reason the Lion did not have to do as the Witch wished was that every night, while the woman was asleep, Dorothy carried him food from the cupboard.  After he had eaten he would lie down on his bed of straw, and Dorothy would lie beside him and put her head on his soft, shaggy mane, while they talked of their troubles and tried to plan some way to escape.  But they could find no way to get out of the castle, for it was constantly guarded by the yellow Winkies, who were the slaves of the Wicked Witch and too afraid of her not to do as she told them.
children.prevalue: The reason the Lion did not have to do as the Witch wished was that every night while the woman was asleep Dorothy carried him food from the cupboard After he had eaten he would lie down on his bed of straw and Dorothy would lie beside him and put her head on his soft shaggy mane while they talked of their troubles and tried to plan some way to escape But they could find no way to get out of the castle for it was constantly guarded by the yellow Winkies who were the slaves of the Wicked Witch and too afraid of her not to do as she told them

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: The girl had to work hard during the day, and often the Witch threatened to beat her with the same old umbrella she always carried in her hand.  But, in truth, she did not dare to strike Dorothy, because of the mark upon her forehead.  The child did not know this, and was full of fear for herself and Toto.  Once the Witch struck Toto a blow with her umbrella and the brave little dog flew at her and bit her leg in return.  The Witch did not bleed where she was bitten, for she was so wicked that the blood in her had dried up many years before.
children.prevalue: The girl had to work hard during the day and often the Witch threatened to beat her with the same old umbrella she always carried in her hand But in truth she did not dare to strike Dorothy because of the mark upon her forehead The child did not know this and was full of fear for herself and Toto Once the Witch struck Toto a blow with her umbrella and the brave little dog flew at her and bit her leg in return The Witch did not bleed where she was bitten for she was so wicked that the blood in her had dried up many years before

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Dorothy's life became very sad as she grew to understand that it would be harder than ever to get back to Kansas and Aunt Em again.  Sometimes she would cry bitterly for hours, with Toto sitting at her feet and looking into her face, whining dismally to show how sorry he was for his little mistress.  Toto did not really care whether he was in Kansas or the Land of Oz so long as Dorothy was with him; but he knew the little girl was unhappy, and that made him unhappy too.
children.prevalue: Dorothy s life became very sad as she grew to understand that it would be harder than ever to get back to Kansas and Aunt Em again Sometimes she would cry bitterly for hours with Toto sitting at her feet and looking into her face whining dismally to show how sorry he was for his little mistress Toto did not really care whether he was in Kansas or the Land of Oz so long as Dorothy was with him but he knew the little girl was unhappy and that made him unhappy too

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: Now the Wicked Witch had a great longing to have for her own the Silver Shoes which the girl always wore.  Her bees and her crows and her wolves were lying in heaps and drying up, and she had used up all the power of the Golden Cap; but if she could only get hold of the Silver Shoes, they would give her more power than all the other things she had lost.  She watched Dorothy carefully, to see if she ever took off her shoes, thinking she might steal them.  But the child was so proud of her pretty shoes that she never took them off except at night and when she took her bath.  The Witch was too much afraid of the dark to dare go in Dorothy's room at night to take the shoes, and her dread of water was greater than her fear of the dark, so she never came near when Dorothy was bathing.  Indeed, the old Witch never touched water, nor ever let water touch her in any way.
children.prevalue: Now the Wicked Witch had a great longing to have for her own the Silver Shoes which the girl always wore Her bees and her crows and her wolves were lying in heaps and drying up and she had used up all the power of the Golden Cap but if she could only get hold of the Silver Shoes they would give her more power than all the other things she had lost She watched Dorothy carefully to see if she ever took off her shoes thinking she might steal them But the child was so proud of her pretty shoes that she never took them off except at night and when she took her bath The Witch was too much afraid of the dark to dare go in Dorothy s room at night to take the shoes and her dread of water was greater than her fear of the dark so she never came near when Dorothy was bathing Indeed the old Witch never touched water nor ever let water touch her in any way

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: But the wicked creature was very cunning, and she finally thought of a trick that would give her what she wanted.  She placed a bar of iron in the middle of the kitchen floor, and then by her magic arts made the iron invisible to human eyes.  So that when Dorothy walked across the floor she stumbled over the bar, not being able to see it, and fell at full length.  She was not much hurt, but in her fall one of the Silver Shoes came off; and before she could reach it, the Witch had snatched it away and put it on her own skinny foot.
children.prevalue: But the wicked creature was very cunning and she finally thought of a trick that would give her what she wanted She placed a bar of iron in the middle of the kitchen floor and then by her magic arts made the iron invisible to human eyes So that when Dorothy walked across the floor she stumbled over the bar not being able to see it and fell at full length She was not much hurt but in her fall one of the Silver Shoes came off and before she could reach it the Witch had snatched it away and put it on her own skinny foot

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: The wicked woman was greatly pleased with the success of her trick, for as long as she had one of the shoes she owned half the power of their charm, and Dorothy could not use it against her, even had she known how to do so.
children.prevalue: The wicked woman was greatly pleased with the success of her trick for as long as she had one of the shoes she owned half the power of their charm and Dorothy could not use it against her even had she known how to do so

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: The little girl, seeing she had lost one of her pretty shoes, grew angry, and said to the Witch, Give me back my shoe!
children.prevalue: The little girl seeing she had lost one of her pretty shoes grew angry and said to the Witch Give me back my shoe

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: I will not, retorted the Witch, for it is now my shoe, and not yours.
children.prevalue: I will not retorted the Witch for it is now my shoe and not yours

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: You are a wicked creature! cried Dorothy.  You have no right to take my shoe from me.
children.prevalue: You are a wicked creature cried Dorothy You have no right to take my shoe from me

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: I shall keep it, just the same, said the Witch, laughing at her, and someday I shall get the other one from you, too.
children.prevalue: I shall keep it just the same said the Witch laughing at her and someday I shall get the other one from you too

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: This made Dorothy so very angry that she picked up the bucket of water that stood near and dashed it over the Witch, wetting her from head to foot.
children.prevalue: This made Dorothy so very angry that she picked up the bucket of water that stood near and dashed it over the Witch wetting her from head to foot

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: Instantly the wicked woman gave a loud cry of fear, and then, as Dorothy looked at her in wonder, the Witch began to shrink and fall away.
children.prevalue: Instantly the wicked woman gave a loud cry of fear and then as Dorothy looked at her in wonder the Witch began to shrink and fall away

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: See what you have done! she screamed.  In a minute I shall melt away.
children.prevalue: See what you have done she screamed In a minute I shall melt away

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: I'm very sorry, indeed, said Dorothy, who was truly frightened to see the Witch actually melting away like brown sugar before her very eyes.
children.prevalue: I m very sorry indeed said Dorothy who was truly frightened to see the Witch actually melting away like brown sugar before her very eyes

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Didn't you know water would be the end of me? asked the Witch, in a wailing, despairing voice.
children.prevalue: Didn t you know water would be the end of me asked the Witch in a wailing despairing voice

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Of course not, answered Dorothy.  How should I?
children.prevalue: Of course not answered Dorothy How should I

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: Well, in a few minutes I shall be all melted, and you will have the castle to yourself.  I have been wicked in my day, but I never thought a little girl like you would ever be able to melt me and end my wicked deeds.  Look out--here I go!
children.prevalue: Well in a few minutes I shall be all melted and you will have the castle to yourself I have been wicked in my day but I never thought a little girl like you would ever be able to melt me and end my wicked deeds Look out here I go

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: With these words the Witch fell down in a brown, melted, shapeless mass and began to spread over the clean boards of the kitchen floor.  Seeing that she had really melted away to nothing, Dorothy drew another bucket of water and threw it over the mess.  She then swept it all out the door.  After picking out the silver shoe, which was all that was left of the old woman, she cleaned and dried it with a cloth, and put it on her foot again.  Then, being at last free to do as she chose, she ran out to the courtyard to tell the Lion that the Wicked Witch of the West had come to an end, and that they were no longer prisoners in a strange land.
children.prevalue: With these words the Witch fell down in a brown melted shapeless mass and began to spread over the clean boards of the kitchen floor Seeing that she had really melted away to nothing Dorothy drew another bucket of water and threw it over the mess She then swept it all out the door After picking out the silver shoe which was all that was left of the old woman she cleaned and dried it with a cloth and put it on her foot again Then being at last free to do as she chose she ran out to the courtyard to tell the Lion that the Wicked Witch of the West had come to an end and that they were no longer prisoners in a strange land

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The Cowardly Lion was much pleased to hear that the Wicked Witch had been melted by a bucket of water, and Dorothy at once unlocked the gate of his prison and set him free.  They went in together to the castle, where Dorothy's first act was to call all the Winkies together and tell them that they were no longer slaves.
children.prevalue: The Cowardly Lion was much pleased to hear that the Wicked Witch had been melted by a bucket of water and Dorothy at once unlocked the gate of his prison and set him free They went in together to the castle where Dorothy s first act was to call all the Winkies together and tell them that they were no longer slaves

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: There was great rejoicing among the yellow Winkies, for they had been made to work hard during many years for the Wicked Witch, who had always treated them with great cruelty.  They kept this day as a holiday, then and ever after, and spent the time in feasting and dancing.
children.prevalue: There was great rejoicing among the yellow Winkies for they had been made to work hard during many years for the Wicked Witch who had always treated them with great cruelty They kept this day as a holiday then and ever after and spent the time in feasting and dancing

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: If our friends, the Scarecrow and the Tin Woodman, were only with us, said the Lion, I should be quite happy.
children.prevalue: If our friends the Scarecrow and the Tin Woodman were only with us said the Lion I should be quite happy

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Don't you suppose we could rescue them? asked the girl anxiously.
children.prevalue: Don t you suppose we could rescue them asked the girl anxiously

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: We can try, answered the Lion.
children.prevalue: We can try answered the Lion

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: So they called the yellow Winkies and asked them if they would help to rescue their friends, and the Winkies said that they would be delighted to do all in their power for Dorothy, who had set them free from bondage.  So she chose a number of the Winkies who looked as if they knew the most, and they all started away.  They traveled that day and part of the next until they came to the rocky plain where the Tin Woodman lay, all battered and bent.  His axe was near him, but the blade was rusted and the handle broken off short.
children.prevalue: So they called the yellow Winkies and asked them if they would help to rescue their friends and the Winkies said that they would be delighted to do all in their power for Dorothy who had set them free from bondage So she chose a number of the Winkies who looked as if they knew the most and they all started away They traveled that day and part of the next until they came to the rocky plain where the Tin Woodman lay all battered and bent His axe was near him but the blade was rusted and the handle broken off short

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: The Winkies lifted him tenderly in their arms, and carried him back to the Yellow Castle again, Dorothy shedding a few tears by the way at the sad plight of her old friend, and the Lion looking sober and sorry. When they reached the castle Dorothy said to the Winkies:
children.prevalue: The Winkies lifted him tenderly in their arms and carried him back to the Yellow Castle again Dorothy shedding a few tears by the way at the sad plight of her old friend and the Lion looking sober and sorry When they reached the castle Dorothy said to the Winkies

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Are any of your people tinsmiths?
children.prevalue: Are any of your people tinsmiths

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Oh, yes.  Some of us are very good tinsmiths, they told her.
children.prevalue: Oh yes Some of us are very good tinsmiths they told her

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Then bring them to me, she said.  And when the tinsmiths came, bringing with them all their tools in baskets, she inquired, Can you straighten out those dents in the Tin Woodman, and bend him back into shape again, and solder him together where he is broken?
children.prevalue: Then bring them to me she said And when the tinsmiths came bringing with them all their tools in baskets she inquired Can you straighten out those dents in the Tin Woodman and bend him back into shape again and solder him together where he is broken

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: The tinsmiths looked the Woodman over carefully and then answered that they thought they could mend him so he would be as good as ever.  So they set to work in one of the big yellow rooms of the castle and worked for three days and four nights, hammering and twisting and bending and soldering and polishing and pounding at the legs and body and head of the Tin Woodman, until at last he was straightened out into his old form, and his joints worked as well as ever.  To be sure, there were several patches on him, but the tinsmiths did a good job, and as the Woodman was not a vain man he did not mind the patches at all.
children.prevalue: The tinsmiths looked the Woodman over carefully and then answered that they thought they could mend him so he would be as good as ever So they set to work in one of the big yellow rooms of the castle and worked for three days and four nights hammering and twisting and bending and soldering and polishing and pounding at the legs and body and head of the Tin Woodman until at last he was straightened out into his old form and his joints worked as well as ever To be sure there were several patches on him but the tinsmiths did a good job and as the Woodman was not a vain man he did not mind the patches at all

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: When, at last, he walked into Dorothy's room and thanked her for rescuing him, he was so pleased that he wept tears of joy, and Dorothy had to wipe every tear carefully from his face with her apron, so his joints would not be rusted.  At the same time her own tears fell thick and fast at the joy of meeting her old friend again, and these tears did not need to be wiped away.  As for the Lion, he wiped his eyes so often with the tip of his tail that it became quite wet, and he was obliged to go out into the courtyard and hold it in the sun till it dried.
children.prevalue: When at last he walked into Dorothy s room and thanked her for rescuing him he was so pleased that he wept tears of joy and Dorothy had to wipe every tear carefully from his face with her apron so his joints would not be rusted At the same time her own tears fell thick and fast at the joy of meeting her old friend again and these tears did not need to be wiped away As for the Lion he wiped his eyes so often with the tip of his tail that it became quite wet and he was obliged to go out into the courtyard and hold it in the sun till it dried

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: If we only had the Scarecrow with us again, said the Tin Woodman, when Dorothy had finished telling him everything that had happened, I should be quite happy.
children.prevalue: If we only had the Scarecrow with us again said the Tin Woodman when Dorothy had finished telling him everything that had happened I should be quite happy

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: We must try to find him, said the girl.
children.prevalue: We must try to find him said the girl

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: So she called the Winkies to help her, and they walked all that day and part of the next until they came to the tall tree in the branches of which the Winged Monkeys had tossed the Scarecrow's clothes.
children.prevalue: So she called the Winkies to help her and they walked all that day and part of the next until they came to the tall tree in the branches of which the Winged Monkeys had tossed the Scarecrow s clothes

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: It was a very tall tree, and the trunk was so smooth that no one could climb it; but the Woodman said at once, I'll chop it down, and then we can get the Scarecrow's clothes.
children.prevalue: It was a very tall tree and the trunk was so smooth that no one could climb it but the Woodman said at once I ll chop it down and then we can get the Scarecrow s clothes

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Now while the tinsmiths had been at work mending the Woodman himself, another of the Winkies, who was a goldsmith, had made an axe-handle of solid gold and fitted it to the Woodman's axe, instead of the old broken handle.  Others polished the blade until all the rust was removed and it glistened like burnished silver.
children.prevalue: Now while the tinsmiths had been at work mending the Woodman himself another of the Winkies who was a goldsmith had made an axe handle of solid gold and fitted it to the Woodman s axe instead of the old broken handle Others polished the blade until all the rust was removed and it glistened like burnished silver

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: As soon as he had spoken, the Tin Woodman began to chop, and in a short time the tree fell over with a crash, whereupon the Scarecrow's clothes fell out of the branches and rolled off on the ground.
children.prevalue: As soon as he had spoken the Tin Woodman began to chop and in a short time the tree fell over with a crash whereupon the Scarecrow s clothes fell out of the branches and rolled off on the ground

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Dorothy picked them up and had the Winkies carry them back to the castle, where they were stuffed with nice, clean straw; and behold! here was the Scarecrow, as good as ever, thanking them over and over again for saving him.
children.prevalue: Dorothy picked them up and had the Winkies carry them back to the castle where they were stuffed with nice clean straw and behold here was the Scarecrow as good as ever thanking them over and over again for saving him

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Now that they were reunited, Dorothy and her friends spent a few happy days at the Yellow Castle, where they found everything they needed to make them comfortable.
children.prevalue: Now that they were reunited Dorothy and her friends spent a few happy days at the Yellow Castle where they found everything they needed to make them comfortable

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: But one day the girl thought of Aunt Em, and said, We must go back to Oz, and claim his promise.
children.prevalue: But one day the girl thought of Aunt Em and said We must go back to Oz and claim his promise

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Yes, said the Woodman, at last I shall get my heart.
children.prevalue: Yes said the Woodman at last I shall get my heart

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: And I shall get my brains, added the Scarecrow joyfully.
children.prevalue: And I shall get my brains added the Scarecrow joyfully

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: And I shall get my courage, said the Lion thoughtfully.
children.prevalue: And I shall get my courage said the Lion thoughtfully

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: And I shall get back to Kansas, cried Dorothy, clapping her hands. Oh, let us start for the Emerald City tomorrow!
children.prevalue: And I shall get back to Kansas cried Dorothy clapping her hands Oh let us start for the Emerald City tomorrow

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: This they decided to do.  The next day they called the Winkies together and bade them good-bye.  The Winkies were sorry to have them go, and they had grown so fond of the Tin Woodman that they begged him to stay and rule over them and the Yellow Land of the West.  Finding they were determined to go, the Winkies gave Toto and the Lion each a golden collar; and to Dorothy they presented a beautiful bracelet studded with diamonds; and to the Scarecrow they gave a gold-headed walking stick, to keep him from stumbling; and to the Tin Woodman they offered a silver oil-can, inlaid with gold and set with precious jewels.
children.prevalue: This they decided to do The next day they called the Winkies together and bade them good bye The Winkies were sorry to have them go and they had grown so fond of the Tin Woodman that they begged him to stay and rule over them and the Yellow Land of the West Finding they were determined to go the Winkies gave Toto and the Lion each a golden collar and to Dorothy they presented a beautiful bracelet studded with diamonds and to the Scarecrow they gave a gold headed walking stick to keep him from stumbling and to the Tin Woodman they offered a silver oil can inlaid with gold and set with precious jewels

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Every one of the travelers made the Winkies a pretty speech in return, and all shook hands with them until their arms ached.
children.prevalue: Every one of the travelers made the Winkies a pretty speech in return and all shook hands with them until their arms ached

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Dorothy went to the Witch's cupboard to fill her basket with food for the journey, and there she saw the Golden Cap.  She tried it on her own head and found that it fitted her exactly.  She did not know anything about the charm of the Golden Cap, but she saw that it was pretty, so she made up her mind to wear it and carry her sunbonnet in the basket.
children.prevalue: Dorothy went to the Witch s cupboard to fill her basket with food for the journey and there she saw the Golden Cap She tried it on her own head and found that it fitted her exactly She did not know anything about the charm of the Golden Cap but she saw that it was pretty so she made up her mind to wear it and carry her sunbonnet in the basket

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Then, being prepared for the journey, they all started for the Emerald City; and the Winkies gave them three cheers and many good wishes to carry with them.
children.prevalue: Then being prepared for the journey they all started for the Emerald City and the Winkies gave them three cheers and many good wishes to carry with them

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: You will remember there was no road--not even a pathway--between the castle of the Wicked Witch and the Emerald City.  When the four travelers went in search of the Witch she had seen them coming, and so sent the Winged Monkeys to bring them to her.  It was much harder to find their way back through the big fields of buttercups and yellow daisies than it was being carried.  They knew, of course, they must go straight east, toward the rising sun; and they started off in the right way.  But at noon, when the sun was over their heads, they did not know which was east and which was west, and that was the reason they were lost in the great fields.  They kept on walking, however, and at night the moon came out and shone brightly.  So they lay down among the sweet smelling yellow flowers and slept soundly until morning--all but the Scarecrow and the Tin Woodman.
children.prevalue: You will remember there was no road not even a pathway between the castle of the Wicked Witch and the Emerald City When the four travelers went in search of the Witch she had seen them coming and so sent the Winged Monkeys to bring them to her It was much harder to find their way back through the big fields of buttercups and yellow daisies than it was being carried They knew of course they must go straight east toward the rising sun and they started off in the right way But at noon when the sun was over their heads they did not know which was east and which was west and that was the reason they were lost in the great fields They kept on walking however and at night the moon came out and shone brightly So they lay down among the sweet smelling yellow flowers and slept soundly until morning all but the Scarecrow and the Tin Woodman

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The next morning the sun was behind a cloud, but they started on, as if they were quite sure which way they were going.
children.prevalue: The next morning the sun was behind a cloud but they started on as if they were quite sure which way they were going

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: If we walk far enough, said Dorothy, I am sure we shall sometime come to some place.
children.prevalue: If we walk far enough said Dorothy I am sure we shall sometime come to some place

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: But day by day passed away, and they still saw nothing before them but the scarlet fields.  The Scarecrow began to grumble a bit.
children.prevalue: But day by day passed away and they still saw nothing before them but the scarlet fields The Scarecrow began to grumble a bit

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: We have surely lost our way, he said, and unless we find it again in time to reach the Emerald City, I shall never get my brains.
children.prevalue: We have surely lost our way he said and unless we find it again in time to reach the Emerald City I shall never get my brains

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Nor I my heart, declared the Tin Woodman.  It seems to me I can scarcely wait till I get to Oz, and you must admit this is a very long journey.
children.prevalue: Nor I my heart declared the Tin Woodman It seems to me I can scarcely wait till I get to Oz and you must admit this is a very long journey

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: You see, said the Cowardly Lion, with a whimper, I haven't the courage to keep tramping forever, without getting anywhere at all.
children.prevalue: You see said the Cowardly Lion with a whimper I haven t the courage to keep tramping forever without getting anywhere at all

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Then Dorothy lost heart.  She sat down on the grass and looked at her companions, and they sat down and looked at her, and Toto found that for the first time in his life he was too tired to chase a butterfly that flew past his head.  So he put out his tongue and panted and looked at Dorothy as if to ask what they should do next.
children.prevalue: Then Dorothy lost heart She sat down on the grass and looked at her companions and they sat down and looked at her and Toto found that for the first time in his life he was too tired to chase a butterfly that flew past his head So he put out his tongue and panted and looked at Dorothy as if to ask what they should do next

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Suppose we call the field mice, she suggested.  They could probably tell us the way to the Emerald City.
children.prevalue: Suppose we call the field mice she suggested They could probably tell us the way to the Emerald City

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: To be sure they could, cried the Scarecrow.  Why didn't we think of that before?
children.prevalue: To be sure they could cried the Scarecrow Why didn t we think of that before

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Dorothy blew the little whistle she had always carried about her neck since the Queen of the Mice had given it to her.  In a few minutes they heard the pattering of tiny feet, and many of the small gray mice came running up to her.  Among them was the Queen herself, who asked, in her squeaky little voice:
children.prevalue: Dorothy blew the little whistle she had always carried about her neck since the Queen of the Mice had given it to her In a few minutes they heard the pattering of tiny feet and many of the small gray mice came running up to her Among them was the Queen herself who asked in her squeaky little voice

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: What can I do for my friends?
children.prevalue: What can I do for my friends

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: We have lost our way, said Dorothy.  Can you tell us where the Emerald City is?
children.prevalue: We have lost our way said Dorothy Can you tell us where the Emerald City is

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Certainly, answered the Queen; but it is a great way off, for you have had it at your backs all this time.  Then she noticed Dorothy's Golden Cap, and said, Why don't you use the charm of the Cap, and call the Winged Monkeys to you?  They will carry you to the City of Oz in less than an hour.
children.prevalue: Certainly answered the Queen but it is a great way off for you have had it at your backs all this time Then she noticed Dorothy s Golden Cap and said Why don t you use the charm of the Cap and call the Winged Monkeys to you They will carry you to the City of Oz in less than an hour

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: I didn't know there was a charm, answered Dorothy, in surprise. What is it?
children.prevalue: I didn t know there was a charm answered Dorothy in surprise What is it

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: It is written inside the Golden Cap, replied the Queen of the Mice. But if you are going to call the Winged Monkeys we must run away, for they are full of mischief and think it great fun to plague us.
children.prevalue: It is written inside the Golden Cap replied the Queen of the Mice But if you are going to call the Winged Monkeys we must run away for they are full of mischief and think it great fun to plague us

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Won't they hurt me? asked the girl anxiously.
children.prevalue: Won t they hurt me asked the girl anxiously

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Oh, no.  They must obey the wearer of the Cap.  Good-bye! And she scampered out of sight, with all the mice hurrying after her.
children.prevalue: Oh no They must obey the wearer of the Cap Good bye And she scampered out of sight with all the mice hurrying after her

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Dorothy looked inside the Golden Cap and saw some words written upon the lining.  These, she thought, must be the charm, so she read the directions carefully and put the Cap upon her head.
children.prevalue: Dorothy looked inside the Golden Cap and saw some words written upon the lining These she thought must be the charm so she read the directions carefully and put the Cap upon her head

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Ep-pe, pep-pe, kak-ke! she said, standing on her left foot.
children.prevalue: Ep pe pep pe kak ke she said standing on her left foot

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: What did you say? asked the Scarecrow, who did not know what she was doing.
children.prevalue: What did you say asked the Scarecrow who did not know what she was doing

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Hil-lo, hol-lo, hel-lo!  Dorothy went on, standing this time on her right foot.
children.prevalue: Hil lo hol lo hel lo Dorothy went on standing this time on her right foot

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Hello! replied the Tin Woodman calmly.
children.prevalue: Hello replied the Tin Woodman calmly

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Ziz-zy, zuz-zy, zik! said Dorothy, who was now standing on both feet. This ended the saying of the charm, and they heard a great chattering and flapping of wings, as the band of Winged Monkeys flew up to them.
children.prevalue: Ziz zy zuz zy zik said Dorothy who was now standing on both feet This ended the saying of the charm and they heard a great chattering and flapping of wings as the band of Winged Monkeys flew up to them

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: The King bowed low before Dorothy, and asked, What is your command?
children.prevalue: The King bowed low before Dorothy and asked What is your command

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: We wish to go to the Emerald City, said the child, and we have lost our way.
children.prevalue: We wish to go to the Emerald City said the child and we have lost our way

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: We will carry you, replied the King, and no sooner had he spoken than two of the Monkeys caught Dorothy in their arms and flew away with her. Others took the Scarecrow and the Woodman and the Lion, and one little Monkey seized Toto and flew after them, although the dog tried hard to bite him.
children.prevalue: We will carry you replied the King and no sooner had he spoken than two of the Monkeys caught Dorothy in their arms and flew away with her Others took the Scarecrow and the Woodman and the Lion and one little Monkey seized Toto and flew after them although the dog tried hard to bite him

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: The Scarecrow and the Tin Woodman were rather frightened at first, for they remembered how badly the Winged Monkeys had treated them before; but they saw that no harm was intended, so they rode through the air quite cheerfully, and had a fine time looking at the pretty gardens and woods far below them.
children.prevalue: The Scarecrow and the Tin Woodman were rather frightened at first for they remembered how badly the Winged Monkeys had treated them before but they saw that no harm was intended so they rode through the air quite cheerfully and had a fine time looking at the pretty gardens and woods far below them

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Dorothy found herself riding easily between two of the biggest Monkeys, one of them the King himself.  They had made a chair of their hands and were careful not to hurt her.
children.prevalue: Dorothy found herself riding easily between two of the biggest Monkeys one of them the King himself They had made a chair of their hands and were careful not to hurt her

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Why do you have to obey the charm of the Golden Cap? she asked.
children.prevalue: Why do you have to obey the charm of the Golden Cap she asked

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: That is a long story, answered the King, with a winged laugh; but as we have a long journey before us, I will pass the time by telling you about it, if you wish.
children.prevalue: That is a long story answered the King with a winged laugh but as we have a long journey before us I will pass the time by telling you about it if you wish

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: I shall be glad to hear it, she replied.
children.prevalue: I shall be glad to hear it she replied

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Once, began the leader, we were a free people, living happily in the great forest, flying from tree to tree, eating nuts and fruit, and doing just as we pleased without calling anybody master.  Perhaps some of us were rather too full of mischief at times, flying down to pull the tails of the animals that had no wings, chasing birds, and throwing nuts at the people who walked in the forest.  But we were careless and happy and full of fun, and enjoyed every minute of the day.  This was many years ago, long before Oz came out of the clouds to rule over this land.
children.prevalue: Once began the leader we were a free people living happily in the great forest flying from tree to tree eating nuts and fruit and doing just as we pleased without calling anybody master Perhaps some of us were rather too full of mischief at times flying down to pull the tails of the animals that had no wings chasing birds and throwing nuts at the people who walked in the forest But we were careless and happy and full of fun and enjoyed every minute of the day This was many years ago long before Oz came out of the clouds to rule over this land

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: There lived here then, away at the North, a beautiful princess, who was also a powerful sorceress.  All her magic was used to help the people, and she was never known to hurt anyone who was good.  Her name was Gayelette, and she lived in a handsome palace built from great blocks of ruby.  Everyone loved her, but her greatest sorrow was that she could find no one to love in return, since all the men were much too stupid and ugly to mate with one so beautiful and wise.  At last, however, she found a boy who was handsome and manly and wise beyond his years.  Gayelette made up her mind that when he grew to be a man she would make him her husband, so she took him to her ruby palace and used all her magic powers to make him as strong and good and lovely as any woman could wish.  When he grew to manhood, Quelala, as he was called, was said to be the best and wisest man in all the land, while his manly beauty was so great that Gayelette loved him dearly, and hastened to make everything ready for the wedding.
children.prevalue: There lived here then away at the North a beautiful princess who was also a powerful sorceress All her magic was used to help the people and she was never known to hurt anyone who was good Her name was Gayelette and she lived in a handsome palace built from great blocks of ruby Everyone loved her but her greatest sorrow was that she could find no one to love in return since all the men were much too stupid and ugly to mate with one so beautiful and wise At last however she found a boy who was handsome and manly and wise beyond his years Gayelette made up her mind that when he grew to be a man she would make him her husband so she took him to her ruby palace and used all her magic powers to make him as strong and good and lovely as any woman could wish When he grew to manhood Quelala as he was called was said to be the best and wisest man in all the land while his manly beauty was so great that Gayelette loved him dearly and hastened to make everything ready for the wedding

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: My grandfather was at that time the King of the Winged Monkeys which lived in the forest near Gayelette's palace, and the old fellow loved a joke better than a good dinner.  One day, just before the wedding, my grandfather was flying out with his band when he saw Quelala walking beside the river.  He was dressed in a rich costume of pink silk and purple velvet, and my grandfather thought he would see what he could do.  At his word the band flew down and seized Quelala, carried him in their arms until they were over the middle of the river, and then dropped him into the water.
children.prevalue: My grandfather was at that time the King of the Winged Monkeys which lived in the forest near Gayelette s palace and the old fellow loved a joke better than a good dinner One day just before the wedding my grandfather was flying out with his band when he saw Quelala walking beside the river He was dressed in a rich costume of pink silk and purple velvet and my grandfather thought he would see what he could do At his word the band flew down and seized Quelala carried him in their arms until they were over the middle of the river and then dropped him into the water

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: 'Swim out, my fine fellow,' cried my grandfather, 'and see if the water has spotted your clothes.'
