Quelala was much too wise not to swim, and he was not in the least spoiled by all his good fortune.  He laughed, when he came to the top of the water, and swam in to shore. But when Gayelette came running out to him she found his silks and velvet all ruined by the river.
children.prevalue: Swim out my fine fellow cried my grandfather and see if the water has spotted your clothes Quelala was much too wise not to swim and he was not in the least spoiled by all his good fortune He laughed when he came to the top of the water and swam in to shore But when Gayelette came running out to him she found his silks and velvet all ruined by the river

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: The princess was angry, and she knew, of course, who did it.  She had all the Winged Monkeys brought before her, and she said at first that their wings should be tied and they should be treated as they had treated Quelala, and dropped in the river.  But my grandfather pleaded hard, for he knew the Monkeys would drown in the river with their wings tied, and Quelala said a kind word for them also; so that Gayelette finally spared them, on condition that the Winged Monkeys should ever after do three times the bidding of the owner of the Golden Cap.  This Cap had been made for a wedding present to Quelala, and it is said to have cost the princess half her kingdom.  Of course my grandfather and all the other Monkeys at once agreed to the condition, and that is how it happens that we are three times the slaves of the owner of the Golden Cap, whosoever he may be.
children.prevalue: The princess was angry and she knew of course who did it She had all the Winged Monkeys brought before her and she said at first that their wings should be tied and they should be treated as they had treated Quelala and dropped in the river But my grandfather pleaded hard for he knew the Monkeys would drown in the river with their wings tied and Quelala said a kind word for them also so that Gayelette finally spared them on condition that the Winged Monkeys should ever after do three times the bidding of the owner of the Golden Cap This Cap had been made for a wedding present to Quelala and it is said to have cost the princess half her kingdom Of course my grandfather and all the other Monkeys at once agreed to the condition and that is how it happens that we are three times the slaves of the owner of the Golden Cap whosoever he may be

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: And what became of them? asked Dorothy, who had been greatly interested in the story.
children.prevalue: And what became of them asked Dorothy who had been greatly interested in the story

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: Quelala being the first owner of the Golden Cap, replied the Monkey, he was the first to lay his wishes upon us.  As his bride could not bear the sight of us, he called us all to him in the forest after he had married her and ordered us always to keep where she could never again set eyes on a Winged Monkey, which we were glad to do, for we were all afraid of her.
children.prevalue: Quelala being the first owner of the Golden Cap replied the Monkey he was the first to lay his wishes upon us As his bride could not bear the sight of us he called us all to him in the forest after he had married her and ordered us always to keep where she could never again set eyes on a Winged Monkey which we were glad to do for we were all afraid of her

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: This was all we ever had to do until the Golden Cap fell into the hands of the Wicked Witch of the West, who made us enslave the Winkies, and afterward drive Oz himself out of the Land of the West.  Now the Golden Cap is yours, and three times you have the right to lay your wishes upon us.
children.prevalue: This was all we ever had to do until the Golden Cap fell into the hands of the Wicked Witch of the West who made us enslave the Winkies and afterward drive Oz himself out of the Land of the West Now the Golden Cap is yours and three times you have the right to lay your wishes upon us

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: As the Monkey King finished his story Dorothy looked down and saw the green, shining walls of the Emerald City before them.  She wondered at the rapid flight of the Monkeys, but was glad the journey was over. The strange creatures set the travelers down carefully before the gate of the City, the King bowed low to Dorothy, and then flew swiftly away, followed by all his band.
children.prevalue: As the Monkey King finished his story Dorothy looked down and saw the green shining walls of the Emerald City before them She wondered at the rapid flight of the Monkeys but was glad the journey was over The strange creatures set the travelers down carefully before the gate of the City the King bowed low to Dorothy and then flew swiftly away followed by all his band

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: That was a good ride, said the little girl.
children.prevalue: That was a good ride said the little girl

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: Yes, and a quick way out of our troubles, replied the Lion.  How lucky it was you brought away that wonderful Cap!
children.prevalue: Yes and a quick way out of our troubles replied the Lion How lucky it was you brought away that wonderful Cap

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The four travelers walked up to the great gate of Emerald City and rang the bell.  After ringing several times, it was opened by the same Guardian of the Gates they had met before.
children.prevalue: The four travelers walked up to the great gate of Emerald City and rang the bell After ringing several times it was opened by the same Guardian of the Gates they had met before

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: What! are you back again? he asked, in surprise.
children.prevalue: What are you back again he asked in surprise

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Do you not see us? answered the Scarecrow.
children.prevalue: Do you not see us answered the Scarecrow

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: But I thought you had gone to visit the Wicked Witch of the West.
children.prevalue: But I thought you had gone to visit the Wicked Witch of the West

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: We did visit her, said the Scarecrow.
children.prevalue: We did visit her said the Scarecrow

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: And she let you go again? asked the man, in wonder.
children.prevalue: And she let you go again asked the man in wonder

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: She could not help it, for she is melted, explained the Scarecrow.
children.prevalue: She could not help it for she is melted explained the Scarecrow

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Melted!  Well, that is good news, indeed, said the man.  Who melted her?
children.prevalue: Melted Well that is good news indeed said the man Who melted her

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: It was Dorothy, said the Lion gravely.
children.prevalue: It was Dorothy said the Lion gravely

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Good gracious! exclaimed the man, and he bowed very low indeed before her.
children.prevalue: Good gracious exclaimed the man and he bowed very low indeed before her

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Then he led them into his little room and locked the spectacles from the great box on all their eyes, just as he had done before.  Afterward they passed on through the gate into the Emerald City.  When the people heard from the Guardian of the Gates that Dorothy had melted the Wicked Witch of the West, they all gathered around the travelers and followed them in a great crowd to the Palace of Oz.
children.prevalue: Then he led them into his little room and locked the spectacles from the great box on all their eyes just as he had done before Afterward they passed on through the gate into the Emerald City When the people heard from the Guardian of the Gates that Dorothy had melted the Wicked Witch of the West they all gathered around the travelers and followed them in a great crowd to the Palace of Oz

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: The soldier with the green whiskers was still on guard before the door, but he let them in at once, and they were again met by the beautiful green girl, who showed each of them to their old rooms at once, so they might rest until the Great Oz was ready to receive them.
children.prevalue: The soldier with the green whiskers was still on guard before the door but he let them in at once and they were again met by the beautiful green girl who showed each of them to their old rooms at once so they might rest until the Great Oz was ready to receive them

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: The soldier had the news carried straight to Oz that Dorothy and the other travelers had come back again, after destroying the Wicked Witch; but Oz made no reply.  They thought the Great Wizard would send for them at once, but he did not.  They had no word from him the next day, nor the next, nor the next.  The waiting was tiresome and wearing, and at last they grew vexed that Oz should treat them in so poor a fashion, after sending them to undergo hardships and slavery.  So the Scarecrow at last asked the green girl to take another message to Oz, saying if he did not let them in to see him at once they would call the Winged Monkeys to help them, and find out whether he kept his promises or not. When the Wizard was given this message he was so frightened that he sent word for them to come to the Throne Room at four minutes after nine o'clock the next morning.  He had once met the Winged Monkeys in the Land of the West, and he did not wish to meet them again.
children.prevalue: The soldier had the news carried straight to Oz that Dorothy and the other travelers had come back again after destroying the Wicked Witch but Oz made no reply They thought the Great Wizard would send for them at once but he did not They had no word from him the next day nor the next nor the next The waiting was tiresome and wearing and at last they grew vexed that Oz should treat them in so poor a fashion after sending them to undergo hardships and slavery So the Scarecrow at last asked the green girl to take another message to Oz saying if he did not let them in to see him at once they would call the Winged Monkeys to help them and find out whether he kept his promises or not When the Wizard was given this message he was so frightened that he sent word for them to come to the Throne Room at four minutes after nine o clock the next morning He had once met the Winged Monkeys in the Land of the West and he did not wish to meet them again

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: The four travelers passed a sleepless night, each thinking of the gift Oz had promised to bestow on him.  Dorothy fell asleep only once, and then she dreamed she was in Kansas, where Aunt Em was telling her how glad she was to have her little girl at home again.
children.prevalue: The four travelers passed a sleepless night each thinking of the gift Oz had promised to bestow on him Dorothy fell asleep only once and then she dreamed she was in Kansas where Aunt Em was telling her how glad she was to have her little girl at home again

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Promptly at nine o'clock the next morning the green-whiskered soldier came to them, and four minutes later they all went into the Throne Room of the Great Oz.
children.prevalue: Promptly at nine o clock the next morning the green whiskered soldier came to them and four minutes later they all went into the Throne Room of the Great Oz

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Of course each one of them expected to see the Wizard in the shape he had taken before, and all were greatly surprised when they looked about and saw no one at all in the room.  They kept close to the door and closer to one another, for the stillness of the empty room was more dreadful than any of the forms they had seen Oz take.
children.prevalue: Of course each one of them expected to see the Wizard in the shape he had taken before and all were greatly surprised when they looked about and saw no one at all in the room They kept close to the door and closer to one another for the stillness of the empty room was more dreadful than any of the forms they had seen Oz take

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Presently they heard a solemn Voice, that seemed to come from somewhere near the top of the great dome, and it said:
children.prevalue: Presently they heard a solemn Voice that seemed to come from somewhere near the top of the great dome and it said

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: I am Oz, the Great and Terrible.  Why do you seek me?
children.prevalue: I am Oz the Great and Terrible Why do you seek me

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: They looked again in every part of the room, and then, seeing no one, Dorothy asked, Where are you?
children.prevalue: They looked again in every part of the room and then seeing no one Dorothy asked Where are you

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: I am everywhere, answered the Voice, but to the eyes of common mortals I am invisible.  I will now seat myself upon my throne, that you may converse with me.  Indeed, the Voice seemed just then to come straight from the throne itself; so they walked toward it and stood in a row while Dorothy said:
children.prevalue: I am everywhere answered the Voice but to the eyes of common mortals I am invisible I will now seat myself upon my throne that you may converse with me Indeed the Voice seemed just then to come straight from the throne itself so they walked toward it and stood in a row while Dorothy said

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: We have come to claim our promise, O Oz.
children.prevalue: We have come to claim our promise O Oz

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: What promise? asked Oz.
children.prevalue: What promise asked Oz

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: You promised to send me back to Kansas when the Wicked Witch was destroyed, said the girl.
children.prevalue: You promised to send me back to Kansas when the Wicked Witch was destroyed said the girl

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: And you promised to give me brains, said the Scarecrow.
children.prevalue: And you promised to give me brains said the Scarecrow

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: And you promised to give me a heart, said the Tin Woodman.
children.prevalue: And you promised to give me a heart said the Tin Woodman

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: And you promised to give me courage, said the Cowardly Lion.
children.prevalue: And you promised to give me courage said the Cowardly Lion

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Is the Wicked Witch really destroyed? asked the Voice, and Dorothy thought it trembled a little.
children.prevalue: Is the Wicked Witch really destroyed asked the Voice and Dorothy thought it trembled a little

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Yes, she answered, I melted her with a bucket of water.
children.prevalue: Yes she answered I melted her with a bucket of water

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Dear me, said the Voice, how sudden!  Well, come to me tomorrow, for I must have time to think it over.
children.prevalue: Dear me said the Voice how sudden Well come to me tomorrow for I must have time to think it over

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: You've had plenty of time already, said the Tin Woodman angrily.
children.prevalue: You ve had plenty of time already said the Tin Woodman angrily

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: We shan't wait a day longer, said the Scarecrow.
children.prevalue: We shan t wait a day longer said the Scarecrow

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: You must keep your promises to us! exclaimed Dorothy.
children.prevalue: You must keep your promises to us exclaimed Dorothy

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: The Lion thought it might be as well to frighten the Wizard, so he gave a large, loud roar, which was so fierce and dreadful that Toto jumped away from him in alarm and tipped over the screen that stood in a corner.  As it fell with a crash they looked that way, and the next moment all of them were filled with wonder.  For they saw, standing in just the spot the screen had hidden, a little old man, with a bald head and a wrinkled face, who seemed to be as much surprised as they were. The Tin Woodman, raising his axe, rushed toward the little man and cried out, Who are you?
children.prevalue: The Lion thought it might be as well to frighten the Wizard so he gave a large loud roar which was so fierce and dreadful that Toto jumped away from him in alarm and tipped over the screen that stood in a corner As it fell with a crash they looked that way and the next moment all of them were filled with wonder For they saw standing in just the spot the screen had hidden a little old man with a bald head and a wrinkled face who seemed to be as much surprised as they were The Tin Woodman raising his axe rushed toward the little man and cried out Who are you

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: I am Oz, the Great and Terrible, said the little man, in a trembling voice.  But don't strike me--please don't--and I'll do anything you want me to.
children.prevalue: I am Oz the Great and Terrible said the little man in a trembling voice But don t strike me please don t and I ll do anything you want me to

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Our friends looked at him in surprise and dismay.
children.prevalue: Our friends looked at him in surprise and dismay

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: I thought Oz was a great Head, said Dorothy.
children.prevalue: I thought Oz was a great Head said Dorothy

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: And I thought Oz was a lovely Lady, said the Scarecrow.
children.prevalue: And I thought Oz was a lovely Lady said the Scarecrow

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: And I thought Oz was a terrible Beast, said the Tin Woodman.
children.prevalue: And I thought Oz was a terrible Beast said the Tin Woodman

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: And I thought Oz was a Ball of Fire, exclaimed the Lion.
children.prevalue: And I thought Oz was a Ball of Fire exclaimed the Lion

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: No, you are all wrong, said the little man meekly.  I have been making believe.
children.prevalue: No you are all wrong said the little man meekly I have been making believe

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Making believe! cried Dorothy.  Are you not a Great Wizard?
children.prevalue: Making believe cried Dorothy Are you not a Great Wizard

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: Hush, my dear, he said.  Don't speak so loud, or you will be overheard--and I should be ruined.  I'm supposed to be a Great Wizard.
children.prevalue: Hush my dear he said Don t speak so loud or you will be overheard and I should be ruined I m supposed to be a Great Wizard

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: And aren't you? she asked.
children.prevalue: And aren t you she asked

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Not a bit of it, my dear; I'm just a common man.
children.prevalue: Not a bit of it my dear I m just a common man

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: You're more than that, said the Scarecrow, in a grieved tone; you're a humbug.
children.prevalue: You re more than that said the Scarecrow in a grieved tone you re a humbug

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Exactly so! declared the little man, rubbing his hands together as if it pleased him.  I am a humbug.
children.prevalue: Exactly so declared the little man rubbing his hands together as if it pleased him I am a humbug

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: But this is terrible, said the Tin Woodman.  How shall I ever get my heart?
children.prevalue: But this is terrible said the Tin Woodman How shall I ever get my heart

children.name: Paragraph_48
children.value: Or I my courage? asked the Lion.
children.prevalue: Or I my courage asked the Lion

children.name: Paragraph_49
children.value: Or I my brains? wailed the Scarecrow, wiping the tears from his eyes with his coat sleeve.
children.prevalue: Or I my brains wailed the Scarecrow wiping the tears from his eyes with his coat sleeve

children.name: Paragraph_50
children.value: My dear friends, said Oz, I pray you not to speak of these little things.  Think of me, and the terrible trouble I'm in at being found out.
children.prevalue: My dear friends said Oz I pray you not to speak of these little things Think of me and the terrible trouble I m in at being found out

children.name: Paragraph_51
children.value: Doesn't anyone else know you're a humbug? asked Dorothy.
children.prevalue: Doesn t anyone else know you re a humbug asked Dorothy

children.name: Paragraph_52
children.value: No one knows it but you four--and myself, replied Oz.  I have fooled everyone so long that I thought I should never be found out.  It was a great mistake my ever letting you into the Throne Room.  Usually I will not see even my subjects, and so they believe I am something terrible.
children.prevalue: No one knows it but you four and myself replied Oz I have fooled everyone so long that I thought I should never be found out It was a great mistake my ever letting you into the Throne Room Usually I will not see even my subjects and so they believe I am something terrible

children.name: Paragraph_53
children.value: But, I don't understand, said Dorothy, in bewilderment.  How was it that you appeared to me as a great Head?
children.prevalue: But I don t understand said Dorothy in bewilderment How was it that you appeared to me as a great Head

children.name: Paragraph_54
children.value: That was one of my tricks, answered Oz.  Step this way, please, and I will tell you all about it.
children.prevalue: That was one of my tricks answered Oz Step this way please and I will tell you all about it

children.name: Paragraph_55
children.value: He led the way to a small chamber in the rear of the Throne Room, and they all followed him.  He pointed to one corner, in which lay the great Head, made out of many thicknesses of paper, and with a carefully painted face.
children.prevalue: He led the way to a small chamber in the rear of the Throne Room and they all followed him He pointed to one corner in which lay the great Head made out of many thicknesses of paper and with a carefully painted face

children.name: Paragraph_56
children.value: This I hung from the ceiling by a wire, said Oz.  I stood behind the screen and pulled a thread, to make the eyes move and the mouth open.
children.prevalue: This I hung from the ceiling by a wire said Oz I stood behind the screen and pulled a thread to make the eyes move and the mouth open

children.name: Paragraph_57
children.value: But how about the voice? she inquired.
children.prevalue: But how about the voice she inquired

children.name: Paragraph_58
children.value: Oh, I am a ventriloquist, said the little man.  I can throw the sound of my voice wherever I wish, so that you thought it was coming out of the Head.  Here are the other things I used to deceive you.  He showed the Scarecrow the dress and the mask he had worn when he seemed to be the lovely Lady.  And the Tin Woodman saw that his terrible Beast was nothing but a lot of skins, sewn together, with slats to keep their sides out.  As for the Ball of Fire, the false Wizard had hung that also from the ceiling.  It was really a ball of cotton, but when oil was poured upon it the ball burned fiercely.
children.prevalue: Oh I am a ventriloquist said the little man I can throw the sound of my voice wherever I wish so that you thought it was coming out of the Head Here are the other things I used to deceive you He showed the Scarecrow the dress and the mask he had worn when he seemed to be the lovely Lady And the Tin Woodman saw that his terrible Beast was nothing but a lot of skins sewn together with slats to keep their sides out As for the Ball of Fire the false Wizard had hung that also from the ceiling It was really a ball of cotton but when oil was poured upon it the ball burned fiercely

children.name: Paragraph_59
children.value: Really, said the Scarecrow, you ought to be ashamed of yourself for being such a humbug.
children.prevalue: Really said the Scarecrow you ought to be ashamed of yourself for being such a humbug

children.name: Paragraph_60
children.value: I am--I certainly am, answered the little man sorrowfully; but it was the only thing I could do.  Sit down, please, there are plenty of chairs; and I will tell you my story.
children.prevalue: I am I certainly am answered the little man sorrowfully but it was the only thing I could do Sit down please there are plenty of chairs and I will tell you my story

children.name: Paragraph_61
children.value: So they sat down and listened while he told the following tale.
children.prevalue: So they sat down and listened while he told the following tale

children.name: Paragraph_62
children.value: I was born in Omaha--
children.prevalue: I was born in Omaha

children.name: Paragraph_63
children.value: Why, that isn't very far from Kansas! cried Dorothy.
children.prevalue: Why that isn t very far from Kansas cried Dorothy

children.name: Paragraph_64
children.value: No, but it's farther from here, he said, shaking his head at her sadly.  When I grew up I became a ventriloquist, and at that I was very well trained by a great master.  I can imitate any kind of a bird or beast.  Here he mewed so like a kitten that Toto pricked up his ears and looked everywhere to see where she was.  After a time, continued Oz, I tired of that, and became a balloonist.
children.prevalue: No but it s farther from here he said shaking his head at her sadly When I grew up I became a ventriloquist and at that I was very well trained by a great master I can imitate any kind of a bird or beast Here he mewed so like a kitten that Toto pricked up his ears and looked everywhere to see where she was After a time continued Oz I tired of that and became a balloonist

children.name: Paragraph_65
children.value: What is that? asked Dorothy.
children.prevalue: What is that asked Dorothy

children.name: Paragraph_66
children.value: A man who goes up in a balloon on circus day, so as to draw a crowd of people together and get them to pay to see the circus, he explained.
children.prevalue: A man who goes up in a balloon on circus day so as to draw a crowd of people together and get them to pay to see the circus he explained

children.name: Paragraph_67
children.value: Oh, she said, I know.
children.prevalue: Oh she said I know

children.name: Paragraph_68
children.value: Well, one day I went up in a balloon and the ropes got twisted, so that I couldn't come down again.  It went way up above the clouds, so far that a current of air struck it and carried it many, many miles away.  For a day and a night I traveled through the air, and on the morning of the second day I awoke and found the balloon floating over a strange and beautiful country.
children.prevalue: Well one day I went up in a balloon and the ropes got twisted so that I couldn t come down again It went way up above the clouds so far that a current of air struck it and carried it many many miles away For a day and a night I traveled through the air and on the morning of the second day I awoke and found the balloon floating over a strange and beautiful country

children.name: Paragraph_69
children.value: It came down gradually, and I was not hurt a bit.  But I found myself in the midst of a strange people, who, seeing me come from the clouds, thought I was a great Wizard.  Of course I let them think so, because they were afraid of me, and promised to do anything I wished them to.
children.prevalue: It came down gradually and I was not hurt a bit But I found myself in the midst of a strange people who seeing me come from the clouds thought I was a great Wizard Of course I let them think so because they were afraid of me and promised to do anything I wished them to

children.name: Paragraph_70
children.value: Just to amuse myself, and keep the good people busy, I ordered them to build this City, and my Palace; and they did it all willingly and well. Then I thought, as the country was so green and beautiful, I would call it the Emerald City; and to make the name fit better I put green spectacles on all the people, so that everything they saw was green.
children.prevalue: Just to amuse myself and keep the good people busy I ordered them to build this City and my Palace and they did it all willingly and well Then I thought as the country was so green and beautiful I would call it the Emerald City and to make the name fit better I put green spectacles on all the people so that everything they saw was green

children.name: Paragraph_71
children.value: But isn't everything here green? asked Dorothy.
children.prevalue: But isn t everything here green asked Dorothy

children.name: Paragraph_72
children.value: No more than in any other city, replied Oz; but when you wear green spectacles, why of course everything you see looks green to you.  The Emerald City was built a great many years ago, for I was a young man when the balloon brought me here, and I am a very old man now.  But my people have worn green glasses on their eyes so long that most of them think it really is an Emerald City, and it certainly is a beautiful place, abounding in jewels and precious metals, and every good thing that is needed to make one happy.  I have been good to the people, and they like me; but ever since this Palace was built, I have shut myself up and would not see any of them.
children.prevalue: No more than in any other city replied Oz but when you wear green spectacles why of course everything you see looks green to you The Emerald City was built a great many years ago for I was a young man when the balloon brought me here and I am a very old man now But my people have worn green glasses on their eyes so long that most of them think it really is an Emerald City and it certainly is a beautiful place abounding in jewels and precious metals and every good thing that is needed to make one happy I have been good to the people and they like me but ever since this Palace was built I have shut myself up and would not see any of them

children.name: Paragraph_73
children.value: One of my greatest fears was the Witches, for while I had no magical powers at all I soon found out that the Witches were really able to do wonderful things.  There were four of them in this country, and they ruled the people who live in the North and South and East and West. Fortunately, the Witches of the North and South were good, and I knew they would do me no harm; but the Witches of the East and West were terribly wicked, and had they not thought I was more powerful than they themselves, they would surely have destroyed me.  As it was, I lived in deadly fear of them for many years; so you can imagine how pleased I was when I heard your house had fallen on the Wicked Witch of the East. When you came to me, I was willing to promise anything if you would only do away with the other Witch; but, now that you have melted her, I am ashamed to say that I cannot keep my promises.
children.prevalue: One of my greatest fears was the Witches for while I had no magical powers at all I soon found out that the Witches were really able to do wonderful things There were four of them in this country and they ruled the people who live in the North and South and East and West Fortunately the Witches of the North and South were good and I knew they would do me no harm but the Witches of the East and West were terribly wicked and had they not thought I was more powerful than they themselves they would surely have destroyed me As it was I lived in deadly fear of them for many years so you can imagine how pleased I was when I heard your house had fallen on the Wicked Witch of the East When you came to me I was willing to promise anything if you would only do away with the other Witch but now that you have melted her I am ashamed to say that I cannot keep my promises

children.name: Paragraph_74
children.value: I think you are a very bad man, said Dorothy.
children.prevalue: I think you are a very bad man said Dorothy

children.name: Paragraph_75
children.value: Oh, no, my dear; I'm really a very good man, but I'm a very bad Wizard, I must admit.
children.prevalue: Oh no my dear I m really a very good man but I m a very bad Wizard I must admit

children.name: Paragraph_76
children.value: Can't you give me brains? asked the Scarecrow.
children.prevalue: Can t you give me brains asked the Scarecrow

children.name: Paragraph_77
children.value: You don't need them.  You are learning something every day.  A baby has brains, but it doesn't know much.  Experience is the only thing that brings knowledge, and the longer you are on earth the more experience you are sure to get.
children.prevalue: You don t need them You are learning something every day A baby has brains but it doesn t know much Experience is the only thing that brings knowledge and the longer you are on earth the more experience you are sure to get

children.name: Paragraph_78
children.value: That may all be true, said the Scarecrow, but I shall be very unhappy unless you give me brains.
children.prevalue: That may all be true said the Scarecrow but I shall be very unhappy unless you give me brains

children.name: Paragraph_79
children.value: The false Wizard looked at him carefully.
children.prevalue: The false Wizard looked at him carefully

children.name: Paragraph_80
children.value: Well, he said with a sigh, I'm not much of a magician, as I said; but if you will come to me tomorrow morning, I will stuff your head with brains.  I cannot tell you how to use them, however; you must find that out for yourself.
children.prevalue: Well he said with a sigh I m not much of a magician as I said but if you will come to me tomorrow morning I will stuff your head with brains I cannot tell you how to use them however you must find that out for yourself

children.name: Paragraph_81
children.value: Oh, thank you--thank you! cried the Scarecrow.  I'll find a way to use them, never fear!
children.prevalue: Oh thank you thank you cried the Scarecrow I ll find a way to use them never fear

children.name: Paragraph_82
children.value: But how about my courage? asked the Lion anxiously.
children.prevalue: But how about my courage asked the Lion anxiously

children.name: Paragraph_83
children.value: You have plenty of courage, I am sure, answered Oz.  All you need is confidence in yourself.  There is no living thing that is not afraid when it faces danger.  The True courage is in facing danger when you are afraid, and that kind of courage you have in plenty.
children.prevalue: You have plenty of courage I am sure answered Oz All you need is confidence in yourself There is no living thing that is not afraid when it faces danger The True courage is in facing danger when you are afraid and that kind of courage you have in plenty

children.name: Paragraph_84
children.value: Perhaps I have, but I'm scared just the same, said the Lion.  I shall really be very unhappy unless you give me the sort of courage that makes one forget he is afraid.
children.prevalue: Perhaps I have but I m scared just the same said the Lion I shall really be very unhappy unless you give me the sort of courage that makes one forget he is afraid

children.name: Paragraph_85
children.value: Very well, I will give you that sort of courage tomorrow, replied Oz.
children.prevalue: Very well I will give you that sort of courage tomorrow replied Oz

children.name: Paragraph_86
children.value: How about my heart? asked the Tin Woodman.
children.prevalue: How about my heart asked the Tin Woodman

children.name: Paragraph_87
children.value: Why, as for that, answered Oz, I think you are wrong to want a heart.  It makes most people unhappy.  If you only knew it, you are in luck not to have a heart.
children.prevalue: Why as for that answered Oz I think you are wrong to want a heart It makes most people unhappy If you only knew it you are in luck not to have a heart

children.name: Paragraph_88
children.value: That must be a matter of opinion, said the Tin Woodman.  For my part, I will bear all the unhappiness without a murmur, if you will give me the heart.
children.prevalue: That must be a matter of opinion said the Tin Woodman For my part I will bear all the unhappiness without a murmur if you will give me the heart

children.name: Paragraph_89
children.value: Very well, answered Oz meekly.  Come to me tomorrow and you shall have a heart.  I have played Wizard for so many years that I may as well continue the part a little longer.
children.prevalue: Very well answered Oz meekly Come to me tomorrow and you shall have a heart I have played Wizard for so many years that I may as well continue the part a little longer

children.name: Paragraph_90
children.value: And now, said Dorothy, how am I to get back to Kansas?
children.prevalue: And now said Dorothy how am I to get back to Kansas

children.name: Paragraph_91
children.value: We shall have to think about that, replied the little man.  Give me two or three days to consider the matter and I'll try to find a way to carry you over the desert.  In the meantime you shall all be treated as my guests, and while you live in the Palace my people will wait upon you and obey your slightest wish.  There is only one thing I ask in return for my help--such as it is.  You must keep my secret and tell no one I am a humbug.
children.prevalue: We shall have to think about that replied the little man Give me two or three days to consider the matter and I ll try to find a way to carry you over the desert In the meantime you shall all be treated as my guests and while you live in the Palace my people will wait upon you and obey your slightest wish There is only one thing I ask in return for my help such as it is You must keep my secret and tell no one I am a humbug

children.name: Paragraph_92
children.value: They agreed to say nothing of what they had learned, and went back to their rooms in high spirits.  Even Dorothy had hope that The Great and Terrible Humbug, as she called him, would find a way to send her back to Kansas, and if he did she was willing to forgive him everything.
children.prevalue: They agreed to say nothing of what they had learned and went back to their rooms in high spirits Even Dorothy had hope that The Great and Terrible Humbug as she called him would find a way to send her back to Kansas and if he did she was willing to forgive him everything

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Next morning the Scarecrow said to his friends:
children.prevalue: Next morning the Scarecrow said to his friends

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Congratulate me.  I am going to Oz to get my brains at last.  When I return I shall be as other men are.
children.prevalue: Congratulate me I am going to Oz to get my brains at last When I return I shall be as other men are

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: I have always liked you as you were, said Dorothy simply.
children.prevalue: I have always liked you as you were said Dorothy simply

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: It is kind of you to like a Scarecrow, he replied.  But surely you will think more of me when you hear the splendid thoughts my new brain is going to turn out.  Then he said good-bye to them all in a cheerful voice and went to the Throne Room, where he rapped upon the door.
children.prevalue: It is kind of you to like a Scarecrow he replied But surely you will think more of me when you hear the splendid thoughts my new brain is going to turn out Then he said good bye to them all in a cheerful voice and went to the Throne Room where he rapped upon the door

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Come in, said Oz.
children.prevalue: Come in said Oz

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: The Scarecrow went in and found the little man sitting down by the window, engaged in deep thought.
children.prevalue: The Scarecrow went in and found the little man sitting down by the window engaged in deep thought

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: I have come for my brains, remarked the Scarecrow, a little uneasily.
children.prevalue: I have come for my brains remarked the Scarecrow a little uneasily

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Oh, yes; sit down in that chair, please, replied Oz.  You must excuse me for taking your head off, but I shall have to do it in order to put your brains in their proper place.
children.prevalue: Oh yes sit down in that chair please replied Oz You must excuse me for taking your head off but I shall have to do it in order to put your brains in their proper place

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: That's all right, said the Scarecrow.  You are quite welcome to take my head off, as long as it will be a better one when you put it on again.
children.prevalue: That s all right said the Scarecrow You are quite welcome to take my head off as long as it will be a better one when you put it on again

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: So the Wizard unfastened his head and emptied out the straw.  Then he entered the back room and took up a measure of bran, which he mixed with a great many pins and needles.  Having shaken them together thoroughly, he filled the top of the Scarecrow's head with the mixture and stuffed the rest of the space with straw, to hold it in place.
children.prevalue: So the Wizard unfastened his head and emptied out the straw Then he entered the back room and took up a measure of bran which he mixed with a great many pins and needles Having shaken them together thoroughly he filled the top of the Scarecrow s head with the mixture and stuffed the rest of the space with straw to hold it in place

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: When he had fastened the Scarecrow's head on his body again he said to him, Hereafter you will be a great man, for I have given you a lot of bran-new brains.
children.prevalue: When he had fastened the Scarecrow s head on his body again he said to him Hereafter you will be a great man for I have given you a lot of bran new brains

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: The Scarecrow was both pleased and proud at the fulfillment of his greatest wish, and having thanked Oz warmly he went back to his friends.
children.prevalue: The Scarecrow was both pleased and proud at the fulfillment of his greatest wish and having thanked Oz warmly he went back to his friends

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Dorothy looked at him curiously.  His head was quite bulged out at the top with brains.
children.prevalue: Dorothy looked at him curiously His head was quite bulged out at the top with brains

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: How do you feel? she asked.
children.prevalue: How do you feel she asked

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: I feel wise indeed, he answered earnestly.  When I get used to my brains I shall know everything.
children.prevalue: I feel wise indeed he answered earnestly When I get used to my brains I shall know everything

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Why are those needles and pins sticking out of your head? asked the Tin Woodman.
children.prevalue: Why are those needles and pins sticking out of your head asked the Tin Woodman

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: That is proof that he is sharp, remarked the Lion.
children.prevalue: That is proof that he is sharp remarked the Lion

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Well, I must go to Oz and get my heart, said the Woodman.  So he walked to the Throne Room and knocked at the door.
children.prevalue: Well I must go to Oz and get my heart said the Woodman So he walked to the Throne Room and knocked at the door

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Come in, called Oz, and the Woodman entered and said, I have come for my heart.
children.prevalue: Come in called Oz and the Woodman entered and said I have come for my heart

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Very well, answered the little man.  But I shall have to cut a hole in your breast, so I can put your heart in the right place.  I hope it won't hurt you.
children.prevalue: Very well answered the little man But I shall have to cut a hole in your breast so I can put your heart in the right place I hope it won t hurt you

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Oh, no, answered the Woodman.  I shall not feel it at all.
children.prevalue: Oh no answered the Woodman I shall not feel it at all

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: So Oz brought a pair of tinsmith's shears and cut a small, square hole in the left side of the Tin Woodman's breast.  Then, going to a chest of drawers, he took out a pretty heart, made entirely of silk and stuffed with sawdust.
children.prevalue: So Oz brought a pair of tinsmith s shears and cut a small square hole in the left side of the Tin Woodman s breast Then going to a chest of drawers he took out a pretty heart made entirely of silk and stuffed with sawdust

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Isn't it a beauty? he asked.
children.prevalue: Isn t it a beauty he asked

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: It is, indeed! replied the Woodman, who was greatly pleased.  But is it a kind heart?
children.prevalue: It is indeed replied the Woodman who was greatly pleased But is it a kind heart

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Oh, very! answered Oz.  He put the heart in the Woodman's breast and then replaced the square of tin, soldering it neatly together where it had been cut.
children.prevalue: Oh very answered Oz He put the heart in the Woodman s breast and then replaced the square of tin soldering it neatly together where it had been cut

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: There, said he; now you have a heart that any man might be proud of. I'm sorry I had to put a patch on your breast, but it really couldn't be helped.
children.prevalue: There said he now you have a heart that any man might be proud of I m sorry I had to put a patch on your breast but it really couldn t be helped

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Never mind the patch, exclaimed the happy Woodman.  I am very grateful to you, and shall never forget your kindness.
children.prevalue: Never mind the patch exclaimed the happy Woodman I am very grateful to you and shall never forget your kindness

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Don't speak of it, replied Oz.
children.prevalue: Don t speak of it replied Oz

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Then the Tin Woodman went back to his friends, who wished him every joy on account of his good fortune.
children.prevalue: Then the Tin Woodman went back to his friends who wished him every joy on account of his good fortune

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: The Lion now walked to the Throne Room and knocked at the door.
children.prevalue: The Lion now walked to the Throne Room and knocked at the door

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Come in, said Oz.
children.prevalue: Come in said Oz

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: I have come for my courage, announced the Lion, entering the room.
children.prevalue: I have come for my courage announced the Lion entering the room

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Very well, answered the little man; I will get it for you.
children.prevalue: Very well answered the little man I will get it for you

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: He went to a cupboard and reaching up to a high shelf took down a square green bottle, the contents of which he poured into a green-gold dish, beautifully carved.  Placing this before the Cowardly Lion, who sniffed at it as if he did not like it, the Wizard said:
children.prevalue: He went to a cupboard and reaching up to a high shelf took down a square green bottle the contents of which he poured into a green gold dish beautifully carved Placing this before the Cowardly Lion who sniffed at it as if he did not like it the Wizard said

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Drink.
children.prevalue: Drink

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: What is it? asked the Lion.
children.prevalue: What is it asked the Lion

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Well, answered Oz, if it were inside of you, it would be courage. You know, of course, that courage is always inside one; so that this really cannot be called courage until you have swallowed it.  Therefore I advise you to drink it as soon as possible.
children.prevalue: Well answered Oz if it were inside of you it would be courage You know of course that courage is always inside one so that this really cannot be called courage until you have swallowed it Therefore I advise you to drink it as soon as possible

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: The Lion hesitated no longer, but drank till the dish was empty.
children.prevalue: The Lion hesitated no longer but drank till the dish was empty

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: How do you feel now? asked Oz.
children.prevalue: How do you feel now asked Oz

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Full of courage, replied the Lion, who went joyfully back to his friends to tell them of his good fortune.
children.prevalue: Full of courage replied the Lion who went joyfully back to his friends to tell them of his good fortune

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Oz, left to himself, smiled to think of his success in giving the Scarecrow and the Tin Woodman and the Lion exactly what they thought they wanted.  How can I help being a humbug, he said, when all these people make me do things that everybody knows can't be done?  It was easy to make the Scarecrow and the Lion and the Woodman happy, because they imagined I could do anything.  But it will take more than imagination to carry Dorothy back to Kansas, and I'm sure I don't know how it can be done.
children.prevalue: Oz left to himself smiled to think of his success in giving the Scarecrow and the Tin Woodman and the Lion exactly what they thought they wanted How can I help being a humbug he said when all these people make me do things that everybody knows can t be done It was easy to make the Scarecrow and the Lion and the Woodman happy because they imagined I could do anything But it will take more than imagination to carry Dorothy back to Kansas and I m sure I don t know how it can be done

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: For three days Dorothy heard nothing from Oz.  These were sad days for the little girl, although her friends were all quite happy and contented.  The Scarecrow told them there were wonderful thoughts in his head; but he would not say what they were because he knew no one could understand them but himself.  When the Tin Woodman walked about he felt his heart rattling around in his breast; and he told Dorothy he had discovered it to be a kinder and more tender heart than the one he had owned when he was made of flesh.  The Lion declared he was afraid of nothing on earth, and would gladly face an army or a dozen of the fierce Kalidahs.
children.prevalue: For three days Dorothy heard nothing from Oz These were sad days for the little girl although her friends were all quite happy and contented The Scarecrow told them there were wonderful thoughts in his head but he would not say what they were because he knew no one could understand them but himself When the Tin Woodman walked about he felt his heart rattling around in his breast and he told Dorothy he had discovered it to be a kinder and more tender heart than the one he had owned when he was made of flesh The Lion declared he was afraid of nothing on earth and would gladly face an army or a dozen of the fierce Kalidahs

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: Thus each of the little party was satisfied except Dorothy, who longed more than ever to get back to Kansas.
children.prevalue: Thus each of the little party was satisfied except Dorothy who longed more than ever to get back to Kansas

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: On the fourth day, to her great joy, Oz sent for her, and when she entered the Throne Room he greeted her pleasantly:
children.prevalue: On the fourth day to her great joy Oz sent for her and when she entered the Throne Room he greeted her pleasantly

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Sit down, my dear; I think I have found the way to get you out of this country.
children.prevalue: Sit down my dear I think I have found the way to get you out of this country

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: And back to Kansas? she asked eagerly.
children.prevalue: And back to Kansas she asked eagerly

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Well, I'm not sure about Kansas, said Oz, for I haven't the faintest notion which way it lies.  But the first thing to do is to cross the desert, and then it should be easy to find your way home.
children.prevalue: Well I m not sure about Kansas said Oz for I haven t the faintest notion which way it lies But the first thing to do is to cross the desert and then it should be easy to find your way home

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: How can I cross the desert? she inquired.
children.prevalue: How can I cross the desert she inquired

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Well, I'll tell you what I think, said the little man.  You see, when I came to this country it was in a balloon.  You also came through the air, being carried by a cyclone.  So I believe the best way to get across the desert will be through the air.  Now, it is quite beyond my powers to make a cyclone; but I've been thinking the matter over, and I believe I can make a balloon.
children.prevalue: Well I ll tell you what I think said the little man You see when I came to this country it was in a balloon You also came through the air being carried by a cyclone So I believe the best way to get across the desert will be through the air Now it is quite beyond my powers to make a cyclone but I ve been thinking the matter over and I believe I can make a balloon

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: How? asked Dorothy.
children.prevalue: How asked Dorothy

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: A balloon, said Oz, is made of silk, which is coated with glue to keep the gas in it.  I have plenty of silk in the Palace, so it will be no trouble to make the balloon.  But in all this country there is no gas to fill the balloon with, to make it float.
children.prevalue: A balloon said Oz is made of silk which is coated with glue to keep the gas in it I have plenty of silk in the Palace so it will be no trouble to make the balloon But in all this country there is no gas to fill the balloon with to make it float

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: If it won't float, remarked Dorothy, it will be of no use to us.
children.prevalue: If it won t float remarked Dorothy it will be of no use to us

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: True, answered Oz.  But there is another way to make it float, which is to fill it with hot air.  Hot air isn't as good as gas, for if the air should get cold the balloon would come down in the desert, and we should be lost.
children.prevalue: True answered Oz But there is another way to make it float which is to fill it with hot air Hot air isn t as good as gas for if the air should get cold the balloon would come down in the desert and we should be lost

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: We! exclaimed the girl.  Are you going with me?
children.prevalue: We exclaimed the girl Are you going with me

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Yes, of course, replied Oz.  I am tired of being such a humbug.  If I should go out of this Palace my people would soon discover I am not a Wizard, and then they would be vexed with me for having deceived them. So I have to stay shut up in these rooms all day, and it gets tiresome. I'd much rather go back to Kansas with you and be in a circus again.
children.prevalue: Yes of course replied Oz I am tired of being such a humbug If I should go out of this Palace my people would soon discover I am not a Wizard and then they would be vexed with me for having deceived them So I have to stay shut up in these rooms all day and it gets tiresome I d much rather go back to Kansas with you and be in a circus again

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: I shall be glad to have your company, said Dorothy.
children.prevalue: I shall be glad to have your company said Dorothy

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Thank you, he answered.  Now, if you will help me sew the silk together, we will begin to work on our balloon.
children.prevalue: Thank you he answered Now if you will help me sew the silk together we will begin to work on our balloon

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: So Dorothy took a needle and thread, and as fast as Oz cut the strips of silk into proper shape the girl sewed them neatly together.  First there was a strip of light green silk, then a strip of dark green and then a strip of emerald green; for Oz had a fancy to make the balloon in different shades of the color about them.  It took three days to sew all the strips together, but when it was finished they had a big bag of green silk more than twenty feet long.
children.prevalue: So Dorothy took a needle and thread and as fast as Oz cut the strips of silk into proper shape the girl sewed them neatly together First there was a strip of light green silk then a strip of dark green and then a strip of emerald green for Oz had a fancy to make the balloon in different shades of the color about them It took three days to sew all the strips together but when it was finished they had a big bag of green silk more than twenty feet long

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Then Oz painted it on the inside with a coat of thin glue, to make it airtight, after which he announced that the balloon was ready.
children.prevalue: Then Oz painted it on the inside with a coat of thin glue to make it airtight after which he announced that the balloon was ready

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: But we must have a basket to ride in, he said.  So he sent the soldier with the green whiskers for a big clothes basket, which he fastened with many ropes to the bottom of the balloon.
children.prevalue: But we must have a basket to ride in he said So he sent the soldier with the green whiskers for a big clothes basket which he fastened with many ropes to the bottom of the balloon

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: When it was all ready, Oz sent word to his people that he was going to make a visit to a great brother Wizard who lived in the clouds.  The news spread rapidly throughout the city and everyone came to see the wonderful sight.
children.prevalue: When it was all ready Oz sent word to his people that he was going to make a visit to a great brother Wizard who lived in the clouds The news spread rapidly throughout the city and everyone came to see the wonderful sight

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Oz ordered the balloon carried out in front of the Palace, and the people gazed upon it with much curiosity.  The Tin Woodman had chopped a big pile of wood, and now he made a fire of it, and Oz held the bottom of the balloon over the fire so that the hot air that arose from it would be caught in the silken bag.  Gradually the balloon swelled out and rose into the air, until finally the basket just touched the ground.
children.prevalue: Oz ordered the balloon carried out in front of the Palace and the people gazed upon it with much curiosity The Tin Woodman had chopped a big pile of wood and now he made a fire of it and Oz held the bottom of the balloon over the fire so that the hot air that arose from it would be caught in the silken bag Gradually the balloon swelled out and rose into the air until finally the basket just touched the ground

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Then Oz got into the basket and said to all the people in a loud voice:
children.prevalue: Then Oz got into the basket and said to all the people in a loud voice

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: I am now going away to make a visit.  While I am gone the Scarecrow will rule over you.  I command you to obey him as you would me.
children.prevalue: I am now going away to make a visit While I am gone the Scarecrow will rule over you I command you to obey him as you would me

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: The balloon was by this time tugging hard at the rope that held it to the ground, for the air within it was hot, and this made it so much lighter in weight than the air without that it pulled hard to rise into the sky.
children.prevalue: The balloon was by this time tugging hard at the rope that held it to the ground for the air within it was hot and this made it so much lighter in weight than the air without that it pulled hard to rise into the sky

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Come, Dorothy! cried the Wizard.  Hurry up, or the balloon will fly away.
children.prevalue: Come Dorothy cried the Wizard Hurry up or the balloon will fly away

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: I can't find Toto anywhere, replied Dorothy, who did not wish to leave her little dog behind.  Toto had run into the crowd to bark at a kitten, and Dorothy at last found him.  She picked him up and ran towards the balloon.
children.prevalue: I can t find Toto anywhere replied Dorothy who did not wish to leave her little dog behind Toto had run into the crowd to bark at a kitten and Dorothy at last found him She picked him up and ran towards the balloon

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: She was within a few steps of it, and Oz was holding out his hands to help her into the basket, when, crack! went the ropes, and the balloon rose into the air without her.
children.prevalue: She was within a few steps of it and Oz was holding out his hands to help her into the basket when crack went the ropes and the balloon rose into the air without her

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: Come back! she screamed.  I want to go, too!
children.prevalue: Come back she screamed I want to go too

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: I can't come back, my dear, called Oz from the basket.  Good-bye!
children.prevalue: I can t come back my dear called Oz from the basket Good bye

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Good-bye! shouted everyone, and all eyes were turned upward to where the Wizard was riding in the basket, rising every moment farther and farther into the sky.
children.prevalue: Good bye shouted everyone and all eyes were turned upward to where the Wizard was riding in the basket rising every moment farther and farther into the sky

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: And that was the last any of them ever saw of Oz, the Wonderful Wizard, though he may have reached Omaha safely, and be there now, for all we know.  But the people remembered him lovingly, and said to one another:
children.prevalue: And that was the last any of them ever saw of Oz the Wonderful Wizard though he may have reached Omaha safely and be there now for all we know But the people remembered him lovingly and said to one another

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Oz was always our friend.  When he was here he built for us this beautiful Emerald City, and now he is gone he has left the Wise Scarecrow to rule over us.
children.prevalue: Oz was always our friend When he was here he built for us this beautiful Emerald City and now he is gone he has left the Wise Scarecrow to rule over us

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Still, for many days they grieved over the loss of the Wonderful Wizard, and would not be comforted.
children.prevalue: Still for many days they grieved over the loss of the Wonderful Wizard and would not be comforted

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Dorothy wept bitterly at the passing of her hope to get home to Kansas again; but when she thought it all over she was glad she had not gone up in a balloon.  And she also felt sorry at losing Oz, and so did her companions.
children.prevalue: Dorothy wept bitterly at the passing of her hope to get home to Kansas again but when she thought it all over she was glad she had not gone up in a balloon And she also felt sorry at losing Oz and so did her companions

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The Tin Woodman came to her and said:
children.prevalue: The Tin Woodman came to her and said

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: Truly I should be ungrateful if I failed to mourn for the man who gave me my lovely heart.  I should like to cry a little because Oz is gone, if you will kindly wipe away my tears, so that I shall not rust.
children.prevalue: Truly I should be ungrateful if I failed to mourn for the man who gave me my lovely heart I should like to cry a little because Oz is gone if you will kindly wipe away my tears so that I shall not rust

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: With pleasure, she answered, and brought a towel at once.  Then the Tin Woodman wept for several minutes, and she watched the tears carefully and wiped them away with the towel.  When he had finished, he thanked her kindly and oiled himself thoroughly with his jeweled oil-can, to guard against mishap.
children.prevalue: With pleasure she answered and brought a towel at once Then the Tin Woodman wept for several minutes and she watched the tears carefully and wiped them away with the towel When he had finished he thanked her kindly and oiled himself thoroughly with his jeweled oil can to guard against mishap

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: The Scarecrow was now the ruler of the Emerald City, and although he was not a Wizard the people were proud of him.  For, they said, there is not another city in all the world that is ruled by a stuffed man.  And, so far as they knew, they were quite right.
children.prevalue: The Scarecrow was now the ruler of the Emerald City and although he was not a Wizard the people were proud of him For they said there is not another city in all the world that is ruled by a stuffed man And so far as they knew they were quite right

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: The morning after the balloon had gone up with Oz, the four travelers met in the Throne Room and talked matters over.  The Scarecrow sat in the big throne and the others stood respectfully before him.
children.prevalue: The morning after the balloon had gone up with Oz the four travelers met in the Throne Room and talked matters over The Scarecrow sat in the big throne and the others stood respectfully before him

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: We are not so unlucky, said the new ruler, for this Palace and the Emerald City belong to us, and we can do just as we please.  When I remember that a short time ago I was up on a pole in a farmer's cornfield, and that now I am the ruler of this beautiful City, I am quite satisfied with my lot.
children.prevalue: We are not so unlucky said the new ruler for this Palace and the Emerald City belong to us and we can do just as we please When I remember that a short time ago I was up on a pole in a farmer s cornfield and that now I am the ruler of this beautiful City I am quite satisfied with my lot

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: I also, said the Tin Woodman, am well-pleased with my new heart; and, really, that was the only thing I wished in all the world.
children.prevalue: I also said the Tin Woodman am well pleased with my new heart and really that was the only thing I wished in all the world

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: For my part, I am content in knowing I am as brave as any beast that ever lived, if not braver, said the Lion modestly.
children.prevalue: For my part I am content in knowing I am as brave as any beast that ever lived if not braver said the Lion modestly

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: If Dorothy would only be contented to live in the Emerald City, continued the Scarecrow, we might all be happy together.
children.prevalue: If Dorothy would only be contented to live in the Emerald City continued the Scarecrow we might all be happy together

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: But I don't want to live here, cried Dorothy.  I want to go to Kansas, and live with Aunt Em and Uncle Henry.
children.prevalue: But I don t want to live here cried Dorothy I want to go to Kansas and live with Aunt Em and Uncle Henry

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Well, then, what can be done? inquired the Woodman.
children.prevalue: Well then what can be done inquired the Woodman

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: The Scarecrow decided to think, and he thought so hard that the pins and needles began to stick out of his brains.  Finally he said:
children.prevalue: The Scarecrow decided to think and he thought so hard that the pins and needles began to stick out of his brains Finally he said

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Why not call the Winged Monkeys, and ask them to carry you over the desert?
children.prevalue: Why not call the Winged Monkeys and ask them to carry you over the desert

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: I never thought of that! said Dorothy joyfully.  It's just the thing.  I'll go at once for the Golden Cap.
children.prevalue: I never thought of that said Dorothy joyfully It s just the thing I ll go at once for the Golden Cap

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: When she brought it into the Throne Room she spoke the magic words, and soon the band of Winged Monkeys flew in through the open window and stood beside her.
children.prevalue: When she brought it into the Throne Room she spoke the magic words and soon the band of Winged Monkeys flew in through the open window and stood beside her

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: This is the second time you have called us, said the Monkey King, bowing before the little girl.  What do you wish?
children.prevalue: This is the second time you have called us said the Monkey King bowing before the little girl What do you wish

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: I want you to fly with me to Kansas, said Dorothy.
children.prevalue: I want you to fly with me to Kansas said Dorothy

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: But the Monkey King shook his head.
children.prevalue: But the Monkey King shook his head

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: That cannot be done, he said.  We belong to this country alone, and cannot leave it.  There has never been a Winged Monkey in Kansas yet, and I suppose there never will be, for they don't belong there.  We shall be glad to serve you in any way in our power, but we cannot cross the desert.  Good-bye.
children.prevalue: That cannot be done he said We belong to this country alone and cannot leave it There has never been a Winged Monkey in Kansas yet and I suppose there never will be for they don t belong there We shall be glad to serve you in any way in our power but we cannot cross the desert Good bye

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: And with another bow, the Monkey King spread his wings and flew away through the window, followed by all his band.
children.prevalue: And with another bow the Monkey King spread his wings and flew away through the window followed by all his band

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: Dorothy was ready to cry with disappointment.  I have wasted the charm of the Golden Cap to no purpose, she said, for the Winged Monkeys cannot help me.
children.prevalue: Dorothy was ready to cry with disappointment I have wasted the charm of the Golden Cap to no purpose she said for the Winged Monkeys cannot help me

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: It is certainly too bad! said the tender-hearted Woodman.
children.prevalue: It is certainly too bad said the tender hearted Woodman

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: The Scarecrow was thinking again, and his head bulged out so horribly that Dorothy feared it would burst.
children.prevalue: The Scarecrow was thinking again and his head bulged out so horribly that Dorothy feared it would burst

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Let us call in the soldier with the green whiskers, he said, and ask his advice.
children.prevalue: Let us call in the soldier with the green whiskers he said and ask his advice

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: So the soldier was summoned and entered the Throne Room timidly, for while Oz was alive he never was allowed to come farther than the door.
children.prevalue: So the soldier was summoned and entered the Throne Room timidly for while Oz was alive he never was allowed to come farther than the door

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: This little girl, said the Scarecrow to the soldier, wishes to cross the desert.  How can she do so?
children.prevalue: This little girl said the Scarecrow to the soldier wishes to cross the desert How can she do so

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: I cannot tell, answered the soldier, for nobody has ever crossed the desert, unless it is Oz himself.
children.prevalue: I cannot tell answered the soldier for nobody has ever crossed the desert unless it is Oz himself

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Is there no one who can help me? asked Dorothy earnestly.
children.prevalue: Is there no one who can help me asked Dorothy earnestly

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: Glinda might, he suggested.
children.prevalue: Glinda might he suggested

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Who is Glinda? inquired the Scarecrow.
children.prevalue: Who is Glinda inquired the Scarecrow

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: The Witch of the South.  She is the most powerful of all the Witches, and rules over the Quadlings.  Besides, her castle stands on the edge of the desert, so she may know a way to cross it.
children.prevalue: The Witch of the South She is the most powerful of all the Witches and rules over the Quadlings Besides her castle stands on the edge of the desert so she may know a way to cross it

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Glinda is a Good Witch, isn't she? asked the child.
children.prevalue: Glinda is a Good Witch isn t she asked the child

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: The Quadlings think she is good, said the soldier, and she is kind to everyone.  I have heard that Glinda is a beautiful woman, who knows how to keep young in spite of the many years she has lived.
children.prevalue: The Quadlings think she is good said the soldier and she is kind to everyone I have heard that Glinda is a beautiful woman who knows how to keep young in spite of the many years she has lived

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: How can I get to her castle? asked Dorothy.
children.prevalue: How can I get to her castle asked Dorothy

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: The road is straight to the South, he answered, but it is said to be full of dangers to travelers.  There are wild beasts in the woods, and a race of queer men who do not like strangers to cross their country. For this reason none of the Quadlings ever come to the Emerald City.
children.prevalue: The road is straight to the South he answered but it is said to be full of dangers to travelers There are wild beasts in the woods and a race of queer men who do not like strangers to cross their country For this reason none of the Quadlings ever come to the Emerald City

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: The soldier then left them and the Scarecrow said:
children.prevalue: The soldier then left them and the Scarecrow said

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: It seems, in spite of dangers, that the best thing Dorothy can do is to travel to the Land of the South and ask Glinda to help her.  For, of course, if Dorothy stays here she will never get back to Kansas.
children.prevalue: It seems in spite of dangers that the best thing Dorothy can do is to travel to the Land of the South and ask Glinda to help her For of course if Dorothy stays here she will never get back to Kansas

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: You must have been thinking again, remarked the Tin Woodman.
children.prevalue: You must have been thinking again remarked the Tin Woodman

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: I have, said the Scarecrow.
children.prevalue: I have said the Scarecrow

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: I shall go with Dorothy, declared the Lion, for I am tired of your city and long for the woods and the country again.  I am really a wild beast, you know.  Besides, Dorothy will need someone to protect her.
children.prevalue: I shall go with Dorothy declared the Lion for I am tired of your city and long for the woods and the country again I am really a wild beast you know Besides Dorothy will need someone to protect her

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: That is true, agreed the Woodman.  My axe may be of service to her; so I also will go with her to the Land of the South.
children.prevalue: That is true agreed the Woodman My axe may be of service to her so I also will go with her to the Land of the South

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: When shall we start? asked the Scarecrow.
children.prevalue: When shall we start asked the Scarecrow

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: Are you going? they asked, in surprise.
children.prevalue: Are you going they asked in surprise

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: Certainly.  If it wasn't for Dorothy I should never have had brains. She lifted me from the pole in the cornfield and brought me to the Emerald City.  So my good luck is all due to her, and I shall never leave her until she starts back to Kansas for good and all.
children.prevalue: Certainly If it wasn t for Dorothy I should never have had brains She lifted me from the pole in the cornfield and brought me to the Emerald City So my good luck is all due to her and I shall never leave her until she starts back to Kansas for good and all

children.name: Paragraph_46
children.value: Thank you, said Dorothy gratefully.  You are all very kind to me. But I should like to start as soon as possible.
children.prevalue: Thank you said Dorothy gratefully You are all very kind to me But I should like to start as soon as possible

children.name: Paragraph_47
children.value: We shall go tomorrow morning, returned the Scarecrow.  So now let us all get ready, for it will be a long journey.
children.prevalue: We shall go tomorrow morning returned the Scarecrow So now let us all get ready for it will be a long journey

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The next morning Dorothy kissed the pretty green girl good-bye, and they all shook hands with the soldier with the green whiskers, who had walked with them as far as the gate.  When the Guardian of the Gate saw them again he wondered greatly that they could leave the beautiful City to get into new trouble.  But he at once unlocked their spectacles, which he put back into the green box, and gave them many good wishes to carry with them.
