children.prevalue: The next morning Dorothy kissed the pretty green girl good bye and they all shook hands with the soldier with the green whiskers who had walked with them as far as the gate When the Guardian of the Gate saw them again he wondered greatly that they could leave the beautiful City to get into new trouble But he at once unlocked their spectacles which he put back into the green box and gave them many good wishes to carry with them

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: You are now our ruler, he said to the Scarecrow; so you must come back to us as soon as possible.
children.prevalue: You are now our ruler he said to the Scarecrow so you must come back to us as soon as possible

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: I certainly shall if I am able, the Scarecrow replied; but I must help Dorothy to get home, first.
children.prevalue: I certainly shall if I am able the Scarecrow replied but I must help Dorothy to get home first

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: As Dorothy bade the good-natured Guardian a last farewell she said:
children.prevalue: As Dorothy bade the good natured Guardian a last farewell she said

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: I have been very kindly treated in your lovely City, and everyone has been good to me.  I cannot tell you how grateful I am.
children.prevalue: I have been very kindly treated in your lovely City and everyone has been good to me I cannot tell you how grateful I am

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Don't try, my dear, he answered.  We should like to keep you with us, but if it is your wish to return to Kansas, I hope you will find a way.  He then opened the gate of the outer wall, and they walked forth and started upon their journey.
children.prevalue: Don t try my dear he answered We should like to keep you with us but if it is your wish to return to Kansas I hope you will find a way He then opened the gate of the outer wall and they walked forth and started upon their journey

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: The sun shone brightly as our friends turned their faces toward the Land of the South.  They were all in the best of spirits, and laughed and chatted together.  Dorothy was once more filled with the hope of getting home, and the Scarecrow and the Tin Woodman were glad to be of use to her.  As for the Lion, he sniffed the fresh air with delight and whisked his tail from side to side in pure joy at being in the country again, while Toto ran around them and chased the moths and butterflies, barking merrily all the time.
children.prevalue: The sun shone brightly as our friends turned their faces toward the Land of the South They were all in the best of spirits and laughed and chatted together Dorothy was once more filled with the hope of getting home and the Scarecrow and the Tin Woodman were glad to be of use to her As for the Lion he sniffed the fresh air with delight and whisked his tail from side to side in pure joy at being in the country again while Toto ran around them and chased the moths and butterflies barking merrily all the time

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: City life does not agree with me at all, remarked the Lion, as they walked along at a brisk pace.  I have lost much flesh since I lived there, and now I am anxious for a chance to show the other beasts how courageous I have grown.
children.prevalue: City life does not agree with me at all remarked the Lion as they walked along at a brisk pace I have lost much flesh since I lived there and now I am anxious for a chance to show the other beasts how courageous I have grown

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: They now turned and took a last look at the Emerald City.  All they could see was a mass of towers and steeples behind the green walls, and high up above everything the spires and dome of the Palace of Oz.
children.prevalue: They now turned and took a last look at the Emerald City All they could see was a mass of towers and steeples behind the green walls and high up above everything the spires and dome of the Palace of Oz

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Oz was not such a bad Wizard, after all, said the Tin Woodman, as he felt his heart rattling around in his breast.
children.prevalue: Oz was not such a bad Wizard after all said the Tin Woodman as he felt his heart rattling around in his breast

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: He knew how to give me brains, and very good brains, too, said the Scarecrow.
children.prevalue: He knew how to give me brains and very good brains too said the Scarecrow

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: If Oz had taken a dose of the same courage he gave me, added the Lion, he would have been a brave man.
children.prevalue: If Oz had taken a dose of the same courage he gave me added the Lion he would have been a brave man

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Dorothy said nothing.  Oz had not kept the promise he made her, but he had done his best, so she forgave him.  As he said, he was a good man, even if he was a bad Wizard.
children.prevalue: Dorothy said nothing Oz had not kept the promise he made her but he had done his best so she forgave him As he said he was a good man even if he was a bad Wizard

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: The first day's journey was through the green fields and bright flowers that stretched about the Emerald City on every side.  They slept that night on the grass, with nothing but the stars over them; and they rested very well indeed.
children.prevalue: The first day s journey was through the green fields and bright flowers that stretched about the Emerald City on every side They slept that night on the grass with nothing but the stars over them and they rested very well indeed

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: In the morning they traveled on until they came to a thick wood.  There was no way of going around it, for it seemed to extend to the right and left as far as they could see; and, besides, they did not dare change the direction of their journey for fear of getting lost.  So they looked for the place where it would be easiest to get into the forest.
children.prevalue: In the morning they traveled on until they came to a thick wood There was no way of going around it for it seemed to extend to the right and left as far as they could see and besides they did not dare change the direction of their journey for fear of getting lost So they looked for the place where it would be easiest to get into the forest

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: The Scarecrow, who was in the lead, finally discovered a big tree with such wide-spreading branches that there was room for the party to pass underneath.  So he walked forward to the tree, but just as he came under the first branches they bent down and twined around him, and the next minute he was raised from the ground and flung headlong among his fellow travelers.
children.prevalue: The Scarecrow who was in the lead finally discovered a big tree with such wide spreading branches that there was room for the party to pass underneath So he walked forward to the tree but just as he came under the first branches they bent down and twined around him and the next minute he was raised from the ground and flung headlong among his fellow travelers

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: This did not hurt the Scarecrow, but it surprised him, and he looked rather dizzy when Dorothy picked him up.
children.prevalue: This did not hurt the Scarecrow but it surprised him and he looked rather dizzy when Dorothy picked him up

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Here is another space between the trees, called the Lion.
children.prevalue: Here is another space between the trees called the Lion

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Let me try it first, said the Scarecrow, for it doesn't hurt me to get thrown about.  He walked up to another tree, as he spoke, but its branches immediately seized him and tossed him back again.
children.prevalue: Let me try it first said the Scarecrow for it doesn t hurt me to get thrown about He walked up to another tree as he spoke but its branches immediately seized him and tossed him back again

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: This is strange, exclaimed Dorothy.  What shall we do?
children.prevalue: This is strange exclaimed Dorothy What shall we do

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: The trees seem to have made up their minds to fight us, and stop our journey, remarked the Lion.
children.prevalue: The trees seem to have made up their minds to fight us and stop our journey remarked the Lion

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: I believe I will try it myself, said the Woodman, and shouldering his axe, he marched up to the first tree that had handled the Scarecrow so roughly.  When a big branch bent down to seize him the Woodman chopped at it so fiercely that he cut it in two.  At once the tree began shaking all its branches as if in pain, and the Tin Woodman passed safely under it.
children.prevalue: I believe I will try it myself said the Woodman and shouldering his axe he marched up to the first tree that had handled the Scarecrow so roughly When a big branch bent down to seize him the Woodman chopped at it so fiercely that he cut it in two At once the tree began shaking all its branches as if in pain and the Tin Woodman passed safely under it

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: Come on! he shouted to the others.  Be quick!  They all ran forward and passed under the tree without injury, except Toto, who was caught by a small branch and shaken until he howled.  But the Woodman promptly chopped off the branch and set the little dog free.
children.prevalue: Come on he shouted to the others Be quick They all ran forward and passed under the tree without injury except Toto who was caught by a small branch and shaken until he howled But the Woodman promptly chopped off the branch and set the little dog free

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: The other trees of the forest did nothing to keep them back, so they made up their minds that only the first row of trees could bend down their branches, and that probably these were the policemen of the forest, and given this wonderful power in order to keep strangers out of it.
children.prevalue: The other trees of the forest did nothing to keep them back so they made up their minds that only the first row of trees could bend down their branches and that probably these were the policemen of the forest and given this wonderful power in order to keep strangers out of it

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: The four travelers walked with ease through the trees until they came to the farther edge of the wood.  Then, to their surprise, they found before them a high wall which seemed to be made of white china.  It was smooth, like the surface of a dish, and higher than their heads.
children.prevalue: The four travelers walked with ease through the trees until they came to the farther edge of the wood Then to their surprise they found before them a high wall which seemed to be made of white china It was smooth like the surface of a dish and higher than their heads

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: What shall we do now? asked Dorothy.
children.prevalue: What shall we do now asked Dorothy

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: I will make a ladder, said the Tin Woodman, for we certainly must climb over the wall.
children.prevalue: I will make a ladder said the Tin Woodman for we certainly must climb over the wall

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: While the Woodman was making a ladder from wood which he found in the forest Dorothy lay down and slept, for she was tired by the long walk. The Lion also curled himself up to sleep and Toto lay beside him.
children.prevalue: While the Woodman was making a ladder from wood which he found in the forest Dorothy lay down and slept for she was tired by the long walk The Lion also curled himself up to sleep and Toto lay beside him

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: The Scarecrow watched the Woodman while he worked, and said to him:
children.prevalue: The Scarecrow watched the Woodman while he worked and said to him

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: I cannot think why this wall is here, nor what it is made of.
children.prevalue: I cannot think why this wall is here nor what it is made of

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Rest your brains and do not worry about the wall, replied the Woodman.  When we have climbed over it, we shall know what is on the other side.
children.prevalue: Rest your brains and do not worry about the wall replied the Woodman When we have climbed over it we shall know what is on the other side

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: After a time the ladder was finished.  It looked clumsy, but the Tin Woodman was sure it was strong and would answer their purpose.  The Scarecrow waked Dorothy and the Lion and Toto, and told them that the ladder was ready.  The Scarecrow climbed up the ladder first, but he was so awkward that Dorothy had to follow close behind and keep him from falling off.  When he got his head over the top of the wall the Scarecrow said, Oh, my!
children.prevalue: After a time the ladder was finished It looked clumsy but the Tin Woodman was sure it was strong and would answer their purpose The Scarecrow waked Dorothy and the Lion and Toto and told them that the ladder was ready The Scarecrow climbed up the ladder first but he was so awkward that Dorothy had to follow close behind and keep him from falling off When he got his head over the top of the wall the Scarecrow said Oh my

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: Go on, exclaimed Dorothy.
children.prevalue: Go on exclaimed Dorothy

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: So the Scarecrow climbed farther up and sat down on the top of the wall, and Dorothy put her head over and cried, Oh, my! just as the Scarecrow had done.
children.prevalue: So the Scarecrow climbed farther up and sat down on the top of the wall and Dorothy put her head over and cried Oh my just as the Scarecrow had done

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Then Toto came up, and immediately began to bark, but Dorothy made him be still.
children.prevalue: Then Toto came up and immediately began to bark but Dorothy made him be still

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: The Lion climbed the ladder next, and the Tin Woodman came last; but both of them cried, Oh, my! as soon as they looked over the wall. When they were all sitting in a row on the top of the wall, they looked down and saw a strange sight.
children.prevalue: The Lion climbed the ladder next and the Tin Woodman came last but both of them cried Oh my as soon as they looked over the wall When they were all sitting in a row on the top of the wall they looked down and saw a strange sight

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Before them was a great stretch of country having a floor as smooth and shining and white as the bottom of a big platter.  Scattered around were many houses made entirely of china and painted in the brightest colors.  These houses were quite small, the biggest of them reaching only as high as Dorothy's waist.  There were also pretty little barns, with china fences around them; and many cows and sheep and horses and pigs and chickens, all made of china, were standing about in groups.
children.prevalue: Before them was a great stretch of country having a floor as smooth and shining and white as the bottom of a big platter Scattered around were many houses made entirely of china and painted in the brightest colors These houses were quite small the biggest of them reaching only as high as Dorothy s waist There were also pretty little barns with china fences around them and many cows and sheep and horses and pigs and chickens all made of china were standing about in groups

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: But the strangest of all were the people who lived in this queer country.  There were milkmaids and shepherdesses, with brightly colored bodices and golden spots all over their gowns; and princesses with most gorgeous frocks of silver and gold and purple; and shepherds dressed in knee breeches with pink and yellow and blue stripes down them, and golden buckles on their shoes; and princes with jeweled crowns upon their heads, wearing ermine robes and satin doublets; and funny clowns in ruffled gowns, with round red spots upon their cheeks and tall, pointed caps.  And, strangest of all, these people were all made of china, even to their clothes, and were so small that the tallest of them was no higher than Dorothy's knee.
children.prevalue: But the strangest of all were the people who lived in this queer country There were milkmaids and shepherdesses with brightly colored bodices and golden spots all over their gowns and princesses with most gorgeous frocks of silver and gold and purple and shepherds dressed in knee breeches with pink and yellow and blue stripes down them and golden buckles on their shoes and princes with jeweled crowns upon their heads wearing ermine robes and satin doublets and funny clowns in ruffled gowns with round red spots upon their cheeks and tall pointed caps And strangest of all these people were all made of china even to their clothes and were so small that the tallest of them was no higher than Dorothy s knee

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: No one did so much as look at the travelers at first, except one little purple china dog with an extra-large head, which came to the wall and barked at them in a tiny voice, afterwards running away again.
children.prevalue: No one did so much as look at the travelers at first except one little purple china dog with an extra large head which came to the wall and barked at them in a tiny voice afterwards running away again

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: How shall we get down? asked Dorothy.
children.prevalue: How shall we get down asked Dorothy

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: They found the ladder so heavy they could not pull it up, so the Scarecrow fell off the wall and the others jumped down upon him so that the hard floor would not hurt their feet.  Of course they took pains not to light on his head and get the pins in their feet.  When all were safely down they picked up the Scarecrow, whose body was quite flattened out, and patted his straw into shape again.
children.prevalue: They found the ladder so heavy they could not pull it up so the Scarecrow fell off the wall and the others jumped down upon him so that the hard floor would not hurt their feet Of course they took pains not to light on his head and get the pins in their feet When all were safely down they picked up the Scarecrow whose body was quite flattened out and patted his straw into shape again

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: We must cross this strange place in order to get to the other side, said Dorothy, for it would be unwise for us to go any other way except due South.
children.prevalue: We must cross this strange place in order to get to the other side said Dorothy for it would be unwise for us to go any other way except due South

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: They began walking through the country of the china people, and the first thing they came to was a china milkmaid milking a china cow.  As they drew near, the cow suddenly gave a kick and kicked over the stool, the pail, and even the milkmaid herself, and all fell on the china ground with a great clatter.
children.prevalue: They began walking through the country of the china people and the first thing they came to was a china milkmaid milking a china cow As they drew near the cow suddenly gave a kick and kicked over the stool the pail and even the milkmaid herself and all fell on the china ground with a great clatter

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: Dorothy was shocked to see that the cow had broken her leg off, and that the pail was lying in several small pieces, while the poor milkmaid had a nick in her left elbow.
children.prevalue: Dorothy was shocked to see that the cow had broken her leg off and that the pail was lying in several small pieces while the poor milkmaid had a nick in her left elbow

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: There! cried the milkmaid angrily.  See what you have done!  My cow has broken her leg, and I must take her to the mender's shop and have it glued on again.  What do you mean by coming here and frightening my cow?
children.prevalue: There cried the milkmaid angrily See what you have done My cow has broken her leg and I must take her to the mender s shop and have it glued on again What do you mean by coming here and frightening my cow

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: I'm very sorry, returned Dorothy.  Please forgive us.
children.prevalue: I m very sorry returned Dorothy Please forgive us

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: But the pretty milkmaid was much too vexed to make any answer.  She picked up the leg sulkily and led her cow away, the poor animal limping on three legs.  As she left them the milkmaid cast many reproachful glances over her shoulder at the clumsy strangers, holding her nicked elbow close to her side.
children.prevalue: But the pretty milkmaid was much too vexed to make any answer She picked up the leg sulkily and led her cow away the poor animal limping on three legs As she left them the milkmaid cast many reproachful glances over her shoulder at the clumsy strangers holding her nicked elbow close to her side

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Dorothy was quite grieved at this mishap.
children.prevalue: Dorothy was quite grieved at this mishap

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: We must be very careful here, said the kind-hearted Woodman, or we may hurt these pretty little people so they will never get over it.
children.prevalue: We must be very careful here said the kind hearted Woodman or we may hurt these pretty little people so they will never get over it

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: A little farther on Dorothy met a most beautifully dressed young Princess, who stopped short as she saw the strangers and started to run away.
children.prevalue: A little farther on Dorothy met a most beautifully dressed young Princess who stopped short as she saw the strangers and started to run away

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Dorothy wanted to see more of the Princess, so she ran after her.  But the china girl cried out:
children.prevalue: Dorothy wanted to see more of the Princess so she ran after her But the china girl cried out

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Don't chase me!  Don't chase me!
children.prevalue: Don t chase me Don t chase me

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: She had such a frightened little voice that Dorothy stopped and said, Why not?
children.prevalue: She had such a frightened little voice that Dorothy stopped and said Why not

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Because, answered the Princess, also stopping, a safe distance away, if I run I may fall down and break myself.
children.prevalue: Because answered the Princess also stopping a safe distance away if I run I may fall down and break myself

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: But could you not be mended? asked the girl.
children.prevalue: But could you not be mended asked the girl

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Oh, yes; but one is never so pretty after being mended, you know, replied the Princess.
children.prevalue: Oh yes but one is never so pretty after being mended you know replied the Princess

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: I suppose not, said Dorothy.
children.prevalue: I suppose not said Dorothy

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: Now there is Mr. Joker, one of our clowns, continued the china lady, who is always trying to stand upon his head.  He has broken himself so often that he is mended in a hundred places, and doesn't look at all pretty.  Here he comes now, so you can see for yourself.
children.prevalue: Now there is Mr Joker one of our clowns continued the china lady who is always trying to stand upon his head He has broken himself so often that he is mended in a hundred places and doesn t look at all pretty Here he comes now so you can see for yourself

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Indeed, a jolly little clown came walking toward them, and Dorothy could see that in spite of his pretty clothes of red and yellow and green he was completely covered with cracks, running every which way and showing plainly that he had been mended in many places.
children.prevalue: Indeed a jolly little clown came walking toward them and Dorothy could see that in spite of his pretty clothes of red and yellow and green he was completely covered with cracks running every which way and showing plainly that he had been mended in many places

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: The Clown put his hands in his pockets, and after puffing out his cheeks and nodding his head at them saucily, he said:
children.prevalue: The Clown put his hands in his pockets and after puffing out his cheeks and nodding his head at them saucily he said

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: My lady fair,      Why do you stare    At poor old Mr. Joker?      You're quite as stiff    And prim as if      You'd eaten up a poker!
children.prevalue: My lady fair Why do you stare At poor old Mr Joker You re quite as stiff And prim as if You d eaten up a poker

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Be quiet, sir! said the Princess.  Can't you see these are strangers, and should be treated with respect?
children.prevalue: Be quiet sir said the Princess Can t you see these are strangers and should be treated with respect

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: Well, that's respect, I expect, declared the Clown, and immediately stood upon his head.
children.prevalue: Well that s respect I expect declared the Clown and immediately stood upon his head

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: Don't mind Mr. Joker, said the Princess to Dorothy.  He is considerably cracked in his head, and that makes him foolish.
children.prevalue: Don t mind Mr Joker said the Princess to Dorothy He is considerably cracked in his head and that makes him foolish

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Oh, I don't mind him a bit, said Dorothy.  But you are so beautiful, she continued, that I am sure I could love you dearly. Won't you let me carry you back to Kansas, and stand you on Aunt Em's mantel?  I could carry you in my basket.
children.prevalue: Oh I don t mind him a bit said Dorothy But you are so beautiful she continued that I am sure I could love you dearly Won t you let me carry you back to Kansas and stand you on Aunt Em s mantel I could carry you in my basket

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: That would make me very unhappy, answered the china Princess.  You see, here in our country we live contentedly, and can talk and move around as we please.  But whenever any of us are taken away our joints at once stiffen, and we can only stand straight and look pretty.  Of course that is all that is expected of us when we are on mantels and cabinets and drawing-room tables, but our lives are much pleasanter here in our own country.
children.prevalue: That would make me very unhappy answered the china Princess You see here in our country we live contentedly and can talk and move around as we please But whenever any of us are taken away our joints at once stiffen and we can only stand straight and look pretty Of course that is all that is expected of us when we are on mantels and cabinets and drawing room tables but our lives are much pleasanter here in our own country

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: I would not make you unhappy for all the world! exclaimed Dorothy. So I'll just say good-bye.
children.prevalue: I would not make you unhappy for all the world exclaimed Dorothy So I ll just say good bye

children.name: Paragraph_41
children.value: Good-bye, replied the Princess.
children.prevalue: Good bye replied the Princess

children.name: Paragraph_42
children.value: They walked carefully through the china country.  The little animals and all the people scampered out of their way, fearing the strangers would break them, and after an hour or so the travelers reached the other side of the country and came to another china wall.
children.prevalue: They walked carefully through the china country The little animals and all the people scampered out of their way fearing the strangers would break them and after an hour or so the travelers reached the other side of the country and came to another china wall

children.name: Paragraph_43
children.value: It was not so high as the first, however, and by standing upon the Lion's back they all managed to scramble to the top.  Then the Lion gathered his legs under him and jumped on the wall; but just as he jumped, he upset a china church with his tail and smashed it all to pieces.
children.prevalue: It was not so high as the first however and by standing upon the Lion s back they all managed to scramble to the top Then the Lion gathered his legs under him and jumped on the wall but just as he jumped he upset a china church with his tail and smashed it all to pieces

children.name: Paragraph_44
children.value: That was too bad, said Dorothy, but really I think we were lucky in not doing these little people more harm than breaking a cow's leg and a church.  They are all so brittle!
children.prevalue: That was too bad said Dorothy but really I think we were lucky in not doing these little people more harm than breaking a cow s leg and a church They are all so brittle

children.name: Paragraph_45
children.value: They are, indeed, said the Scarecrow, and I am thankful I am made of straw and cannot be easily damaged.  There are worse things in the world than being a Scarecrow.
children.prevalue: They are indeed said the Scarecrow and I am thankful I am made of straw and cannot be easily damaged There are worse things in the world than being a Scarecrow

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: After climbing down from the china wall the travelers found themselves in a disagreeable country, full of bogs and marshes and covered with tall, rank grass.  It was difficult to walk without falling into muddy holes, for the grass was so thick that it hid them from sight. However, by carefully picking their way, they got safely along until they reached solid ground.  But here the country seemed wilder than ever, and after a long and tiresome walk through the underbrush they entered another forest, where the trees were bigger and older than any they had ever seen.
children.prevalue: After climbing down from the china wall the travelers found themselves in a disagreeable country full of bogs and marshes and covered with tall rank grass It was difficult to walk without falling into muddy holes for the grass was so thick that it hid them from sight However by carefully picking their way they got safely along until they reached solid ground But here the country seemed wilder than ever and after a long and tiresome walk through the underbrush they entered another forest where the trees were bigger and older than any they had ever seen

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: This forest is perfectly delightful, declared the Lion, looking around him with joy.  Never have I seen a more beautiful place.
children.prevalue: This forest is perfectly delightful declared the Lion looking around him with joy Never have I seen a more beautiful place

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: It seems gloomy, said the Scarecrow.
children.prevalue: It seems gloomy said the Scarecrow

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Not a bit of it, answered the Lion.  I should like to live here all my life.  See how soft the dried leaves are under your feet and how rich and green the moss is that clings to these old trees.  Surely no wild beast could wish a pleasanter home.
children.prevalue: Not a bit of it answered the Lion I should like to live here all my life See how soft the dried leaves are under your feet and how rich and green the moss is that clings to these old trees Surely no wild beast could wish a pleasanter home

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Perhaps there are wild beasts in the forest now, said Dorothy.
children.prevalue: Perhaps there are wild beasts in the forest now said Dorothy

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: I suppose there are, returned the Lion, but I do not see any of them about.
children.prevalue: I suppose there are returned the Lion but I do not see any of them about

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: They walked through the forest until it became too dark to go any farther.  Dorothy and Toto and the Lion lay down to sleep, while the Woodman and the Scarecrow kept watch over them as usual.
children.prevalue: They walked through the forest until it became too dark to go any farther Dorothy and Toto and the Lion lay down to sleep while the Woodman and the Scarecrow kept watch over them as usual

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: When morning came, they started again.  Before they had gone far they heard a low rumble, as of the growling of many wild animals.  Toto whimpered a little, but none of the others was frightened, and they kept along the well-trodden path until they came to an opening in the wood, in which were gathered hundreds of beasts of every variety. There were tigers and elephants and bears and wolves and foxes and all the others in the natural history, and for a moment Dorothy was afraid. But the Lion explained that the animals were holding a meeting, and he judged by their snarling and growling that they were in great trouble.
children.prevalue: When morning came they started again Before they had gone far they heard a low rumble as of the growling of many wild animals Toto whimpered a little but none of the others was frightened and they kept along the well trodden path until they came to an opening in the wood in which were gathered hundreds of beasts of every variety There were tigers and elephants and bears and wolves and foxes and all the others in the natural history and for a moment Dorothy was afraid But the Lion explained that the animals were holding a meeting and he judged by their snarling and growling that they were in great trouble

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: As he spoke several of the beasts caught sight of him, and at once the great assemblage hushed as if by magic.  The biggest of the tigers came up to the Lion and bowed, saying:
children.prevalue: As he spoke several of the beasts caught sight of him and at once the great assemblage hushed as if by magic The biggest of the tigers came up to the Lion and bowed saying

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: Welcome, O King of Beasts!  You have come in good time to fight our enemy and bring peace to all the animals of the forest once more.
children.prevalue: Welcome O King of Beasts You have come in good time to fight our enemy and bring peace to all the animals of the forest once more

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: What is your trouble? asked the Lion quietly.
children.prevalue: What is your trouble asked the Lion quietly

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: We are all threatened, answered the tiger, by a fierce enemy which has lately come into this forest.  It is a most tremendous monster, like a great spider, with a body as big as an elephant and legs as long as a tree trunk.  It has eight of these long legs, and as the monster crawls through the forest he seizes an animal with a leg and drags it to his mouth, where he eats it as a spider does a fly.  Not one of us is safe while this fierce creature is alive, and we had called a meeting to decide how to take care of ourselves when you came among us.
children.prevalue: We are all threatened answered the tiger by a fierce enemy which has lately come into this forest It is a most tremendous monster like a great spider with a body as big as an elephant and legs as long as a tree trunk It has eight of these long legs and as the monster crawls through the forest he seizes an animal with a leg and drags it to his mouth where he eats it as a spider does a fly Not one of us is safe while this fierce creature is alive and we had called a meeting to decide how to take care of ourselves when you came among us

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: The Lion thought for a moment.
children.prevalue: The Lion thought for a moment

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Are there any other lions in this forest? he asked.
children.prevalue: Are there any other lions in this forest he asked

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: No; there were some, but the monster has eaten them all.  And, besides, they were none of them nearly so large and brave as you.
children.prevalue: No there were some but the monster has eaten them all And besides they were none of them nearly so large and brave as you

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: If I put an end to your enemy, will you bow down to me and obey me as King of the Forest? inquired the Lion.
children.prevalue: If I put an end to your enemy will you bow down to me and obey me as King of the Forest inquired the Lion

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: We will do that gladly, returned the tiger; and all the other beasts roared with a mighty roar: We will!
children.prevalue: We will do that gladly returned the tiger and all the other beasts roared with a mighty roar We will

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Where is this great spider of yours now? asked the Lion.
children.prevalue: Where is this great spider of yours now asked the Lion

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Yonder, among the oak trees, said the tiger, pointing with his forefoot.
children.prevalue: Yonder among the oak trees said the tiger pointing with his forefoot

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Take good care of these friends of mine, said the Lion, and I will go at once to fight the monster.
children.prevalue: Take good care of these friends of mine said the Lion and I will go at once to fight the monster

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: He bade his comrades good-bye and marched proudly away to do battle with the enemy.
children.prevalue: He bade his comrades good bye and marched proudly away to do battle with the enemy

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: The great spider was lying asleep when the Lion found him, and it looked so ugly that its foe turned up his nose in disgust.  Its legs were quite as long as the tiger had said, and its body covered with coarse black hair.  It had a great mouth, with a row of sharp teeth a foot long; but its head was joined to the pudgy body by a neck as slender as a wasp's waist.  This gave the Lion a hint of the best way to attack the creature, and as he knew it was easier to fight it asleep than awake, he gave a great spring and landed directly upon the monster's back.  Then, with one blow of his heavy paw, all armed with sharp claws, he knocked the spider's head from its body.  Jumping down, he watched it until the long legs stopped wiggling, when he knew it was quite dead.
children.prevalue: The great spider was lying asleep when the Lion found him and it looked so ugly that its foe turned up his nose in disgust Its legs were quite as long as the tiger had said and its body covered with coarse black hair It had a great mouth with a row of sharp teeth a foot long but its head was joined to the pudgy body by a neck as slender as a wasp s waist This gave the Lion a hint of the best way to attack the creature and as he knew it was easier to fight it asleep than awake he gave a great spring and landed directly upon the monster s back Then with one blow of his heavy paw all armed with sharp claws he knocked the spider s head from its body Jumping down he watched it until the long legs stopped wiggling when he knew it was quite dead

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: The Lion went back to the opening where the beasts of the forest were waiting for him and said proudly:
children.prevalue: The Lion went back to the opening where the beasts of the forest were waiting for him and said proudly

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: You need fear your enemy no longer.
children.prevalue: You need fear your enemy no longer

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: Then the beasts bowed down to the Lion as their King, and he promised to come back and rule over them as soon as Dorothy was safely on her way to Kansas.
children.prevalue: Then the beasts bowed down to the Lion as their King and he promised to come back and rule over them as soon as Dorothy was safely on her way to Kansas

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: The four travelers passed through the rest of the forest in safety, and when they came out from its gloom saw before them a steep hill, covered from top to bottom with great pieces of rock.
children.prevalue: The four travelers passed through the rest of the forest in safety and when they came out from its gloom saw before them a steep hill covered from top to bottom with great pieces of rock

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: That will be a hard climb, said the Scarecrow, but we must get over the hill, nevertheless.
children.prevalue: That will be a hard climb said the Scarecrow but we must get over the hill nevertheless

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: So he led the way and the others followed.  They had nearly reached the first rock when they heard a rough voice cry out, Keep back!
children.prevalue: So he led the way and the others followed They had nearly reached the first rock when they heard a rough voice cry out Keep back

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: Who are you? asked the Scarecrow.
children.prevalue: Who are you asked the Scarecrow

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Then a head showed itself over the rock and the same voice said, This hill belongs to us, and we don't allow anyone to cross it.
children.prevalue: Then a head showed itself over the rock and the same voice said This hill belongs to us and we don t allow anyone to cross it

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: But we must cross it, said the Scarecrow.  We're going to the country of the Quadlings.
children.prevalue: But we must cross it said the Scarecrow We re going to the country of the Quadlings

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: But you shall not! replied the voice, and there stepped from behind the rock the strangest man the travelers had ever seen.
children.prevalue: But you shall not replied the voice and there stepped from behind the rock the strangest man the travelers had ever seen

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: He was quite short and stout and had a big head, which was flat at the top and supported by a thick neck full of wrinkles.  But he had no arms at all, and, seeing this, the Scarecrow did not fear that so helpless a creature could prevent them from climbing the hill.  So he said, I'm sorry not to do as you wish, but we must pass over your hill whether you like it or not, and he walked boldly forward.
children.prevalue: He was quite short and stout and had a big head which was flat at the top and supported by a thick neck full of wrinkles But he had no arms at all and seeing this the Scarecrow did not fear that so helpless a creature could prevent them from climbing the hill So he said I m sorry not to do as you wish but we must pass over your hill whether you like it or not and he walked boldly forward

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: As quick as lightning the man's head shot forward and his neck stretched out until the top of the head, where it was flat, struck the Scarecrow in the middle and sent him tumbling, over and over, down the hill.  Almost as quickly as it came the head went back to the body, and the man laughed harshly as he said, It isn't as easy as you think!
children.prevalue: As quick as lightning the man s head shot forward and his neck stretched out until the top of the head where it was flat struck the Scarecrow in the middle and sent him tumbling over and over down the hill Almost as quickly as it came the head went back to the body and the man laughed harshly as he said It isn t as easy as you think

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: A chorus of boisterous laughter came from the other rocks, and Dorothy saw hundreds of the armless Hammer-Heads upon the hillside, one behind every rock.
children.prevalue: A chorus of boisterous laughter came from the other rocks and Dorothy saw hundreds of the armless Hammer Heads upon the hillside one behind every rock

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: The Lion became quite angry at the laughter caused by the Scarecrow's mishap, and giving a loud roar that echoed like thunder, he dashed up the hill.
children.prevalue: The Lion became quite angry at the laughter caused by the Scarecrow s mishap and giving a loud roar that echoed like thunder he dashed up the hill

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: Again a head shot swiftly out, and the great Lion went rolling down the hill as if he had been struck by a cannon ball.
children.prevalue: Again a head shot swiftly out and the great Lion went rolling down the hill as if he had been struck by a cannon ball

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: Dorothy ran down and helped the Scarecrow to his feet, and the Lion came up to her, feeling rather bruised and sore, and said, It is useless to fight people with shooting heads; no one can withstand them.
children.prevalue: Dorothy ran down and helped the Scarecrow to his feet and the Lion came up to her feeling rather bruised and sore and said It is useless to fight people with shooting heads no one can withstand them

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: What can we do, then? she asked.
children.prevalue: What can we do then she asked

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: Call the Winged Monkeys, suggested the Tin Woodman.  You have still the right to command them once more.
children.prevalue: Call the Winged Monkeys suggested the Tin Woodman You have still the right to command them once more

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Very well, she answered, and putting on the Golden Cap she uttered the magic words.  The Monkeys were as prompt as ever, and in a few moments the entire band stood before her.
children.prevalue: Very well she answered and putting on the Golden Cap she uttered the magic words The Monkeys were as prompt as ever and in a few moments the entire band stood before her

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: What are your commands? inquired the King of the Monkeys, bowing low.
children.prevalue: What are your commands inquired the King of the Monkeys bowing low

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: Carry us over the hill to the country of the Quadlings, answered the girl.
children.prevalue: Carry us over the hill to the country of the Quadlings answered the girl

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: It shall be done, said the King, and at once the Winged Monkeys caught the four travelers and Toto up in their arms and flew away with them.  As they passed over the hill the Hammer-Heads yelled with vexation, and shot their heads high in the air, but they could not reach the Winged Monkeys, which carried Dorothy and her comrades safely over the hill and set them down in the beautiful country of the Quadlings.
children.prevalue: It shall be done said the King and at once the Winged Monkeys caught the four travelers and Toto up in their arms and flew away with them As they passed over the hill the Hammer Heads yelled with vexation and shot their heads high in the air but they could not reach the Winged Monkeys which carried Dorothy and her comrades safely over the hill and set them down in the beautiful country of the Quadlings

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: This is the last time you can summon us, said the leader to Dorothy; so good-bye and good luck to you.
children.prevalue: This is the last time you can summon us said the leader to Dorothy so good bye and good luck to you

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: Good-bye, and thank you very much, returned the girl; and the Monkeys rose into the air and were out of sight in a twinkling.
children.prevalue: Good bye and thank you very much returned the girl and the Monkeys rose into the air and were out of sight in a twinkling

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: The country of the Quadlings seemed rich and happy.  There was field upon field of ripening grain, with well-paved roads running between, and pretty rippling brooks with strong bridges across them.  The fences and houses and bridges were all painted bright red, just as they had been painted yellow in the country of the Winkies and blue in the country of the Munchkins.  The Quadlings themselves, who were short and fat and looked chubby and good-natured, were dressed all in red, which showed bright against the green grass and the yellowing grain.
children.prevalue: The country of the Quadlings seemed rich and happy There was field upon field of ripening grain with well paved roads running between and pretty rippling brooks with strong bridges across them The fences and houses and bridges were all painted bright red just as they had been painted yellow in the country of the Winkies and blue in the country of the Munchkins The Quadlings themselves who were short and fat and looked chubby and good natured were dressed all in red which showed bright against the green grass and the yellowing grain

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: The Monkeys had set them down near a farmhouse, and the four travelers walked up to it and knocked at the door.  It was opened by the farmer's wife, and when Dorothy asked for something to eat the woman gave them all a good dinner, with three kinds of cake and four kinds of cookies, and a bowl of milk for Toto.
children.prevalue: The Monkeys had set them down near a farmhouse and the four travelers walked up to it and knocked at the door It was opened by the farmer s wife and when Dorothy asked for something to eat the woman gave them all a good dinner with three kinds of cake and four kinds of cookies and a bowl of milk for Toto

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: How far is it to the Castle of Glinda? asked the child.
children.prevalue: How far is it to the Castle of Glinda asked the child

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: It is not a great way, answered the farmer's wife.  Take the road to the South and you will soon reach it.
children.prevalue: It is not a great way answered the farmer s wife Take the road to the South and you will soon reach it

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: Thanking the good woman, they started afresh and walked by the fields and across the pretty bridges until they saw before them a very beautiful Castle.  Before the gates were three young girls, dressed in handsome red uniforms trimmed with gold braid; and as Dorothy approached, one of them said to her:
children.prevalue: Thanking the good woman they started afresh and walked by the fields and across the pretty bridges until they saw before them a very beautiful Castle Before the gates were three young girls dressed in handsome red uniforms trimmed with gold braid and as Dorothy approached one of them said to her

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: Why have you come to the South Country?
children.prevalue: Why have you come to the South Country

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: To see the Good Witch who rules here, she answered.  Will you take me to her?
children.prevalue: To see the Good Witch who rules here she answered Will you take me to her

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: Let me have your name, and I will ask Glinda if she will receive you. They told who they were, and the girl soldier went into the Castle. After a few moments she came back to say that Dorothy and the others were to be admitted at once.
children.prevalue: Let me have your name and I will ask Glinda if she will receive you They told who they were and the girl soldier went into the Castle After a few moments she came back to say that Dorothy and the others were to be admitted at once

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Before they went to see Glinda, however, they were taken to a room of the Castle, where Dorothy washed her face and combed her hair, and the Lion shook the dust out of his mane, and the Scarecrow patted himself into his best shape, and the Woodman polished his tin and oiled his joints.
children.prevalue: Before they went to see Glinda however they were taken to a room of the Castle where Dorothy washed her face and combed her hair and the Lion shook the dust out of his mane and the Scarecrow patted himself into his best shape and the Woodman polished his tin and oiled his joints

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: When they were all quite presentable they followed the soldier girl into a big room where the Witch Glinda sat upon a throne of rubies.
children.prevalue: When they were all quite presentable they followed the soldier girl into a big room where the Witch Glinda sat upon a throne of rubies

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: She was both beautiful and young to their eyes.  Her hair was a rich red in color and fell in flowing ringlets over her shoulders.  Her dress was pure white but her eyes were blue, and they looked kindly upon the little girl.
children.prevalue: She was both beautiful and young to their eyes Her hair was a rich red in color and fell in flowing ringlets over her shoulders Her dress was pure white but her eyes were blue and they looked kindly upon the little girl

children.name: Paragraph_4
children.value: What can I do for you, my child? she asked.
children.prevalue: What can I do for you my child she asked

children.name: Paragraph_5
children.value: Dorothy told the Witch all her story: how the cyclone had brought her to the Land of Oz, how she had found her companions, and of the wonderful adventures they had met with.
children.prevalue: Dorothy told the Witch all her story how the cyclone had brought her to the Land of Oz how she had found her companions and of the wonderful adventures they had met with

children.name: Paragraph_6
children.value: My greatest wish now, she added, is to get back to Kansas, for Aunt Em will surely think something dreadful has happened to me, and that will make her put on mourning; and unless the crops are better this year than they were last, I am sure Uncle Henry cannot afford it.
children.prevalue: My greatest wish now she added is to get back to Kansas for Aunt Em will surely think something dreadful has happened to me and that will make her put on mourning and unless the crops are better this year than they were last I am sure Uncle Henry cannot afford it

children.name: Paragraph_7
children.value: Glinda leaned forward and kissed the sweet, upturned face of the loving little girl.
children.prevalue: Glinda leaned forward and kissed the sweet upturned face of the loving little girl

children.name: Paragraph_8
children.value: Bless your dear heart, she said, I am sure I can tell you of a way to get back to Kansas.  Then she added, But, if I do, you must give me the Golden Cap.
children.prevalue: Bless your dear heart she said I am sure I can tell you of a way to get back to Kansas Then she added But if I do you must give me the Golden Cap

children.name: Paragraph_9
children.value: Willingly! exclaimed Dorothy; indeed, it is of no use to me now, and when you have it you can command the Winged Monkeys three times.
children.prevalue: Willingly exclaimed Dorothy indeed it is of no use to me now and when you have it you can command the Winged Monkeys three times

children.name: Paragraph_10
children.value: And I think I shall need their service just those three times, answered Glinda, smiling.
children.prevalue: And I think I shall need their service just those three times answered Glinda smiling

children.name: Paragraph_11
children.value: Dorothy then gave her the Golden Cap, and the Witch said to the Scarecrow, What will you do when Dorothy has left us?
children.prevalue: Dorothy then gave her the Golden Cap and the Witch said to the Scarecrow What will you do when Dorothy has left us

children.name: Paragraph_12
children.value: I will return to the Emerald City, he replied, for Oz has made me its ruler and the people like me.  The only thing that worries me is how to cross the hill of the Hammer-Heads.
children.prevalue: I will return to the Emerald City he replied for Oz has made me its ruler and the people like me The only thing that worries me is how to cross the hill of the Hammer Heads

children.name: Paragraph_13
children.value: By means of the Golden Cap I shall command the Winged Monkeys to carry you to the gates of the Emerald City, said Glinda, for it would be a shame to deprive the people of so wonderful a ruler.
children.prevalue: By means of the Golden Cap I shall command the Winged Monkeys to carry you to the gates of the Emerald City said Glinda for it would be a shame to deprive the people of so wonderful a ruler

children.name: Paragraph_14
children.value: Am I really wonderful? asked the Scarecrow.
children.prevalue: Am I really wonderful asked the Scarecrow

children.name: Paragraph_15
children.value: You are unusual, replied Glinda.
children.prevalue: You are unusual replied Glinda

children.name: Paragraph_16
children.value: Turning to the Tin Woodman, she asked, What will become of you when Dorothy leaves this country?
children.prevalue: Turning to the Tin Woodman she asked What will become of you when Dorothy leaves this country

children.name: Paragraph_17
children.value: He leaned on his axe and thought a moment.  Then he said, The Winkies were very kind to me, and wanted me to rule over them after the Wicked Witch died.  I am fond of the Winkies, and if I could get back again to the Country of the West, I should like nothing better than to rule over them forever.
children.prevalue: He leaned on his axe and thought a moment Then he said The Winkies were very kind to me and wanted me to rule over them after the Wicked Witch died I am fond of the Winkies and if I could get back again to the Country of the West I should like nothing better than to rule over them forever

children.name: Paragraph_18
children.value: My second command to the Winged Monkeys, said Glinda will be that they carry you safely to the land of the Winkies.  Your brain may not be so large to look at as those of the Scarecrow, but you are really brighter than he is--when you are well polished--and I am sure you will rule the Winkies wisely and well.
children.prevalue: My second command to the Winged Monkeys said Glinda will be that they carry you safely to the land of the Winkies Your brain may not be so large to look at as those of the Scarecrow but you are really brighter than he is when you are well polished and I am sure you will rule the Winkies wisely and well

children.name: Paragraph_19
children.value: Then the Witch looked at the big, shaggy Lion and asked, When Dorothy has returned to her own home, what will become of you?
children.prevalue: Then the Witch looked at the big shaggy Lion and asked When Dorothy has returned to her own home what will become of you

children.name: Paragraph_20
children.value: Over the hill of the Hammer-Heads, he answered, lies a grand old forest, and all the beasts that live there have made me their King.  If I could only get back to this forest, I would pass my life very happily there.
children.prevalue: Over the hill of the Hammer Heads he answered lies a grand old forest and all the beasts that live there have made me their King If I could only get back to this forest I would pass my life very happily there

children.name: Paragraph_21
children.value: My third command to the Winged Monkeys, said Glinda, shall be to carry you to your forest.  Then, having used up the powers of the Golden Cap, I shall give it to the King of the Monkeys, that he and his band may thereafter be free for evermore.
children.prevalue: My third command to the Winged Monkeys said Glinda shall be to carry you to your forest Then having used up the powers of the Golden Cap I shall give it to the King of the Monkeys that he and his band may thereafter be free for evermore

children.name: Paragraph_22
children.value: The Scarecrow and the Tin Woodman and the Lion now thanked the Good Witch earnestly for her kindness; and Dorothy exclaimed:
children.prevalue: The Scarecrow and the Tin Woodman and the Lion now thanked the Good Witch earnestly for her kindness and Dorothy exclaimed

children.name: Paragraph_23
children.value: You are certainly as good as you are beautiful!  But you have not yet told me how to get back to Kansas.
children.prevalue: You are certainly as good as you are beautiful But you have not yet told me how to get back to Kansas

children.name: Paragraph_24
children.value: Your Silver Shoes will carry you over the desert, replied Glinda. If you had known their power you could have gone back to your Aunt Em the very first day you came to this country.
children.prevalue: Your Silver Shoes will carry you over the desert replied Glinda If you had known their power you could have gone back to your Aunt Em the very first day you came to this country

children.name: Paragraph_25
children.value: But then I should not have had my wonderful brains! cried the Scarecrow.  I might have passed my whole life in the farmer's cornfield.
children.prevalue: But then I should not have had my wonderful brains cried the Scarecrow I might have passed my whole life in the farmer s cornfield

children.name: Paragraph_26
children.value: And I should not have had my lovely heart, said the Tin Woodman.  I might have stood and rusted in the forest till the end of the world.
children.prevalue: And I should not have had my lovely heart said the Tin Woodman I might have stood and rusted in the forest till the end of the world

children.name: Paragraph_27
children.value: And I should have lived a coward forever, declared the Lion, and no beast in all the forest would have had a good word to say to me.
children.prevalue: And I should have lived a coward forever declared the Lion and no beast in all the forest would have had a good word to say to me

children.name: Paragraph_28
children.value: This is all true, said Dorothy, and I am glad I was of use to these good friends.  But now that each of them has had what he most desired, and each is happy in having a kingdom to rule besides, I think I should like to go back to Kansas.
children.prevalue: This is all true said Dorothy and I am glad I was of use to these good friends But now that each of them has had what he most desired and each is happy in having a kingdom to rule besides I think I should like to go back to Kansas

children.name: Paragraph_29
children.value: The Silver Shoes, said the Good Witch, have wonderful powers.  And one of the most curious things about them is that they can carry you to any place in the world in three steps, and each step will be made in the wink of an eye.  All you have to do is to knock the heels together three times and command the shoes to carry you wherever you wish to go.
children.prevalue: The Silver Shoes said the Good Witch have wonderful powers And one of the most curious things about them is that they can carry you to any place in the world in three steps and each step will be made in the wink of an eye All you have to do is to knock the heels together three times and command the shoes to carry you wherever you wish to go

children.name: Paragraph_30
children.value: If that is so, said the child joyfully, I will ask them to carry me back to Kansas at once.
children.prevalue: If that is so said the child joyfully I will ask them to carry me back to Kansas at once

children.name: Paragraph_31
children.value: She threw her arms around the Lion's neck and kissed him, patting his big head tenderly.  Then she kissed the Tin Woodman, who was weeping in a way most dangerous to his joints.  But she hugged the soft, stuffed body of the Scarecrow in her arms instead of kissing his painted face, and found she was crying herself at this sorrowful parting from her loving comrades.
children.prevalue: She threw her arms around the Lion s neck and kissed him patting his big head tenderly Then she kissed the Tin Woodman who was weeping in a way most dangerous to his joints But she hugged the soft stuffed body of the Scarecrow in her arms instead of kissing his painted face and found she was crying herself at this sorrowful parting from her loving comrades

children.name: Paragraph_32
children.value: Glinda the Good stepped down from her ruby throne to give the little girl a good-bye kiss, and Dorothy thanked her for all the kindness she had shown to her friends and herself.
children.prevalue: Glinda the Good stepped down from her ruby throne to give the little girl a good bye kiss and Dorothy thanked her for all the kindness she had shown to her friends and herself

children.name: Paragraph_33
children.value: Dorothy now took Toto up solemnly in her arms, and having said one last good-bye she clapped the heels of her shoes together three times, saying:
children.prevalue: Dorothy now took Toto up solemnly in her arms and having said one last good bye she clapped the heels of her shoes together three times saying

children.name: Paragraph_34
children.value: Take me home to Aunt Em!
children.prevalue: Take me home to Aunt Em

children.name: Paragraph_35
children.value: Instantly she was whirling through the air, so swiftly that all she could see or feel was the wind whistling past her ears.
children.prevalue: Instantly she was whirling through the air so swiftly that all she could see or feel was the wind whistling past her ears

children.name: Paragraph_36
children.value: The Silver Shoes took but three steps, and then she stopped so suddenly that she rolled over upon the grass several times before she knew where she was.
children.prevalue: The Silver Shoes took but three steps and then she stopped so suddenly that she rolled over upon the grass several times before she knew where she was

children.name: Paragraph_37
children.value: At length, however, she sat up and looked about her.
children.prevalue: At length however she sat up and looked about her

children.name: Paragraph_38
children.value: Good gracious! she cried.
children.prevalue: Good gracious she cried

children.name: Paragraph_39
children.value: For she was sitting on the broad Kansas prairie, and just before her was the new farmhouse Uncle Henry built after the cyclone had carried away the old one.  Uncle Henry was milking the cows in the barnyard, and Toto had jumped out of her arms and was running toward the barn, barking furiously.
children.prevalue: For she was sitting on the broad Kansas prairie and just before her was the new farmhouse Uncle Henry built after the cyclone had carried away the old one Uncle Henry was milking the cows in the barnyard and Toto had jumped out of her arms and was running toward the barn barking furiously

children.name: Paragraph_40
children.value: Dorothy stood up and found she was in her stocking-feet.  For the Silver Shoes had fallen off in her flight through the air, and were lost forever in the desert.
children.prevalue: Dorothy stood up and found she was in her stocking feet For the Silver Shoes had fallen off in her flight through the air and were lost forever in the desert

children.name: Paragraph_1
children.value: Aunt Em had just come out of the house to water the cabbages when she looked up and saw Dorothy running toward her.
children.prevalue: Aunt Em had just come out of the house to water the cabbages when she looked up and saw Dorothy running toward her

children.name: Paragraph_2
children.value: My darling child! she cried, folding the little girl in her arms and covering her face with kisses.  Where in the world did you come from?
children.prevalue: My darling child she cried folding the little girl in her arms and covering her face with kisses Where in the world did you come from

children.name: Paragraph_3
children.value: From the Land of Oz, said Dorothy gravely.  And here is Toto, too. And oh, Aunt Em!  I'm so glad to be at home again!
children.prevalue: From the Land of Oz said Dorothy gravely And here is Toto too And oh Aunt Em I m so glad to be at home again
